questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman presents to the emergency department to evaluate a fever and cough. The patient has been experiencing ongoing fevers for the past week. She also has a productive cough that yields greenish sputum. Past medical history includes hypertension and diabetes. She smokes one pack of cigarettes per day and does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 105/min, blood pressure is 100/66 mmHg, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Upright AP and lateral chest radiographs are obtained and demonstrated below. Which of the following anatomic locations is the most likely site for pulmonary auscultation of this patient’s pathology?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Right anterior mid clavicular line, 5th intercostal space
Right posterior mid scapular line, 5th intercostal space
Right anterior mid clavicular line, 2nd intercostal space
Right posterior mid scapular line at the level of the 10th thoracic vertebra
Right anterior midaxillary line, 6th intercostal space

questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical features of pneumonia and a right middle lobe consolidation on chest radiography. The anatomic area for pulmonary auscultation of this pathology is over the right anterior midclavicular line in the fifth intercostal space.  

The lung is divided into several lobes, which are separated by fissures. In both lungs, the oblique fissure runs posteriorly at the level of T3 to the 6th rib anteriorly at the midclavicular line. The horizontal fissure, which separates the superior and middle lobes of the right lung, connects to the right oblique fissure at the midaxillary line near the 5th rib and runs anteriorly to the area of the 4th costal cartilage. Ultimately, these anatomic distinctions create an approach for pulmonary auscultation: most posterior auscultation examines the inferior lobes, whereas anterior auscultation primarily concerns the superior and middle lobes.  

Auscultation should be performed sequentially from the lung apices to the lungs bases. Auscultation should be performed on both the anterior and posterior chest, and sounds of the left chest should be compared to those of the right. Auscultating in this manner will ensure comprehensive examination and evaluation of all the relevant anatomical components of the lungs.    



Option Analysis

✅ Right anterior mid clavicular line, 5th intercostal space:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Right posterior mid scapular line, 5th intercostal space:
Incorrect: The right middle lobe is best auscultated anteriorly over the fourth or fifth intercostal space, midclavicular line. Posterior auscultation will typically only reveal abnormalities of the superior and inferior lobes of the right lung.
❌ Right anterior mid clavicular line, 2nd intercostal space :
Incorrect: This anatomic location is most effective for auscultating the superior lobe of the right lung, not the right middle lobe.
❌ Right posterior mid scapular line at the level of the 10th thoracic vertebra:
Incorrect: This anatomic location is the best space for auscultating the lung bases, not the right middle lobe.
❌ Right anterior midaxillary line, 6th intercostal space :
Incorrect: This space describes the most appropriate area for auscultation of the inferior lobe of the right lung, not the right middle lobe.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department with chest pain. The patient describes the pain as a crushing sensation in the middle of his chest that radiates to the jaw. The pain started two hours ago while he was watching television. He has a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus, but his insurance has lapsed so he does not currently take medication for either condition. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 20 years. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 90/70 mmHg, pulse is 120 bpm, and respirations are 22/minute. Oxygen saturation is 96%. The patient appears anxious and in distress. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the acute management of this patient?

choices.text: Prepare the patient for cardiac catheterization

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms consistent with acute coronary syndrome. Acute coronary syndrome (ACS) is an emergency that requires immediate care and prompt diagnostic evaluation to determine the cause and appropriate treatment. However, because of the rapidly progressive nature of the disease, any patient with a suspicion for acute coronary syndrome should be managed acutely prior to diagnostic evaluation.    

Acute management of patients with ACS starts with assessing the stability of the patient (ABCDE criteria). Patients who are unstable (e.g. hypotension) should be immediately stabilized and then assessed for the possible cause.    

For patients who are unstable (like this patient), acute management begins with obtaining intravenous access; monitoring blood pressure, heart rhythm and oxygen levels; and providing oxygen supplementation if needed.    

After the acute management of ACS is complete, evaluation to obtain an accurate diagnosis should begin immediately, which involves a focused history and physical examination, prompt 12-lead ECG, and cardiac troponin assessment.




Option Analysis

✅ Obtain intravenous access:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Provide supplemental oxygen :
Incorrect: Although oxygen monitoring and supplementation if needed are part of the acute management of acute coronary syndrome, this patient does not need oxygen supplementation as his oxygen saturation is above 95%.  
❌ Obtain a twelve-lead ECG:
Incorrect: Twelve-lead ECG should be obtained after the acute management of this unstable patient, which involves obtaining IV access, monitoring heart rhythm and blood pressure, and providing supplemental oxygen if needed.  
❌ Assess cardiac troponins :
Incorrect: Assessing cardiac troponins is part of the diagnostic evaluation of patients with acute coronary syndrome. However, acute management should precede diagnostic evaluations.  
❌ Prepare the patient for cardiac catheterization :
Incorrect: Catheterization is performed after the diagnosis acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) is made based on elevated cardiac enzymes and ST-segment elevation on ECG. This patient needs acute management before proceeding with the diagnostic evaluation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to his outpatient provider because of headaches and changes in vision that began one-month ago. The headaches are worse in the morning and improve over the day. Past medical history is notable for Cushing syndrome refractory to medical treatment, for which the patient underwent a bilateral adrenalectomy seven-months ago. He was prescribed hydrocortisone supplements after the surgery but has been inconsistent in taking his medications. In the office, his temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F) and blood pressure is 120/79 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for hyperpigmentation of the skin. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopsia. Laboratory testing is notable for a serum ACTH of 700 pg/mL. Magnetic resonance imaging confirms the patient’s underlying condition. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Transsphenoidal resection of the pituitary gland

questions.solution:
This patient has Nelson syndrome, which is a condition in which the pituitary gland enlarges after bilateral adrenalectomy. Bilateral adrenalectomy can be performed to treat Cushing syndrome in patients who have failed more conservative treatment options.  

 The pathophysiology of Nelson syndrome is not fully understood. However, one proposed mechanism is that after the bilateral adrenal glands are excised, there is removal of negative-feedback to the hypothalamus and pituitary, since endogenous cortisol is no longer being synthesized. This results in increased corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) from the hypothalamus. The elevated CRH subsequently increases ACTH production by the pituitary gland. Overtime, the result is pituitary enlargement. In addition, since ACTH and melanocyte stimulating hormone (MSH) are derived from the same precursor molecule, increased ACTH production would also lead to increased MSH production.  

The enlarged pituitary can compress nearby nerves and cause headaches. Moreover, the enlarged pituitary can compress the optic chiasm and cause bitemporal hemianopsia. Patients can also have skin hyperpigmentation secondary to the increased MSH production.    

Surgical resection of the pituitary is the first-line treatment of Nelson syndrome. Radiotherapy or radiosurgery can be utilized in patients who have failed first-line treatment. Medications such as bromocriptine and cabergoline have been tested, but these are generally not as effective as surgical intervention.  

Option Analysis

❌ Initiation of dexamethasone supplementation:
Incorrect: Patients who have undergone bilateral adrenalectomy should take glucocorticoid supplements. This helps prevent the symptoms of adrenal insufficiency. In contrast, this patient’s symptoms of morning headaches and visual disturbances are most consistent with Nelson syndrome (post-adrenalectomy enlargement of the pituitary gland). Glucocorticoid supplements are ineffective in treating Nelson syndrome.    
✅ Transsphenoidal resection of the pituitary gland  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Initiation of octreotide therapy:
Incorrect: Octreotide can be used to treat acromegaly and gigantism in patients with growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenomas. However, there is little data supporting the efficacy of octreotide in treating the ACTH-secreting pituitary adenomas found in patients with Nelson syndrome.    
❌ Resection of the hypothalamus  :
Incorrect: The patient’s symptom of bitemporal hemianopsia is suggestive of a pituitary adenoma that is compressing the optic chiasm. Surgical intervention should be focused on resecting the enlarged pituitary and not the hypothalamus.    
❌ Initiation of chemotherapy:
Incorrect: A pituitary adenoma can compress the optic chiasm and cause bitemporal hemianopsia. However, adenomas are benign tumors. Chemotherapy is not indicated in the treatment of pituitary adenomas, and it can lead to severe side-effects in the patient.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency room with a sudden onset of dizziness and gait instability that began two days earlier. Since it began, she has experienced constant dizziness, nausea, and vomiting, despite trying multiple over the counter medications. The patient also complains of hearing loss in her right ear. On further questioning, she notes that she had a runny nose and dry cough approximately 1 week ago that resolved on its own. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows congested nasal mucosa, oropharyngeal erythema without exudate, and no tenderness to palpation of the sinuses. Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention?
questions.solution:
This patient, who presents with acute onset of persistent dizziness, instability, hearing loss, nausea, and vomiting following a viral infection, most likely has labyrinthitis. Of the options above, only meclizine, an antihistamine, is used to prevent the nausea, vomiting, and dizziness caused by peripheral vertigo.  

Labyrinthitis is inflammation of the inner ear that results in vertigo, hearing loss and ringing in the ears. It typically occurs as an acute attack that lasts for days. It may be associated with nausea, vomiting, and nystagmus. It is thought to be a viral or post-viral inflammatory disorder affecting the vestibular portion of the eighth cranial nerve. Although symptoms are disabling, it is a benign disorder, is self-limited, and recovery is complete in most patients. In pure vestibular neuritis, auditory function is preserved, but when combined with unilateral hearing loss, the condition is called labyrinthitis. Treatment for labyrinthitis includes steroids, as well as symptomatic treatment to reduce vertigo, nausea, and vomiting. These include antihistamines, antiemetics, anticholinergics, and benzodiazepines. Antihistamines are typically the drug of choice.  

Option Analysis

❌ Amoxicillin :
Incorrect: Amoxicillin could be used for the treatment of otitis media or a sinus infection, both of which can lead to bacterial labyrinthitis. However, given her presentation and physical exam findings, she is more likely to be suffering from a viral infection.  
❌ Epley maneuver:
Incorrect: The Epley maneuver is used to treat benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), which is caused by a dislodged otolith. The maneuver attempts to reposition the otolith, thus preventing future attacks of vertigo. This patient’s presentation is consistent with vestibular neuritis.    
✅ Meclizine :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Midodrine :
Incorrect: Midodrine is an alpha-agonist that is used in treating orthostatic hypotension. Although orthostatic hypotension can also cause dizziness, patients will complain of it primarily when adjusting from sitting to standing. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with vestibular neuritis.    
❌ Non-steroidal antiinflammatory drugs:
Incorrect: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are used in various conditions to reduce pain, decrease fever, prevent blood clots and, in higher doses, decrease inflammation. Although labyrinthitis involves inflammation, NSAIDS will not aid in the vestibular symptoms this patient is experiencing.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old man comes to the emergency department with two weeks of fevers and chills. He also reports a poor appetite and has noticed a weight loss of 2.3 kg (5 lb) over the past month. He also complains of malaise with intermittent headaches, muscle aches, and night sweats over this same time period. Medical history is significant for chronic kidney disease (CKD) stage II, due to hypertension. Medications include lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. He was born in India, and he does not drink alcohol or use recreational drugs. His temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse is 45/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 100/50 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. He appears ill. Physical exam shows a regularly irregular heartbeat with a high-pitched, early diastolic decrescendo murmur. Lung auscultation reveals crackles at the bilateral lung bases. Laboratory studies show renal function at baseline and normal cardiac enzymes. An ECG is obtained and shows the following:  



 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s ECG shows second-degree Mobitz type II atrioventricular (AV) block. This heart block is characterized by “all-or-nothing” conduction of electrical impulses through the AV node, leading to dropped beats that appear as a P wave without a subsequent QRS complex. Compared to the lengthening PR intervals in second-degree Mobitz type I (Wenckebach) AV block, Mobitz type II AV block demonstrates a stable PR interval.



Causes of Mobitz type II AV block overlap with the causes of other AV blocks, including myocardial ischemia, cardiomyopathy (e.g., amyloidosis, sarcoidosis), myocarditis (e.g. Lyme disease), hyperkalemia, and medication effects. This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of infective endocarditis, including high fevers, night sweats, anorexia, weight loss, and myalgias. Infective endocarditis of the aortic valve may lead to a periannular abscess at the base of the valve, which places pressure on the adjacent AV node, leading to heart block. An abscess in this location may also lead to aortic insufficiency, which is consistent with the murmur present on this patient’s exam.  

Initial management of all patients with Mobitz type II AV block involves the placement of transcutaneous pacer pads, as this block may cause profound bradycardia and progress to third-degree heart block at any time. If no reversible cause is found, patients will require permanent pacemaker implantation.    

Option Analysis

❌  Left heart catheterization:
Incorrect: Left heart catheterization lets interventional cardiologists visualize the anatomy and patency of the coronary arteries and deploy stents to obstructed vessels. Patients with acutely obstructed coronary arteries who need left heart catheterization would instead present with ST-segment changes and elevated cardiac enzymes.  
❌ Intubation:
Incorrect: Patients with acute or worsening hypoxia, severely altered mental status, or airway obstruction should be intubated to provide mechanical ventilation while the underlying problem is fixed. This patient has a peripheral oxygen saturation greater than 90% on room air and does not require mechanical ventilation.  
❌ Defibrillation:
Incorrect: Defibrillation refers to the application of electricity across the chest to shock the heart back into sinus rhythm, and it only works on ventricular tachycardia (VT) and ventricular fibrillation (VF). Defibrillating a patient who does not have VT of VF can cause a deadly arrhythmia.  
✅ Transcutaneous pacing:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ No treatment is required:
Incorrect: Second-degree type II AV block is a dangerous arrhythmia that can develop into complete heart block and cause circulatory collapse at any time. It must be treated urgently and will require pacemaker placement.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of severe pain in his right big toe. He states the toe feels warm and looks swollen and red. He began chemotherapy last week for treatment of acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 77/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 122/82 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals an erythematous and swollen right first metatarsophalangeal joint. It is tender to palpation with decreased active and passive range of motion. Therapy with which of the following medications could have prevented this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with severe, acute onset pain in his right big toe shortly after initiating chemotherapy for acute lymphoblastic leukemia. He most likely has an acute gout attack secondary to tumor lysis syndrome.    

Widespread lysis of tumor cells can release significant amounts of intracellular components, such as potassium and uric acid. The acute increase in serum uric acid levels overwhelms the excretory capacity of the kidneys, causing uric acid to precipitate and crystallize in joints.    

Prophylaxis in patients, therefore, consists of aggressive hydration, often done intravenously (IV). The goal of IV hydration is to improve renal perfusion and glomerular filtration, and maintain high urine output to reduce the likelihood of uric acid precipitation in the tubules and oversaturation in the blood. In patients considered particularly high-risk for developing tumor lysis syndrome, allopurinol, an inhibitor of xanthine oxidase (the enzyme that converts metabolites into uric acid), can effectively decrease the formation of new uric acid.   

Option Analysis

✅ Allopurinol :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Colchicine:
Incorrect: Colchicine inhibits microtubule polymerization, which inhibits phagocytosis of urate crystals and subsequent leukocyte migration and activation. Although colchicine is useful in treating acute gout attacks, it does not reduce the incidence of future episodes.
❌ Aspirin :
Incorrect: Aspirin causes irreversible inhibition of cyclooxygenase enzymes, resulting in reduced synthesis of prostaglandins, which are involved in inflammation. However, aspirin should be avoided in gout treatment as it inhibits uric acid excretion, which could increase the risk of future episodes.
❌ Indomethacin:
Incorrect: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as indomethacin, are used mainly in the treatment of acute gout attacks. By inhibiting the synthesis of prostaglandins, a chemotactic mediator, NSAIDs reduce joint inflammation. However, NSAIDs do not prevent recurrence of future attacks.
❌ Glucocorticoids:
Incorrect: Glucocorticoids are sometimes useful in the acute treatment of gout attacks. They are not helpful in reducing recurrence of future attacks.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to agitation and altered mentation. The patient was in her usual state until a few hours ago, when she started having severe nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Medical history is remarkable for long-standing Graves disease and gastroesophageal reflux disease. Last week, the patient had an upper respiratory infection that resolved without treatment. The patient has been partially compliant in taking her medications, which include omeprazole and propylthiouracil. Temperature is 40°C (104.0°F), pulse is 150/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 150/100 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is stuporous and her skin is moist. Laboratory tests show elevated liver enzymes, mild hyperglycemia, and leukocytosis. IV propranolol is initiated. Which of the following additional medications should also be administered to this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with acute onset of nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, arrhythmia, and very high fever. In the light of the known noncompliance with medications and long-standing Graves disease, the most likely diagnosis is a thyroid storm.  

Thyroid storm is a rare, life-threatening condition typified by severe clinical manifestations of thyrotoxicosis. The condition is caused by longstanding untreated/undertreated hyperthyroidism (e.g., Graves disease, toxic multinodular goiter, toxic adenoma). It may be precipitated by an acute stress event such as surgery, trauma, infection, iodine overload, or labor. Patients may present with agitation, anxiety, delirium, psychosis, stupor, coma, tachycardia, and congestive heart failure. Hypotension, cardiac arrhythmia, and death from cardiovascular collapse may also occur.  

Laboratory findings include overt primary hyperthyroidism: low TSH and high free T4 and/or T3 concentrations. Testing may also reveal mild hyperglycemia, mild hypercalcemia, abnormal liver function tests, leukocytosis, or leukopenia. Treatment includes beta-blockers, antithyroid drugs, iodine solution, and glucocorticoids, as described in the table below.  


Option Analysis

✅ Hydrocortisone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Heparin:
Incorrect: Heparin is an anticoagulant used in conditions such as venous thromboembolism, deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, myocardial infarction, stroke, or transient ischemic attack. Although some of this patient’s symptoms could be explained by myocardial infarction, the presence of very high fever, diarrhea, and a long history of Graves disease favors another diagnosis.
❌ Ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: Ceftriaxone is used to treat bacterial infections caused by gram-negative or gram-positive bacteria. This patient had a viral upper respiratory infection which has since resolved, and her current presentation favors another diagnosis.
❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin should be given to patients with suspected myocardial infarction. However, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with a thyroid storm. Although antipyretic medications can bring down the patient's fever, aspirin can increase serum free T4 and T3 concentrations by interfering with their protein binding, and therefore, acetaminophen should be used instead for fever reduction.
❌ Dantrolene:
Incorrect: Dantrolene is a ryanodine receptor antagonist used in patients with malignant hyperthermia, a life-threatening condition caused after administration of inhaled anesthetics or succinylcholine. The condition causes hyperthermia and severe muscle contractions. This patient did not receive any of the aforementioned medications.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old female presents to an endocrinologist for follow-up testing after having findings concerning for an endocrine disorder at her primary care physician's office. She initially presented with several months of fatigue, weight loss, and abdominal pain. Her laboratory findings from this visit are demonstrated below:



Which of the following tests will help to further define the etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms consistent with adrenal insufficiency and has laboratory findings concerning for secondary or tertiary adrenal insufficiency. The best test to confirm this diagnosis is the ACTH stimulation test, also referred to as the Cortrosyn stimulation test.  

The diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency begins by first measuring a morning or random cortisol level. If low, a diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency is established. If equivocal, a metyrapone stimulation test can be performed to confirm the presence of adrenal insufficiency.  

After a low cortisol level is established, the next step is measurement of basal adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). If ACTH is high, then the patient’s symptoms are due to primary adrenal insufficiency. If ACTH is low, then the adrenal insufficiency is either due to pituitary dysfunction (secondary adrenal insufficiency) or hypothalamic dysfunction (tertiary adrenal insufficiency). The differentiation between primary and secondary/tertiary adrenal insufficiency can be confirmed via the adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) stimulation test, which measures cortisol levels before and after administration of exogenous ACTH. If primary, exogenous ACTH administration will not yield an increase in cortisol, whereas in secondary/tertiary adrenal insufficiency, cortisol levels will rise.  

A corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) stimulation test can then differentiate between secondary and tertiary adrenal insufficiency. In secondary adrenal insufficiency, which arises due to pituitary dysfunction, exogenous CRH will not yield a subsequent increase in ACTH. In contrast, exogenous CRH will yield an increase in ACTH in the setting of tertiary adrenal insufficiency, which arises when the hypothalamus is not producing adequate CRH.  

Option Analysis

✅ ACTH stimulation test:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Metyrapone stimulation test:
Incorrect: The metyrapone stimulation test is utilized in the setting of an indeterminate cortisol study. In contrast, this patient has low morning cortisol levels, which makes the metyrapone stimulation test not useful.
❌ CRH stimulation test  :
Incorrect: The corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) stimulation test involves administering exogenous CRH and monitoring for a change in levels ACTH. It is used to determine whether a patient has secondary or tertiary adrenal insufficiency and gets performed after an ACTH stimulation test, which is also termed the Cortrosyn stimulation test.
❌ Plasma renin activity:
Incorrect: Measurement of plasma renin activity is useful in the confirmation of primary adrenal insufficiency. This patient has low levels of AM cortisol and ACTH, which is reflective of either secondary or tertiary adrenal insufficiency.
❌ Dexamethasone suppression test:
Incorrect: The dexamethasone suppression test is utilized in the evaluation of Cushing disease, not adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of painless vision loss in the right eye. She reports a 2-month history of difficulty dressing due to shoulder stiffness. She has also experienced right-sided headaches and jaw tightness when eating. Past medical history is significant for carotid atherosclerosis, diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation on the right side of the head. Visual acuity in her right eye is 20/200, and a right afferent pupillary defect is noted. Laboratory studies show an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 65 mm/h. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of shoulder stiffness, jaw claudication, and unilateral temporal headaches is now presenting with painless loss of vision, and therefore, she most likely has giant cell (temporal) arteritis (GCA).    

GCA causes inflammation of the body’s large- and medium-sized arteries, including the carotid arteries, its major branches, and the aorta. The condition can present with symptoms including headaches, jaw claudication and visual disturbances—therefore, the diagnosis of GCA should be considered in any elderly patient presenting with a new headache, abrupt visual disturbances, and/or jaw pain. Jaw claudication is a very common symptom and can be seen in over 50% of patients with temporal arteritis.  

Since temporal arteritis affects the internal carotid artery, it can affect its branches as well, including the ophthalmic artery; therefore, the most feared complication of GCA is permanent loss of vision, which commonly is painless and sudden, can be partial or complete, and can be unilateral or bilateral. Transient vision loss (amaurosis fugax) is often an early manifestation of GCA in which patients describe an abrupt partial field defect or curtain effect in the field of vision of one eye. Funduscopic examination may reveal ischemic optic neuropathy, a swollen, pale optic disc, and blurring of the margins.  

If GCA is suspected, treatment with glucocorticoids should be initiated immediately to prevent permanent loss of vision. A patient presenting with a history of suspicious vision changes should be treated with intravenous methylprednisolone. Temporal artery biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosis.




Option Analysis

❌ Ibuprofen:
Incorrect: Ibuprofen can be used to treat acute migraine headaches in adults, which may also present with visual disturbances. However, this patient has no history of migraines, and new-onset migraine headaches are uncommon in elderly patients. Additionally, the elevated ESR and constellation of other symptoms (e.g., jaw claudication, temporal artery tenderness) suggest a different diagnosis and treatment. 
❌ Acetazolamide:
Incorrect: Acetazolamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, can be used to treat idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH), which may also present with headaches and transient vision loss. IIH, however, is more commonly seen in young females with obesity, and it would be unlikely to present in this elderly patient. Additionally, this patient's constellation of symptoms (e.g., jaw claudication, temporal artery tenderness) is consistent with giant cell (temporal) arteritis, which requires a different treatment. 
✅ Methylprednisolone:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Sumatriptan and administration of 100% O2:
Incorrect: Cluster headaches can present with excruciating periorbital pain as well as lacrimation and rhinorrhea. Although cluster headaches may also present with visual disturbances, this patient's constellation of symptoms is more consistent with giant cell (temporal) arteritis, leading to acute vision loss. Immediate treatment with another medication is needed to prevent permanent vision loss. 
❌ High-dose aspirin and clopidogrel:
Incorrect: Amaurosis fugax (transient vision loss), as seen in this patient, can be caused by carotid atherosclerosis, where an embolus becomes dislodged and travels to the ophthalmic artery. Although this patient has a history of carotid atherosclerosis, her constellation of symptoms is more consistent with giant cell (temporal) arteritis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to his family physician for evaluation of excessive daytime sleepiness. The patient states that he sleeps eight hours every night, but he never wakes up feeling rested. His partner endorses that the patient snores every night and occasionally chokes or gasps during sleep. He actively smokes and has a 25-pack-year smoking history. He watches TV in the bedroom prior to going to sleep. Vitals are temperature is 97.0°F, blood pressure is 160/110 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. BMI is 34 kg/m2. Physical examination demonstrates macroglossia and a large neck. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient’s underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of obesity, a large neck circumference, and macroglossia is most likely suffering from obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). His clinical history of frequent snoring, daytime fatigue, and episodes of choking are suggestive of this diagnosis as well.

The underlying pathology of obstructive sleep apnea occurs due to a physical obstruction of the airway resulting in temporary cessation of breathing. Hence, obstructive sleep apnea is associated with structural abnormalities including: obesity, micrognathia, facial elongation, mandibular hypoplasia, adenoid hyperplasia, a large tongue or neck circumference, and inferior displacement of the hyoid. Nonanatomic factors include male sex, alcohol use, smoking, sedative use, and supine sleeping position. Medical disorders associated with OSA include stroke, hypothyroidism, metabolic syndrome, acromegaly and myasthenia gravis.

Treatment of obstructive sleep apnea is accomplished with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP), which is most effective for patients with moderate to mild obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). Patients who have severe OSA requiring pressure settings in excess of 15-20 cmH2O often require bilevel positive airway pressure (BiPAP). Additionally, side sleeping has also shown to be effective in reducing symptoms of sleep apnea. Additional treatment includes weight loss, improved sleep hygiene, and smoking cessation.    

Option Analysis

❌ Tonsillectomy:
Incorrect: Although adenoid and tonsillar hypertrophy contribute obstructive sleep apnea, this patient has no signs or symptoms of tonsillar hypertrophy.
❌ Sleep hygiene measures:
Incorrect: Sleep hygiene measures include routine bed times, avoidance of screen-time or caffeine late at night, as well as using the bedroom only for sleep and sex. This patient’s history is suspicious for obstructive sleep apnea, which will not be controlled with these measures.
❌ Smoking cessation:
Incorrect: Although smoking has been linked to central sleep apnea, it is not a direct cause of obstructive sleep apnea.
✅ Continuous positive airway pressure:
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Maxillomandibular advancement :
Incorrect: This procedure is a type of surgery where the upper and lower jaws are detached and surgically advanced to create additional space in the posterior oropharynx. It is not an appropriate treatment modality for patients with obesity as the principal cause of sleep apnea.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency room for evaluation of chest pain and shortness of breath. He endorses using intranasal cocaine daily, and his last use was three hours prior to arrival. Temperature is 100 °F (37.7°C), pulse is 100 bpm, blood pressure is 200/120 mmHg, and SpO2 is 99%. The patient appears agitated and irritable. On physical examination, the pupils are mydriatic, and the patient is sweating profusely. Oral mucosa appears moist, and the nasal mucosa is atrophic. Cardiopulmonary exam is unremarkable. The patient moves all four extremities to command with normal deep tendon reflexes. ECG shows sinus tachycardia with ST depression and T wave inversions in I, avL, V5 and V6. He is treated with IV benzodiazepines and undergoes percutaneous intervention. His blood pressure two hours later is 190/100 mmHg. He complains of blurry vision and an occipital headache. Administration of which of the following medications is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with coronary ischemia in the setting of recent cocaine use. Following the procedure, he suffers from features consistent with a hypertensive emergency requiring rapid titration of blood pressure. The most appropriate medication to use in this setting is a vasodilator--such as nitroprusside.

Cocaine is a potent psychostimulant that acts by blocking the reuptake of biogenic amines like norepinephrine, serotonin and dopamine. Cocaine can precipitate coronary ischemia via vasospasm of coronary arteries and subsequent thrombus formation. The treatment of acute cocaine intoxication involves management of severe or symptomatic hypertension and psychomotor agitation, in addition to treatment of cocaine-associated myocardial infarction. Hypertensive emergencies can occur following cocaine use and is characterised by elevated blood pressure with evidence of end organ damage (acute kidney injury, myocardial ischemia, stroke-like symptoms, encephalopathy). In this setting, administration of venodilators such as nitroprusside, nitroglycerin, or phentolamine is appropriate.

Notably, beta blockers are contraindicated in the treatment of cocaine-induced hypertension, as administration can result in uninhibited alpha adrenergic stimulation (which can worsen the vasospastic event).  

Option Analysis

✅ Nitroprusside:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: Beta blockers are contraindicated in the treatment of cocaine intoxication, as administration may result in unopposed alpha adrenergic stimulation--worsening coronary ischemia.
❌ Amlodipine:
Incorrect: Calcium channel blockers are used in the treatment of primary hypertension, as they can cause vasodilation. These drugs typically have a longer onset of action and hence are not first line agents in the treatment of hypertensive emergencies.
❌ Hydrochlorothiazide:
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics are used in the treatment of essential hypertension in patients with normal kidney function. It is not the agent of choice for hypertensive emergencies.
❌ Alteplase:
Incorrect: Alteplase is a thrombolytic medication. This patient presents with features concerning for hypertensive emergency--requiring administration of antihypertensive agents.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man presents to the emergency department to evaluate anaphylaxis following a bee sting. The patient received intramuscular epinephrine in the field without resolution of symptoms. Upon initial evaluation, the patient is in respiratory distress using accessory muscles. The patient's temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 128/min, respirations are 41/min, blood pressure is 82/50 mmHg, and O2. is 82% on room air. Additional intramuscular epinephrine is administered without resolution of symptoms. The decision is made to intubate for airway protection; however, the emergency physician cannot visualize the vocal cords with video laryngoscopy or direct laryngoscopy due to airway edema. Repeat vital signs are as follows: temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 41/min, respirations are 10/min, blood pressure is 60/32 mmHg, and O2. is 60%. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents in respiratory distress due to treatment-resistant anaphylactic shock. The emergency physician cannot establish a definitive airway due to airway edema. Given this patient's impending respiratory arrest, the most appropriate next step in management is performing a cricothyrotomy for definitive airway management.  

Cricothyrotomy and tracheostomy are two surgical procedures to establish an opening for ventilation and respiratory support in the trachea. Cricothyrotomy is the emergent airway procedure in the “can’t intubate, can’t ventilate” scenario. The procedure is performed by making a vertical incision over the cricothyroid membrane into the trachea, followed by the insertion of an endotracheal tube. It is preferred to tracheostomy because it is easier to perform, is associated with less bleeding, and can be performed more quickly.  

In contrast, a tracheostomy is a planned procedure performed for patients with a prolonged course of mechanical ventilation to decrease work of breathing and improve patient comfort when compared to endotracheal intubation. Additional indications include vocal cord paralysis, previous neck surgery or throat trauma, and chronic upper airway obstruction. This procedure is performed by making a horizontal incision midway between the cricoid cartilage and the sternal notch, with subsequent placement of a tracheostomy tube.  

Option Analysis

✅ Cricothyrotomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Tracheostomy :
Incorrect: A tracheostomy refers to a surgical opening in the trachea. Tracheostomy is not the preferred approach in most patients who require the establishment of an emergency airway. 
❌ Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation:
Incorrect: Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) is a salvage therapy that circulates the patient’s blood through an artificial oxygenating device in the setting of respiratory failure. This patient is critically ill and will decompensate further unless an immediate airway is established.   
❌ Fiberoptic intubation:
Incorrect: Fiberoptic intubation is often performed in patients with significant airway edema; however, this patient is critically ill and will decompensate further unless an immediate airway is established.   
❌ Needle cricothyrotomy:
Incorrect: Needle cricothyrotomy is an option to establish an emergency surgical airway, but it is not the procedure of choice in most adult patients. It is used more commonly in pediatric patients. However, even in the pediatric setting, it is still not the first-line choice as ventilation is difficult through a small caliber cannula, and it requires an unobstructed airway for passive expiration. As such, this patient is not a candidate.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is being treated in the cardiac intensive care unit after he developed an acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction 4 days ago. The patient presented a few hours after symptom onset and was treated with medical therapy and reperfusion using percutaneous intervention to remove a clot in the left anterior descending artery. This morning, the patient developed sudden onset, severe chest pain. Evaluation at the bedside reveals a blood pressure of 60/40 mmHg. Physical examination is significant for distant heart sounds. Which of the following complications is this patient experiencing?
questions.solution:
This patient experienced an acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) involving the left anterior descending artery. Four day later, he is experiencing sudden, severe chest pain, hypotension, and distant heart sounds, which are characteristic of cardiac tamponade secondary to left ventricular free wall rupture.    

Left ventricular free wall rupture is a severe and lethal mechanical complication of STEMI involving the left anterior descending artery. It is most likely to occur within the first 5 days post-MI but can occur up to 2 weeks later. The patient initially develops severe chest pain due to the tearing of the left ventricular wall, followed by very rapid accumulation of blood in the pericardium, resulting in acute cardiac tamponade characterized by hypotension and distant heart sounds. Most patients enter into cardiac arrest, and thus the mortality rate for left ventricular free wall rupture is very high.    

Mechanical complications of myocardial infarction are summarized in the table below.  Other complications that occur after myocardial infarction (MI) include ventricular arrhythmias (the most common cause of the death 24 hours post-MI), postinfarction acute pericarditis (occurs within 1-3 days), Dressler syndrome (weeks to months after MI), and left ventricular aneurysm (occurs several months after MI).  


Option Analysis

✅ Left ventricular free wall rupture :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Interventricular septum rupture :
Incorrect: Interventricular septum rupture is another possible complication of STEMI involving the left anterior descending artery; however, a holosystolic murmur is heard on exam in these patients. Distant heart sounds instead indicate cardiac tamponade, which is seen in free wall rupture.  
❌ Papillary muscle rupture :
Incorrect: Papillary muscle rupture is a possible complication of STEMI involving the right coronary artery or the posterior descending artery, not the left anterior descending artery. In addition, examination shows a holosystolic murmur indicative of aortic regurgitation, not distant heart sounds.  
❌ Dressler syndrome :
Incorrect: Dressler syndrome is an autoimmune complication of STEMI and involves autoimmune attack on the pericardium leading to fibrinous pericarditis. It occurs weeks to months after the episode of STEMI, not within 4 days.  
❌ Acute postinfarction fibrinous pericarditis:
Incorrect: Acute postinfarction fibrinous pericarditis occurs 1-3 days after STEMI and is characterized by chest pain and pericardial friction rub. Hypotension and distant heart sounds are not seen.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician due to dyspnea and a productive cough for the past several months. Past medical history is significant for hypertension. The patient has a 42-pack-year smoking history. She has tried multiple times to quit smoking by herself, but these attempts have been unsuccessful.Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Physical examination reveals diffuse bilateral wheezes and rales. Pulmonary function testing (PFT) is performed, and the diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is confirmed. Which of the following medications would be most effective in stopping the progression of this patient’s disease?
questions.solution:
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a common, preventable, and treatable disease that is characterized by obstruction of airflow due to either chronic bronchitis or emphysema. The main risk factor for COPD is tobacco smoking, but other occupational pollutants like dust and silica can also contribute to disease initiation and progression. Smoking cessation has the greatest capacity to influence the progression of COPD, and patients should be counseled on quitting at all visits. Therefore, encouraging smoking cessation is an essential step in COPD management for all individuals who smoke. Smoking cessation can substantially reduce the rate of decline in lung function (forced expiratory volume in one second [FEV1]) that occurs in patients with COPD.  

Interventions that assist smoking cessation include non-pharmacological methods, such as physician encouragement and behavioral counseling, as well as pharmacological methods, such as nicotine replacement therapy, bupropion, and varenicline (which acts on central nicotine receptors in the brain). The best cessation rates are achieved when counseling is combined with medication therapy.  



Option Analysis

✅ Varenicline :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Albuterol:
Incorrect: Short-acting beta agonists, such as albuterol, have been shown to improve symptoms and lung function in patients with COPD. However, they are not the most effective treatment option in this patient who is currently still smoking.
❌ Ipratropium :
Incorrect: Short-acting muscarinic antagonists (SAMAs), such as ipratropium, have been shown to improve symptoms and lung function in patients with COPD. However, they are not the most effective treatment option in this patient who is currently still smoking. 
❌ Formoterol  :
Incorrect: Long-acting beta agonists (LABAs), such as formoterol and salmeterol, have been shown to improve symptoms and lung function in patients with COPD. However, they are not the most effective treatment option in this patient who is currently still smoking.
❌ Tiotropium:
Incorrect: Long-acting muscarinic antagonists (LAMAs), such as tiotropium and umeclidinium, have been shown to improve symptoms and lung function in patients with COPD. However, they are not the most effective treatment option in this patient who is currently still smoking.

questions.text: 68-year-old man is brought to the physician by his partner because of increasing forgetfulness over the last 5 weeks. The patient is unable to finish his daily crossword puzzles and often has to call his partner when he is at the grocery store to help remember the list. He has had an 8-lb weight gain over this same time period. The patient has chronic hypertension, which is well-controlled with lisinopril, and he has also recently started taking laxatives several times a week to relieve constipation. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 57/min, blood pressure is 128/86 mm Hg, and BMI is 27 kg/m2. The patient is alert and oriented to time, place, and person. Physical examination shows dry skin and a slightly distended abdomen. There is no mucosal pallor and capillary refill is less than 2 seconds. Deep tendon reflexes are delayed in the upper and lower extremities. Further testing confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with classic signs of hypothyroidism, such as fatigue, cognitive decline, constipation, and delayed deep tendon reflexes. Cognitive decline in an elderly patient is oftentimes worrisome for a more serious underlying condition, such as dementia and Alzheimer disease; therefore, it is important to first rule out reversible causes of cognitive decline.  

To screen for hypothyroidism, a thyroid function test should be performed. Laboratory testing would show decreased thyroxine (T4) levels and elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels. Treatment consists of replacing low T4 levels by administering levothyroxine (synthetic T4), which is then peripherally converted to T3. Although T3 (liothyronine) is the metabolically active form of thyroid hormone, it has a much shorter half-life; this instability makes direct T3 thyroid hormone replacement therapy undesirable.    

 

Option Analysis

✅ Levothyroxine :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Vitamin B12 supplementation:
Incorrect: When considering the diagnosis of dementia in an elderly patient, screening for vitamin B12 levels is a crucial part of initial investigations. Patients with vitamin B12 deficiency would present with signs of anemia; this patient has no mucosal pallor and normal capillary refill, making this diagnosis unlikely. Moreover, vitamin B12 deficiency would not account for the patient’s weight gain, abdominal distention, or delayed deep tendon reflexes.
❌ Paroxetine:
Incorrect: Paroxetine is used in the treatment of depression, which can cause pseudodementia in the geriatric population. Pseudodementia is an important cause of declining cognition in the elderly. It is extremely important to rule this out, as it is a reversible cause of cognitive decline. However, this patient has no other symptoms of depression (e.g., anhedonia, sleep disturbances, sense of guilt).
❌ Donepezil :
Incorrect: Donepezil is an cholinesterase inhibitor that is used in treating Alzheimer disease. Alzheimer disease normally begins insidiously over a timeframe of several years. In contrast, this patient’s current symptoms have been present for only several weeks, making the diagnosis of Alzheimer disease unlikely. 
❌ Penicillin:
Incorrect: When considering the diagnosis of dementia in an elderly patient, screening for syphilis is important, as neurosyphilis can also present with signs of dementia and personality changes. Neurosyphilis can be treated with penicillin. This patient’s other signs and symptoms (e.g., weight gain, delayed deep tendon reflexes), however, make this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a hypertension follow up. She was diagnosed with hypertension 6 months ago and was prescribed a low-sodium diet and exercise. Medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type 2 that is currently managed with metformin. She has been smoking 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. Family history is significant for osteoporosis in her mother and diabetes mellitus in her father. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 152/95 mmHg. Urinalysis reveals microalbuminuria. DXA scan shows normal bone mineral density. A decision is made to add a pharmacological treatment to manage the hypertension. The first-line treatment for this patient’s condition works by which of the following mechanisms of action?

choices.text: Block calcium influx in vascular smooth muscle cells
Inhibit NaCl reabsorption in early distal collecting duct
Inhibit cotransport of Na+/K+/2Cl−  channels at thick ascending limb
Inhibit the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II
Increase cGMP level in vascular smooth muscle cells

questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with hypertension and failed to respond to lifestyle modification (i.e. diet and exercise). A decision is made to add pharmacological intervention to control the blood pressure.  

In the absence of a specific clinical indication, there are three main drug classes that can be used for initial monotherapy: thiazide diuretics, long-acting calcium channel blockers (most often a dihydropyridine), and angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor (ACEI) inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB). However, this patient has diabetes mellitus in addition to high blood pressure, which is an indication for the addition of an ACEI or an ARB due to their protective effect against diabetic nephropathy. ACE inhibitors and ARBs lower intraglomerular pressure by decreasing efferent arteriolar pressure. Other indications for specific therapy are described in the table below.    

One important mechanism that regulates blood pressure is the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone (RAAS) system, which is a cascade of events that leads to an increase in blood pressure. When blood pressure is low, blood flow to the kidneys decreases. The kidneys respond by secreting renin into the bloodstream. Renin is a proteolytic enzyme that breaks down a protein made in the liver called angiotensinogen, which gives rise to angiotensin I. When it reaches the lungs, angiotensin I is converted into angiotensin II by an enzyme called angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE). Angiotensin II binds to receptors in vascular smooth muscle and causes them to constrict, which increases the blood pressure. Finally, angiotensin II also stimulates the release of aldosterone by the adrenal glands. Aldosterone increases reabsorption of sodium in the kidneys, which also increases water reabsorption, resulting in increased blood volume, which increases blood pressure. ACE inhibitors main effect is attributed to lowering the levels of angiotensin II, a potent vasoconstrictor.  



Option Analysis

❌ Block calcium influx in vascular smooth muscle cells :
Incorrect: This answer is the mechanism of action of calcium channel blockers (CCB), which can be used as monotherapy for initial management of hypertension, but there are no absolute indications for CCBs in patients with hypertension. This patient has diabetes in addition to high blood pressure, which favors the use of an angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor or an angiotensin receptor blocker. CCBs can be used as the first-line in patients with atrial fibrillation/flutter (nondihydropyridine) or Raynaud phenomenon (dihydropyridine). 
❌ Inhibit NaCl reabsorption in early distal collecting duct:
Incorrect: This answer is the mechanism of action of thiazide diuretics (HCTZ) which can be used as monotherapy for initial management of hypertension when no other comorbidities exist (e.g. diabetes mellitus). The preferred thiazide diuretic in patients with primary hypertension is chlorthalidone, since major trials such as ALLHAT have shown improved cardiovascular outcomes with this regimen. Thiazides can be used as the first line in patients with osteoporosis as it reduces calcium excretion; however, this patient’s normal DXA scan suggests no osteopenia/osteoporosis. Furthermore, this patient has diabetes in addition to high blood pressure, which favors the use of an angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor or an angiotensin receptor blocker. 
❌ Inhibit cotransport of Na+/K+/2Cl−  channels at thick ascending limb :
Incorrect: This answer is the mechanism of action of loop diuretics, which are occasionally added to hypertension treatment for volume control in patients with heart failure or chronic kidney disease. However, loop diuretics are not used as first line or monotherapy. 
✅ Inhibit the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increase cGMP level in vascular smooth muscle cells:
Incorrect: This answer is the mechanism of action of hydralazine and nitroprusside, which are often used in severe hypertension/hypertensive emergency but not for chronic hypertension maintenance.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old woman comes to the emergency department complaining of shortness of breath and oral mucosal bleeding for the last 3 days. Past medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease. The patient often forgets to take her diabetes medications and missed her last two dialysis appointments. The patient’s temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 114/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 144/78 mmHg. Diffuse crackles are heard in the bilateral lungs. Petechiae are observed on the oral mucosa. 3+ pitting edema is present in the bilateral lower extremities. Laboratory testing is obtained, and results are shown below.  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Hematologic  
 Platelet count  190,000/mm3  
 Hemoglobin  14.3 g/dL 
 Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)  84 fL 
Blood, plasma, serum  
 Creatinine  6.2 mg/dL 
 Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN)  76 mg/dL 
Coagulation studies  
 Prothrombin time (PT)  10 seconds 
 Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)  32 seconds 
 Bleeding time*  15 minutes 
*Reference Range: 2-7 minutes  
Which of the following interventions is most likely to resolve this patient’s platelet dysfunction?
questions.solution:
This patient has oral mucosal petechiae in the setting of chronic kidney disease and elevated blood urea levels. She most likely has uremic platelet dysfunction.    

The pathophysiology of uremic platelet dysfunction is not fully understood, but it is thought to be due to an accumulation of toxins that interferes with the normal platelet-endothelium interaction.  

Treatment for uremic platelet dysfunction includes dialysis, desmopressin (DDAVP), and correction of the anemia. Dialysis helps reduce blood urea nitrogen levels. Desmopressin promotes the release of factor VIII and von Willebrand factor from endothelial cells. Anemia can be corrected using red blood cell transfusions or administration of erythropoietin.   

Option Analysis

❌ Plasmapheresis:
Incorrect: Plasmapheresis can be used to treat conditions such as hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS) and thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). However, plasmapheresis would not be useful in treating uremic platelet dysfunction.  
❌ Steroids and intravenous immunoglobulins (IVIG):
Incorrect: Steroids and intravenous immunoglobulins (IVIG) are used to treat immune thrombocytopenia (ITP). Patients with ITP would have isolated thrombocytopenia. In contrast, this patient has a normal platelet count. Moreover, the condition would not account for the patient’s elevated blood urea nitrogen levels.
❌ Fresh frozen plasma:
Incorrect: Fresh frozen plasma is used to treat disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) and to immediately reverse anticoagulants. Patients with DIC would have thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, as well as an elevated prothrombin time and activated partial thromboplastin time.   
✅ Dialysis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cryoprecipitate:
Incorrect: Cryoprecipitate is used to treat coagulation factor deficiencies that involve fibrinogen and factor VIII. However, its indications are very limited, and it is not commonly used.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man comes to the physician for follow-up after elevated liver enzyme levels were found on routine blood work. The patient has type II diabetes mellitus that was diagnosed 3 years ago and is currently taking metformin. He drinks 2 beers every weekend and does not consume illicit substances. He has never traveled outside of the country. He has no family history of liver disease. Vital signs are within normal limits. His BMI is 31 kg/m2. Physical examination reveals an obese abdomen with no tenderness to palpation in any of the abdominal quadrants. Laboratory testing for viral hepatitis yields the following results:



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step for the management of this patient’s elevated liver enzyme levels?

choices.text: Initiation of ledipasvir and sofosbuvir therapy

questions.solution:
Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is a condition wherein hepatic steatosis develops in individuals who drink little or no alcohol. It is the most common cause of incidental elevations in serum transaminases, and most individuals with steatosis are asymptomatic. NAFLD most commonly occurs in patients with metabolic syndrome, which consists of hypertension, hyperglycemia, insulin resistance, and dyslipidemia. NAFLD initially begins as steatosis (fatty infiltration), and it can progress to active steatohepatitis (fatty infiltration and inflammation) and then cirrhosis; however, the incidence of progression is low.  

Risk factors for NAFLD include obesity and insulin resistance; both of these factors increase the mobilization of free fatty acids from adipose tissue, which are eventually taken up by hepatocytes. As intrahepatic lipids and their metabolic intermediates accumulate, hepatocytes become sensitized to the toxic effects of inflammatory cytokines. Additionally, the accumulation of lipid metabolism byproducts increases the production of reactive oxygen species, which disrupt mitochondrial function, cause liver injury, and trigger stellate cell activation.  

A liver biopsy would show hepatocellular lipid accumulation, with various degrees of inflammatory infiltrates, depending on the stage of the disease. Treatment is directed towards weight reduction and reversal of insulin resistance, as these are the primary drivers of NAFLD.  


Image reproduced from



Option Analysis

✅ Education on weight loss strategies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Initiation of ledipasvir and sofosbuvir therapy:
Incorrect: Ledipasvir and sofosbuvir are medications commonly used to treat chronic hepatitis C (HCV) infection. This patient is negative for anti-HCV antibodies and has no history of HCV risk factors (e.g. IV drug use). Hence, it is unlikely this patient has an underlying HCV infection.
❌ No intervention:
Incorrect: While this patient’s hepatitis viral testing indicates that he does not have active viral hepatitis, his weight and diabetes mellitus suggest that his elevated liver enzymes could be due to nonalcoholic fatty liver disease. Counseling that could lead to weight reduction could prevent progression and even reverse his NAFLD.
❌ Initiation of tenofovir:
Incorrect: Tenofovir can be used to treat patients with chronic hepatitis B infection. This patient tested negative for the hepatitis B surface antigen and positive for the surface antibody, indicating that this patient has either recovered from a past infection or has been vaccinated.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man is evaluated for muscle weakness and a 5-kg (11-lb) unintentional weight loss over the past 4 months. In addition, the patient frequently wakes up at night due to coughing and finds himself covered in sweat. Past medical history is notable for hyperlipidemia, for which he currently takes atorvastatin. Social history is notable for a 40-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), blood pressure is 122/73 mmHg, pulse is 65/min, and respiratory rate is 15/min. Physical examination is notable for 4/5 strength in the proximal arms and legs. Swelling and a purplish-red discoloration is observed on the bilateral eyelids. During the visit, the patient frequently coughs. Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention?

choices.text: Obtain serum TSH and T3/T4 levels
Perform muscle biopsy of the quadriceps

questions.solution:
This patient has dermatomyositis, likely secondary to an underlying lung malignancy. Dermatomyositis is an autoimmune antibody-mediated condition that presents with proximal muscle weakness and cutaneous findings. These include Gottron papules, heliotrope rash (which was observed on this patient’s examination), shawl and face rash, and mechanic hands (hyperkeratotic, scaling, and fissuring of the patient’s hands).  

Dermatomyositis is associated with malignancies such as Hodgkin lymphoma as well as lung, stomach, colorectal, and ovarian cancer. In this vignette, the patient’s symptoms of cough, night sweats, and unintentional weight loss in combination with his smoking history raise concerns for a lung malignancy. If an underlying malignancy is suspected, additional testing such as x-ray or CT should be ordered.  

Option Analysis

❌ Obtain serum TSH and T3/T4 levels:
Incorrect: Measurements of serum TSH and T3/T4 levels are necessary in the work-up hypothyroidism. This condition can cause myopathy and muscle weakness. However, hypothyroidism typically causes an increase in body weight. Moreover, it would be atypical for hypothyroidism to cause the cough and night sweats experienced by this patient.
❌ Obtain peripheral blood eosinophil count:
Incorrect: A peripheral blood eosinophil count can be ordered as part of the work-up for eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss syndrome). The condition can present with pulmonary syndromes (e.g., sinusitis, asthma) and cutaneous findings (e.g., nodules, purpura). However, it would be atypical for the condition to present with proximal muscle weakness or night sweats.
❌ Perform muscle biopsy of the quadriceps:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is highly characteristic of dermatomyositis. He has symmetrical proximal muscle weakness and skin findings consistent with a heliotrope rash. As a result, a muscle biopsy is unnecessary to confirm the diagnosis. Instead, additional testing should be performed to evaluate for an underlying malignancy, especially given the patient’s night sweats and unintentional weight loss, since dermatomyositis is associated with malignancy. 
❌ Discontinue atorvastatin:
Incorrect: Statin-associated myopathy can present with muscle pain and weakness. Discontinuation of the medication can prevent side-effect exacerbation and progression to rhabdomyolysis. However, statin-associated myopathy would not account for the patient’s heliotrope rash, chronic cough, or unintentional weight loss.
✅ Order a chest radiograph:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old man comes to his physician for evaluation of excessive fatigue and shortness of breath. He has also unintentionally lost 12-lb (5.4 kg) in the past 2 months. He has not had abdominal pain, melena, or changes in bowel habits. He has not visited a physician in many years, but he was urged by his partner to make an appointment. The patient recently retired from a battery-manufacturing factory, which he worked at for 35 years. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for skin and conjunctival pallor. Laboratory results are as follows:

 Laboratory Value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  9.8 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  40% 
 Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)  74 μm3 

Which of the following diagnostic studies would be most helpful in confirming this patient’s underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This elderly male is presenting with fatigue, dyspnea, and conjunctival pallor. Laboratory testing is notable for microcytic anemia (decreased hemoglobin and mean corpuscular volume). These findings are likely due to iron-deficiency anemia secondary to a gastrointestinal malignancy. A colonoscopy should be performed to evaluate for underlying colorectal cancer.  

The symptoms of colon cancer vary depending on its location. Right-sided colon cancers often cause chronic occult bleeding, resulting in iron-deficiency anemia. In contrast to left-sided colon cancers, right-sided tumors do not typically cause obstruction, since the right-sided colon has a larger diameter than the left.  

Left-sided colon cancers, in contrast, tend to have a different presentation. They are usually smaller, but as they infiltrate the wall of the colon, the cancer can encircle the lumen and cause significant narrowing. As a result, patients with left-sided colon cancers typically present with signs of obstruction, such as narrowing of stool (“pencil-thin stools”), colicky pains, constipation, and abdominal distension. In some cases, left-sided colon cancer can cause hematochezia, which is the passage of fresh, bright red blood through the anus.


Option Analysis

✅ Colonoscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thyroid function studies:
Incorrect: Although this patient is presenting with excessive fatigue, which can also be seen in patients with hypothyroidism, the other presenting symptoms and laboratory findings (e.g., pallor, anemia) cannot be fully explained by hypothyroidism alone. 
❌ Chest x-ray:
Incorrect: Although this patient has a significant smoking history and recent weight loss, he does not have the chronic cough or hemoptysis typically seen in lung cancer.
❌ Serum lead levels:
Incorrect: Lead poisoning can be seen in patients who have had chronic exposure to the substance, such as those working in battery manufacturing plants. Lead poisoning typically manifests with abdominal pain, constipation, and cognitive impairments. However, none of these symptoms are present in this patient. 
❌ Hemoglobin electrophoresis:
Incorrect: Hemoglobin electrophoresis can be used for further evaluation in patients suspected of having thalassemia or sickle cell trait/disease. However, these conditions would typically manifest with symptoms in childhood. It would be unusual for any of these conditions to first present with symptoms in a 61-year-old.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his partner for evaluation of altered mental status. His partner states the patient woke up today with knee pain, for which he took an “over-the-counter pain reliever” and his prescription hydrocodone-acetaminophen. Several hours later, the partner noticed he was less responsive and unaware of where he was. The patient has a history of chronic lower back pain and chronic alcohol use. On physical examination, the patient is not oriented and responds only to pain. The patient grimaces with palpation of the right upper quadrant. AST and ALT are 2136 and 2467 IU/L, respectively. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapeutic treatment for this patient's clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with altered mental status, right upper quadrant tenderness, and elevated liver enzymes consistent with acute hepatic injury and encephalopathy secondary to acetaminophen overdose. Most cases of acetaminophen toxicity are due to intentional ingestion of large amounts of acetaminophen; however, some patients develop toxicity unintentionally via ingestion of acetaminophen from multiple sources or via underlying hepatic dysfunction (e.g. chronic alcohol use).

Acetaminophen metabolism at therapeutic doses occurs through glucuronidation and sulfation in the liver, which yields non-toxic products that are eliminated through urine. A minimal amount of acetaminophen is converted by CYP450 to the toxic N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine (NAPQI); however, this compound is quickly eliminated by combining with the substrate glutathione.

In case of overdose, glucuronidation and sulfation pathways become saturated, leading to increased metabolism by CYP450 and production of NAPQI. The high amount of NAPQI depletes glutathione, with subsequent NAPQI accumulation, resulting in hepatic necrosis and acute liver failure.

First-line treatment for acetaminophen toxicity is N-acetylcysteine (NAC). NAC is fully protective to the liver; it exerts its protective effects by replenishing glutathione, increasing detoxification of NAPQI, and thus preventing further hepatocyte injury and necrosis.



Option Analysis

✅ N-Acetylcysteine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Activated charcoal:
Incorrect: Activated charcoal may be used to treat acetaminophen overdose when the patient is alert and protecting their airway and ingestion was within one hour of presentation. Activated charcoal should be avoided in this patient due to the risk of aspiration injury.
❌ Sodium bicarbonate:
Incorrect: Sodium bicarbonate is an alkaline solution that is used in the treatment of salicylates and tricyclic antidepressants toxicity. It has no role in the management of acetaminophen toxicity.
❌ Orogastric lavage :
Incorrect: Orogastric lavage is not effective for the treatment of acetaminophen toxicity.
❌ Whole bowel irrigation.:
Incorrect: Whole bowel irrigation, like orogastric lavage, is not effective for the treatment of acetaminophen toxicity.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of pain in the right lower extremity. The patient was running on the beach without shoes over the past weekend and sustained a small laceration to the bottom of the foot. Over the past 24 hours, he has been experiencing severe pain and swelling of the foot to the point that he is unable to bear weight. He is otherwise healthy and does not smoke, consume alcohol, or use illicit substances. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 109/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 131/72 mmHg. On physical examination, a 3 cm x 3 cm area of erythema is noted on the underside of the right foot. The patient is exquisitely tender to palpation over the entire aspect of the right foot extending to the mid tibia. A radiograph of the right foot is obtained and demonstrates the following finding:



Reproduced from: Radiopaedia

Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: Intravenous vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam dual therapy

questions.solution:
This patient has right foot cellulitis, pain out of proportion to physical exam findings, and radiograph demonstrating air in the soft tissue. Together, these findings are consistent with necrotizing fasciitis, which must be treated emergently with surgical debridement of devitalized tissue.

Necrotizing fasciitis is a rare but serious infection of deep soft tissues that results in rapid, progressive destruction of muscle fascia and overlying subcutaneous fat. Typically, bacteria (usually anaerobes or Streptococcus pyogenes) with appropriate toxin-carrying capabilities enter through broken skin and spread along the myofascial plane. Pyrogenic exotoxins induce cytokine production, contributing to tissue destruction and subsequent production of methane and CO2. Ultimately, this process causes bullae formation, crepitus, and gas within soft tissue.

Necrotizing fasciitis carries a high rate of morbidity and mortality. Therefore, prompt recognition and treatment are paramount. Clues to the diagnosis include pain out of proportion to physical exam findings, erythema without sharp margins, as well as skin bullae and necrosis. Definitive treatment includes debridement of devitalized tissue for source control, as well as empiric antibiotics that include either carbapenem or piperacillin-tazobactam plus vancomycin and clindamycin. This combination is effective against both Gram positive and anaerobic pathogens. Furthermore, clindamycin helps inhibit bacterial toxin production.



Option Analysis

✅ Surgical debridement:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Intravenous ceftriaxone monotherapy:
Incorrect: This patient has pain out of proportion to physical exam findings. Furthermore, the radiograph demonstrates accumulation of air within the subcutaneous tissue. These findings are suggestive of necrotising fasciitis, which is often caused by Gram positive and anaerobic bacteria. Ceftriaxone lacks adequate coverage to treat this type of infection.
❌ Below the knee amputation:
Incorrect: This patient should be taken to the operating room for surgical exploration. Attempts to debride the infected tissue and save the limb should be attempted before proceeding to amputation.
❌ Intravenous vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam dual therapy:
Incorrect: Intravenous vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam reflects incomplete antibiotic therapy for necrotizing soft tissue infections. Clindamycin should also be added, since the antibiotic decreases toxin production by bacteria.
❌ Incision and drainage:
Incorrect: Simple incision and drainage is performed for skin abscesses. In contrast, necrotizing soft tissue infections would need to undergo surgical debridement.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for a routine evaluation. The patient has noticed some difficulty seeing presentation slides during his college lectures. He has not experienced difficulty reading textbooks or viewing text on his laptop screen. He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Vital signs are within normal limits, and visual acuity is noted to be 20/30 bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This young-adult presents with difficulty seeing distant objects but not near objects. He likely has myopia, which can be treated with the application of concave lenses.

Normally, as light enters the eye, the lens bends the light such that the optical image is clearly focused on the retina. When the cornea and lens fail to optimize this focus, a distortion, or blurring of the image, can occur. With hyperopia (far-sightedeness), the axial length of the eye is too short for the refractive power of the cornea and lens. Thus, the image is focused behind the retina. This refractive error can be corrected with a convex (converging) lens. In contrast, myopia (near-sightedeness) occurs when the axial length of the eye is too long for the refractive power of the cornea and lens. These abnormalities cause the image to be focused in front of the retina. Treatment for myopia involves application of a concave (diverging) lens.

Lastly, astigmatism refers to an abnormal curvature of the cornea, which causes light rays entering the eye along different planes to be focused unevenly, resulting in distortion of vision at all distances. Treatment involves application of a cylindrical lens.



Option Analysis

✅ Concave lens:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Convex lens:
Incorrect: Convex lenses are used to correct for hyperopia (farsightedness). This patient, on the other hand, has difficulty seeing distant objects and likely has myopia (nearsightedness).
❌ Cylindrical lens :
Incorrect: Cylindrical lenses are used to correct for astigmatism, which is an abnormal curvature of the cornea. The condition manifests with difficulty seeing both near and far objects.
❌ Magnifying reading lenses:
