Incorrect: Presbyopia, also termed age-related nearsightedness, occurs due to changes in the lens’s curvature, a decline in lens elasticity, and a decrease in ciliary muscle strength. Symptoms of presbyopia generally manifest around the age of 40 and can be treated with magnifying reading glasses. In contrast, this patient is in his 20s and is unlikely to have presbyopia.
❌ Laser iridotomy:
Incorrect: Laser iridotomy can be used to treat acute closed-angle glaucoma, which often presents with severe eye pain, eye redness, and a dilated pupil. In contrast, laser iridotomy is not used to treat nearsightedness.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of chronic tinnitus of her right ear. The patient reports insidious onset of symptoms over the past three to four months with associated “balance issues.” The patient has not had other significant medical history. This patient’s Weber test demonstrates lateralization of sound to the left ear, while Rinne testing demonstrates air conduction greater than bone conduction in the right ear. Which of the following is the most likely anatomic site of this patient’s primary pathology?
questions.solution:
Two tests, the Weber test and the Rinne test, can help determine if a patient has conductive or sensorineural hearing loss. The Weber test is performed by placing a struck tuning fork on the bridge of the forehead. In an individual with normal hearing, there is no lateralization of sound. With unilateral conductive hearing loss, sound lateralizes to the affected ear. Whereas, with unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, sound lateralizes to the normal ear.

The Rinne test is performed by placing the base of a struck tuning fork on the mastoid bone until the patient no longer hears sound. Next, the fork is moved beside the ear and the patient is asked if they can still hear sound. In a normal test, air conduction is greater than bone conduction. However, in patients with conductive hearing loss, bone conduction is greater than air conduction. Unfortunately, the Rinne test cannot differentiate between normal hearing individuals and those with sensorineural hearing loss, as both present with air conduction greater than bone conduction.

Hearing loss is broadly categorized into conductive, sensorineural, and mixed hearing loss. Conductive hearing loss reflects any disease process that affects the transmission of sound from the outside world to the inner ear. Anatomic structures affected in conductive hearing loss include the auricle, external auditory canal, tympanic membrane, and ossicles. Common etiologies include cerumen impaction, tympanic membrane perforation, otosclerosis, otitis media/externa, and cholesteatomas.

In contrast, sensorineural hearing loss reflects any disease process that affects the transmission of neuronal input to the central nervous system via damage to the cochlea or auditory nerve. Common etiologies include presbycusis, noise-induced hearing loss, schwannomas, and Meniere disease. Other etiologies include ototoxic medications (e.g. aminoglycosides), congenital viral infections, congenital long QT syndrome, and Alport syndrome. The patient in question has a right sided sensorineural hearing loss.  

Option Analysis

✅ Cranial nerve VIII  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Auricle  :
Incorrect: The auricle composes the external ear and is involved in conductive hearing loss, not sensorineural hearing loss.  
❌ Ossicles  :
Incorrect: The ossicles, or inner ear bones, are a component of the conductive hearing system. This patient’s presentation is consistent with sensorineural hearing loss.  
❌ External auditory meatus  :
Incorrect: Cerumen impaction, debris, malignancy, and congenital malformations can contribute to conductive hearing loss by impairing sound traveling through the external auditory canal. This patient’s presentation is consistent with sensorineural hearing loss.  
❌ Tympanic membrane  :
Incorrect: Damage to the tympanic membrane may occur through vascular malformations, direct trauma, barotrauma, or inner ear infections. This structure is not typically damaged in patients with sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of new-onset hoarseness. The patient reports worsening hoarseness over several weeks without a precipitating cause. The patient has had no difficulty swallowing liquids or solids. He has a history of long-standing hypertension, mitral valve stenosis, and a twenty-pack-year smoking history. His vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates an irregular heartbeat. A screening electrocardiogram is shown below. Which of the following structures is most likely implicated in this patient’s symptomatology?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient with a longstanding history of hypertension and mitral valve stenosis presents with symptoms of compression of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve, likely secondary to left atrial enlargement. Left atrial enlargement often results in atrial fibrillation, as detailed on this patient’s electrocardiogram.

Left atrial enlargement can occur secondary to mitral regurgitation, left ventricular dysfunction, mitral stenosis, or volume overload. Over time, increased pressure dilates the left atrium, stretching the conduction fibers and resulting in atrial fibrillation. This enlargement can also compress nearby structures including the esophagus and left recurrent laryngeal nerve, which can manifest as dysphagia or hoarseness, respectively.  



Option Analysis

✅ Left recurrent laryngeal nerve :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Phrenic nerve :
Incorrect: The phrenic nerve is less commonly involved in cases of left atrial enlargement. Symptoms of phrenic nerve injury include exertional dyspnea, recurrent pneumonia, anxiety, insomnia, morning headache, excessive daytime somnolence, orthopnea, fatigue, or difficulty weaning from mechanical ventilation. 
❌ Esophagus:
Incorrect: The esophagus and the left recurrent laryngeal nerve may be affected in cases of left atrial enlargement. However, this patient does not have evidence of dysphagia, suggesting an absence of esophageal compression.
❌ Pulmonary vein :
Incorrect: Injury to the pulmonary vein can occur following cardiac ablation procedures, which can result in pulmonary hypertension. However, this patient has not undergone cardiac ablation, and he does not have signs of pulmonary hypertension. Hoarseness is more consistent with recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.
❌ Tricuspid valve:
Incorrect: Cardiac ablation procedures can result in direct cardiac damage, including injury to the tricuspid valve. However, this patient has not undergone a cardiac ablation, and hoarseness is more consistent with recurrent laryngeal nerve injury. Additionally, injury to the tricuspid valve would manifest with a systolic murmur, which is absent in this patient.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. The patient was walking up stairs at work when he suddenly collapsed in the stairwell. The patient describes the pain as “an elephant sitting on my chest” with associated shortness of breath. Past medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, and a twenty-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 154/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 99% on room air. Initial examination demonstrates a diaphoretic male in moderate distress clutching the front of his chest. An initial electrocardiogram is demonstrated below. Which of the following cardiac vessels most likely requires revascularization?  


Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient with multiple comorbidities and cardiovascular risk factors presents with classic features of acute coronary syndrome, including exertional chest pressure not relieved with rest. His initial electrocardiogram meets the criteria for ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), with notable elevations in the anterolateral leads of the heart with reciprocal depressions inferiorly. Given these findings, this patient most likely has occlusion of the left anterior descending coronary artery.   

Myocardial infarction is defined by irreversible necrosis of heart muscle secondary to prolonged ischemia. Clinically, this condition most commonly presents with chest pressure or pain radiating to the arm/jaw with associated dyspnea, diaphoresis, and nausea or vomiting. On electrocardiography, a STEMI can be recognized by the presence of ST-elevations in one or more contiguous leads with reciprocal depressions of corresponding leads.  

The three most commonly occluded vessels include the left anterior descending coronary artery (LAD), the right coronary artery (RCA), and the left circumflex coronary artery (LCX). These areas correspond to the anterior, inferior, and lateral anatomic regions of the heart, respectively. In most cases, the posterior descending artery branches from the right coronary artery (right dominant circulation). However, in a subset of cases, the posterior descending artery branches from the left circumflex coronary artery (left dominant circulation) or from the RCA and LCX (codominant circulation).  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Left anterior descending coronary artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Posterior descending coronary artery :
Incorrect: Infarction of the posterior descending coronary artery manifests with ST-depressions in V1-V3 and tall R-waves. A posterior ECG will demonstrate elevations in V7-V9, confirming the diagnosis. 
❌ Right coronary artery :
Incorrect: Infarction of the right coronary artery manifests with ST-elevations of the inferior leads and reciprocal changes in the anterior leads. 
❌ Left circumflex coronary artery:
Incorrect: Infarction of the left circumflex coronary artery manifests with ST elevations or q-waves in lead I or aVL. 
❌ Obtuse marginal artery :
Incorrect: Like infarctions of the left circumflex coronary artery, infarction of the obtuse marginal artery results in a lateral STEMI pattern on ECG–with elevations or q-waves in leads I, aVL, or V5-V6.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of respiratory distress. Paramedics report that the patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and has felt more short of breath over the past week. The patient's temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse 111/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 101/60 mmHg, and O2. is 87% on room air. Upon initial assessment, the patient is audibly wheezing and cannot provide any significant history due to an altered mental status. During the evaluation, the patient becomes cyanotic, and the emergency physician decides to perform rapid sequence intubation using video laryngoscopy and a Macintosh blade. The physician obtains a view of the upper airway, as demonstrated below.  Which of the following spaces correctly identifies the proper placement of the laryngoscope blade?  


Image credit: Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient with respiratory distress undergoes emergent laryngoscopy to place an endotracheal tube for mechanical ventilation. The proper anatomic placement of the Macintosh laryngoscope blade lies in the vallecula, indicated by choice A in the image above.  

Laryngoscopy refers to a medical procedure to achieve direct visualization of upper airway structures using a laryngoscope blade device. Indications for performing this procedure are numerous and include intubation (either elective or emergent) and visualization of structures during upper airway surgery. Direct laryngoscopy through the oropharynx using a Macintosh blade is performed by gently opening the mouth, inserting the laryngoscope blade, sweeping the tongue, placing the blade into the vallecula, and applying superior traction to visualize the vocal cords.  

Structures that can be visualized with this technique include the piriform fossae, aryepiglottic folds, vocal folds, rima glottidis, quadrangular membrane (covered with mucosa), vestibular folds, epiglottis, vallecula, and the dorsum of the tongue.  

Option Analysis

✅ A:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ B:
Incorrect: Choice B reflects the epiglottis. When intubating with a Miller blade, the blade is placed underneath the epiglottis and used to lift it up and out of the airway for visualization and placement of the endotracheal tube. However, the question stem states that intubation is performed using a Macintosh blade.   
❌ C:
Incorrect: Choice C reflects the vocal folds, which are too inferior for placement of the laryngoscope blade. The endotracheal tube should be visualized passing through these structures. 
❌ D:
Incorrect: Choice D reflects the left piriform recess. Placement of the laryngoscope into this space will not provide adequate visualization of the vocal cords. 
❌ E:
Incorrect:  Choice E reflects the right piriform recess. Placement of the laryngoscope into this space will not provide adequate visualization of the vocal cords.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of difficulty swallowing. Over the past several weeks, the patient has had the sensation of “food getting stuck” as he swallows. He also has a new history of intermittent “jitteriness.” Medical history is notable for long-standing hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes, and esophageal reflux. The patient’s medications include metoprolol, metformin, atorvastatin, and omeprazole. He has a history of medication non-compliance. Temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 177/92 mmHg. The patient’s physical examination is unremarkable. A portion of the patient’s telemetry strip is demonstrated below. Which of the following best describes the affected anatomic site that most likely resulted in this patient’s clinical symptoms?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Level of the left main bronchus

questions.solution:
This patient presents for dysphagia evaluation and is found to have new-onset atrial fibrillation. Although rare, atrial fibrillation and associated left atrial dilation can result in compression of the esophagus and subsequent food impaction.  

The esophagus has multiple compression sites as it courses from the oropharynx to the stomach. Superiorly, the esophagus may constrict as it enters the mediastinum, where the cricopharyngeus muscle may cause constriction. Thoracic constrictions occur where the arch of the aorta crosses the esophagus or at the levels of the left main bronchus and the left atrium. Lastly, the esophagus may constrict crossing the diaphragm.  

Pathologic insults at any anatomic site can ultimately slow the passage of solid foods and liquids. Over time, these insults can lead to esophageal stricture formation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Level of the left atrium :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Level of the cricopharyngeal muscle:
Incorrect: Food impaction and stricture formation may result at the esophageal level of the cricopharyngeus muscle. However, this patient's clinical presentation and ECG is more consistent with impaction at the level of the left atrium secondary to atrial dilation and associated compression of the esophagus. 
❌ Level of the aortic arch :
Incorrect: Aortic arch dilation from aortic dissection or aortic aneurysm may impede the esophagus at this level. However, this patient's clinical presentation and ECG is more consistent with impaction at the level of the left atrium secondary to atrial dilation and associated compression of the esophagus. 
❌ Level of the left main bronchus:
Incorrect: Impingement at the level of the left main bronchus may occur from mass effect due to associated trauma or tumor burden. However, this patient's clinical presentation and ECG is more consistent with impaction at the level of the left atrium secondary to atrial dilation and associated compression of the esophagus. 
❌ Level of the diaphragm:
Incorrect: Esophageal constriction may occur at the diaphragm level due to long-standing esophageal reflux disease and associated stricture formation. Typically, affected individuals will have evidence of untreated disease, including epigastric pain, a metallic taste in the mouth, or a history of gastritis or peptic ulcer disease. This patient's clinical presentation and ECG is more consistent with impaction at the level of the left atrium secondary to atrial dilation and associated compression of the esophagus.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency department to evaluate lower extremity swelling. Today, his nurse noted that his left lower extremity was swollen and red compared to his right lower extremity. He resides at a nursing facility and previously had a long ICU stay following an intracerebral hemorrhage secondary to amyloid angiopathy. Past medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus, dementia, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. The patient uses a wheelchair. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), blood pressure is 142/67 mmHg, pulse is 87/min, and O<sub>2</sub> saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals an elderly male in no acute distress. The patient is only oriented to self, which is consistent with his baseline. Contractures are noted in the upper extremities bilaterally. The left lower extremity is erythematous and swollen compared to the right lower extremity. Duplex ultrasonography reveals a deep femoral vein thrombosis in the left leg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient's condition?

choices.text: Placement of inferior vena cava filter

questions.solution:
This patient, with multiple chronic conditions and recent history of intracerebral hemorrhage, presents for evaluation of lower extremity swelling. He is found to have a proximal deep vein thrombosis. Given his history of a recent intracerebral hemorrhage, any form of anticoagulation is strictly contraindicated. Hence, the placement of an inferior vena cava filter is the next best step in management.

Proximal deep vein thrombosis has a high propensity towards embolization and must be treated diligently. Often, chronically ill or critically ill patients with proximal deep vein thrombosis may not receive anticoagulation due to recent surgery, known hemorrhage, or other bleeding dyscrasia. In these instances, an inferior vena cava filter may be inserted into the vena cava to barricade the heart and lungs from thromboemboli. On CT-imaging, a vena cava filter will appear as a radiodense device situated with the filter tip just at the inflow of the renal veins.


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  

Option Analysis

✅ Placement of inferior vena cava filter  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administration of alteplase  :
Incorrect: Alteplase is not indicated in the acute management of deep vein thrombosis. Moreover, administration of this medication could potentially incite further intracerebral hemorrhage.  
❌ IR-guided thrombectomy  :
Incorrect: IR-guided thrombectomy is indicated in the setting of massive deep vein thrombosis which entirely obstructs venous outflow from the extremity, resulting in a compartment syndrome. This rare condition is termed phlegmasia cerulea dolens, and it most commonly occurs in the lower extremities. In contrast, this patient has an uncomplicated deep vein thrombosis, and thus an IR-guided thrombectomy is not clinically indicated.  
❌ Infusion of heparin bolus  :
Incorrect: Administration of heparin would be appropriate for uncomplicated deep vein thrombosis. However, heparin administration could potentiate life-threatening intracerebral hemorrhage given this patient's history.  
❌ Administration of subcutaneous enoxaparin:
Incorrect: Like heparin, administration of enoxaparin would be appropriate for uncomplicated deep vein thrombosis. However, given this patient’s history, heparin administration could potentiate life-threatening intracerebral hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 24-year-old presents to your office with a complaint of left-sided scrotal mass accompanied by dull-aching pain in the scrotal area. They first noticed a small swelling in the area two months ago, which gradually increased in size, and now their left scrotum feels heavy, especially when they stand. They state “Honestly, it feels a bit like a bag of worms.” Review of systems is otherwise unremarkable. Past medical history is noncontributory. The patient is sexually active and uses condoms consistently. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a warm, non-tender, non-fluctuant left scrotal mass that does not transilluminate. The swelling increases in size with the Valsalva maneuver and disappears on lying down. Right scrotum and penis appear normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a left-sided scrotal mass that feels like a “bag of worms,” does not transilluminate, and increases in size with Valsalva; varicocele is the most likely diagnosis. Varicocele is defined as dilation of the pampiniform plexus, which is the venous drainage network of the testes.

Left-sided varicocele is more common due to drainage of the left gonadal vein into the left renal vein at a perpendicular angle. The effect is compounded by the compression of the left renal vein between the aorta and superior mesenteric artery (nutcracker effect), increasing the intravascular pressure in the left gonadal vein and the dilation of the pampiniform plexus. A right-sided varicocele should always raise suspicion for retroperitoneal pathology (e.g. renal cell carcinoma), especially if it is non-diminishing on recumbent position.

Affected patients may be asymptomatic, but they can present with soft, unilateral scrotal mass that does not transilluminate, dull-aching scrotal pain, and/or infertility. A bag-of-worms-like appearance is seen on scrotal examination.

In contrast, a hydrocele is thought to result from an imbalance of fluid secretion and reabsorption in the tunica vaginalis, leading to fluid accumulation around the testes and spermatic cord. Affected patients present with a soft, non-tender fullness in the hemi-scrotum that transilluminates well. Inflammatory conditions, like epididymitis, and torsion can precipitate the development of hydrocele.



Option Analysis

❌ Bacterial sequestration in the epididymis:
Incorrect: Bacterial sequestration in the epididymis causes epididymitis. Affected patients present with a gradual onset of scrotal pain (not a mass) that is accompanied by dysuria, urgency, or frequency. It is often preceded by urethral discharge in sexually active individuals. Common organisms are N. gonorrhea and E. coli.
❌ Fluid in the tunica vaginalis:
Incorrect: Fluid in the tunica vaginalis results in the formation of a hydrocele. Affected patients usually present with a soft, non-tender fullness in the hemi-scrotum that transilluminates. This patient’s swelling did not transilluminate, making hydrocele less likely.
❌ Cystic dilation of epididymis:
Incorrect: Cystic dilation of the epididymis results in a spermatocele. It appears as a soft, round mass in the head of the epididymis that is located on the superior aspect of the testicles. Contrary to this patient’s presentation, a spermatocele does not enlarge with the Valsalva maneuver and is usually asymptomatic.
✅ Dilation of pampiniform plexus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Neoplasia of left testes:
Incorrect: Testicular cancer is the most common cancer of young men and presents as a firm, non-tender nodule. It is discovered by the patient in most cases as a painless mass. Although similar to a varicocele in that it does not transilluminate, its size does not change with position as is observed in this patient.

questions.text:
A 6-month-old boy is brought to the pediatrician to evaluate difficulty feeding and recurrent stridor for several weeks. The patient has been persistently regurgitating feeds and intermittently becomes stridorous while playing. The parents became more concerned when the patient started “turning blue” occasionally. His birth history was uncomplicated, but he has dropped off his growth chart trajectory since his last well child check. Vital signs are within normal limits. With attempted feeding in the clinic, the patient vomits and becomes stridorous. The patient is subsequently sent to the emergency department, where a computed tomography (CT) of the chest is obtained and shown below. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Stenosis of the left subclavian artery

questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents for evaluation of recurrent dysphagia, vomiting, and respiratory distress. These findings are concerning for an anatomic anomaly. CT of the chest subsequently demonstrates a vascular ring of the aorta – specifically, a double aortic arch.   

Vascular anomalies of the aorta include a double arch of the aorta, a retro-esophageal right subclavian artery, and a right arch of the aorta.  

A double aortic arch occurs when two different take-offs from the aorta occur and then reform posterior to the trachea and esophagus. Ultimately this forms a ring around the esophagus and trachea, which can compress these structures and potentially result in difficulty breathing and swallowing.    

A retro-esophageal right subclavian artery refers to a right subclavian artery that arises in the left chest and subsequently courses posterior to the esophagus and trachea. This condition is most commonly asymptomatic but can result in recurrent dysphagia.  

Lastly, a right arch of the aorta represents an aorta that courses to the right of the trachea instead of its usual course to the left of the trachea. This condition represents a mirror image of normal aortic anatomy and is associated with certain genetic disorders. However, it is not pathologic in nature.    

Option Analysis

✅ Double arch of the aorta:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Right arch of the aorta :
Incorrect: A right arch of the aorta represents a mirror image of normal aortic anatomy. While this anatomic anomaly is associated with certain genetic disorders, it is not pathologic and would not account for this patient’s symptoms. 
❌ Stenosis of the left subclavian artery:
Incorrect: Subclavian steal syndrome is a phenomenon that occurs with severe stenosis of the subclavian artery proximal to the ipsilateral vertebral artery. Physiologically, this condition reverses blood flow through the ipsilateral vertebral artery, which can lead to vertebrobasilar ischemia. In addition, patients can manifest with exercise-induced ischemia of the affected limb. 
❌ Pulmonary infundibular stenosis :
Incorrect: Pulmonary infundibular stenosis is associated with Tetralogy of Fallot and is the most important marker of prognosis. While this condition could partially explain this patient’s respiratory distress, it does not explain the history of dysphagia. 
❌ Coarctation of the aorta:
Incorrect: Coarctation of the aorta refers to a discrete narrowing of the descending aorta at the insertion of the ductus arteriosus, just distal to the left subclavian artery. In severe cases, the condition can present with findings of heart failure in infancy.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. The patient states the pain feels sharp, but she does not note any exacerbating or relieving factors. The patient says she has eaten several spicy meals recently and wonders if the pain is related to indigestion. The patient reports she recently began a new exercise regimen involving arm and chest strengthening exercises. The patient is otherwise healthy and takes an oral contraceptive pill daily. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 120/65 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Physical examination shows a young, healthy woman in no acute distress. The cardiopulmonary examination is normal. There is some reproducible pain with palpation over the costal cartilage. ECG demonstrates sinus tachycardia, and chest radiography is unremarkable. Initial troponin is <.05 ng/L. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Discharge home with primary care follow up

questions.solution:
This patient with non-specific chest pain represents a multitude of diagnostic possibilities. Given her tachycardia and current use of oral contraceptive pills, she cannot be safely discharged before evaluation for pulmonary embolism per the PERC (pulmonary embolism rule-out criteria) rule. She should therefore undergo d-dimer testing before discharge to rule out a pulmonary embolism as the cause of her symptoms.    

A patient with chest pain poses a complicated diagnostic challenge given the broad differential diagnoses it encompasses, including cardiac, biliary, musculoskeletal, gastrointestinal, pulmonary and psychiatric etiologies. Life-threatening etiologies that must always be considered for any adult patient presenting with chest pain include acute coronary syndrome, pulmonary embolism, aortic dissection, esophageal rupture, pneumothorax, and cardiac tamponade.   

It is often helpful to employ clinical decision rules such as the PERC criteria to rule out a life-threatening diagnosis. In the case of pulmonary embolism (PE), this tool has been validated to rule out PE if no criteria are present and the pre-test probability is ≤15%. Listed criteria include the presence of tachycardia (heart rate ≥100 bpm), O2 sat >95%, age >50, hormone use, evidence of deep vein thrombosis, hemoptysis, history of thrombophilia, and recent surgery/trauma.  

Only once emergent causes of adult chest pain have been considered should more common diagnoses be considered, including cardiac etiologies like pericarditis and myocarditis, pleural causes like pneumonia, or gastrointestinal causes like an esophageal spasm, gastroesophageal reflux disorder, and peptic ulcer disease. Other common causes of chest pain include rib fracture, herpes zoster, and anxiety.  



Option Analysis

✅ D-dimer testing :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer omeprazole :
Incorrect: This patient presents with chest pain and should have emergent causes ruled out before anchoring on benign etiologies such as gastrointestinal reflux. Given her low-risk Wells score, a d-dimer should be sent.  
❌ Discharge home with primary care follow up :
Incorrect: This patient presents with chest pain and should have emergent causes ruled out before discharge.  
❌ CT-chest angiography:
Incorrect:  CT-chest angiography should be reserved for patients with high-risk Wells scores to evaluate pulmonary embolism. This patient has a low-risk Wells score.  
❌ Apply lidoderm patch and discharge:
Incorrect: While this patient's pain should be appropriately treated, applying a lidoderm patch and discharging the patient is inappropriate as all emergent causes of her chest pain have not been appropriately ruled out.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the emergency department complaining of chest pain that started 3 hours ago and was associated with shortness of breath. The patient has a history of hyperlipidemia and diabetes, and he has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg, pulse is 110 bpm, and respirations are 25/minute. On physical examination, the patient appears anxious and diaphoretic. Which of the following features in the history and physical examination would suggest acute coronary syndrome?

choices.text: Sharp chest pain that decreases with leaning forward
Pressure-like chest pain that radiates to the left shoulder
Sharp chest pain that is reproduced by palpation
Tearing chest pain that radiates to the back

questions.solution:
Acute coronary syndrome (ACS) is an emergency condition that requires immediate management. A precise and focused history and physical examination is critical in patients with suspected ACS as it helps rule out other differential diagnoses and can also indicate the severity of the condition.  

The most common presenting symptom of acute coronary syndrome is chest pain. The pain is usually localized to the substernal region and described as pressure-like or crushing in nature, with radiation to the jaw, left shoulder, or both. Pain can sometimes be in the epigastric region rather than the chest. Sharp, stabbing chest pain that is affected by movement or palpation is non-ischemic and suggests an alternative diagnosis. Other common symptoms of acute coronary syndrome include nausea and vomiting, dyspnea, lightheadedness, and fatigue.  

Acute coronary syndrome does not have many consistent, characteristic physical exam findings, but a detailed physical exam is important in considering all possible differential diagnoses for patients presenting with chest pain. For example, pain that is reproducible with palpation or movement during the physical examination is more suggestive of non-ischemic conditions, such as costochondritis or pericarditis.  

Most commonly, patients with ACS usually appear anxious and diaphoretic. Third and/or fourth heart sounds can sometimes be heard on auscultation in cases of ACS. While it can be physiologic, a pathologic S3 is most commonly caused by ventricular dysfunction and is predictive of adverse cardiac outcomes. The pathologic fourth heart sound (S4) is generated by forceful atrial contraction in the setting of decreased ventricular compliance as a result of conditions such as ischemic heart disease, diastolic dysfunction or hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. If congestive heart failure develops as a result of acute coronary syndrome, bibasilar crackles and hypotension can be present as well.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Sharp chest pain that decreases with leaning forward:
Incorrect: Sharp chest pain that decreases with leaning forward is a feature of acute pericarditis. The chest pain characteristic of acute coronary syndrome is not affected by movement or palpation.  
✅ Pressure-like chest pain that radiates to the left shoulder :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Sharp chest pain that is reproduced by palpation  :
Incorrect: Sharp chest pain that is reproducible by palpation is a feature of costochondritis. Overall, chest pain that is affected by palpation is suggestive of a non-ischemic cause, while the chest pain characteristic of acute coronary syndrome is not affected by movement or palpation.  
❌ Muffled heart sounds  :
Incorrect: Muffled heart sounds are a sign of cardiac tamponade, which also presents with hypotension and distended neck veins. Muffled heart sounds are not seen in patients with isolated acute coronary syndrome.  
❌ Tearing chest pain that radiates to the back :
Incorrect: Aortic dissection presents with sudden, tearing chest pain that more often radiates to the back. The quality of the pain associated with acute coronary syndrome is more commonly pressure-like and radiates to the left shoulder and/or jaw.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of a rash on his chest. The patient had a burning pain across his right chest last week, followed by the eruption of painful blisters two days ago. The patient has a history of a kidney transplant due to underlying diabetes and hypertension. The patient is currently taking tacrolimus daily. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 156/65 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for the finding as shown. Which of the following pathogens is most likely implicated in this patient’s clinical condition?

Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with herpes zoster or shingles, as manifested by the small clustered vesicular lesions in the T3 dermatome across the right chest that do not cross the midline. The organism known to induce this dermatologic finding is human-herpesvirus 3 (HHV-3).   

Shingles refers to the reactivation of a latent infection with the varicella-zoster virus, or HHV-3 – the same pathogen associated with childhood chickenpox. After the primary infection has subsided, the virus remains latent in the dorsal root or trigeminal nerve ganglia, typically for decades. Without proper vaccination, the virus harbors the risk of reactivation (especially in immunocompromised patients) within the ganglion to involve multiple sensory neurons and spread down the sensory nerve to establish infection in the skin.  

Clinically, this condition manifests with a rash that starts as erythematous papules in a single dermatome or several contiguous dermatomes. Over the next several days, the rash develops into small vesicles, which become pustular. As this process occurs, the involved sensory ganglion exhibits intense inflammation and hemorrhagic necrosis of nerve cells, resulting in post-herpetic neuralgia, the most common complication of shingles.    

Most commonly, reactivation occurs on the trunk; however, when reactivation occurs in the distribution of trigeminal V1, ocular involvement may occur. In this case, patients may also experience hearing loss, facial paralysis, or loss of taste, known as Ramsay-hunt syndrome. Less common complications include meningitis, encephalitis, myelitis, or bacterial superinfection in immunocompromised hosts.  

Option Analysis

✅ Varicella-zoster virus (Human-herpes-virus 3) :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect:  Staphylococcus aureus is a well-established cause of purulent cellulitis; however, this patient’s clinical presentation is more consistent with varicella-zoster given the findings of rash that starts as erythematous papules in a single dermatome.  
❌ Epstein Barr virus:
Incorrect:  The Epstein Barr virus, also known as HHV-4, is the most common culprit implicated in the setting of infectious mononucleosis; however, this patient’s clinical presentation is more consistent with varicella-zoster given the findings of rash that starts as erythematous papules in a single dermatome.  
❌ Human-herpes-virus 6:
Incorrect: Human herpesvirus 6 is the pathogen most commonly associated with roseola infantum in children, which typically presents with a few days of high-grade fever followed by the eruption of a blanching maculopapular rash. This patient’s clinical presentation is more consistent with varicella-zoster given the findings of rash that starts as erythematous papules in a single dermatome.  
❌ Cytomegalovirus:
Incorrect: Cytomegalovirus is the most common etiology of infectious mononucleosis in heterophile-negative patients; however, this patient’s clinical presentation is more consistent with varicella-zoster given the findings of rash that starts as erythematous papules in a single dermatome.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of palpitations. A screening electrocardiogram demonstrates supraventricular tachycardia at a heart rate of 160. While the patient is being attached to the monitor, the physician instructs the patient to forcefully exhale against a closed mouth while pinching the nose, which results in termination of the arrhythmia. Stimulation of which of the following nerves is responsible for the change in this patient’s clinical course?
questions.solution:
This patient who presents with supraventricular tachycardia is able to abate the arrhythmia via stimulation of the vagus nerve (CN X) in the middle and inner ear. The auricular branch of the vagus nerve is also known as Alderman's nerve or Arnold's nerve.

In the context of ear anatomy, the vagus nerve supplies the inferior and posterior aspects of the external auditory canal, the concavity of the concha, as well as the lateral surface of the tympanic membrane in a subset of the population. Stimulation of these anatomic structures via valsalva maneuver, cerumen impaction, or tactile stimulation can concurrently stimulate associated reflexes of the vagus nerve. Ultimately, this may produce symptoms such as coughing, vomiting, syncope, or bradycardia.  

Option Analysis

✅ CN X  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ CN IX  :
Incorrect: In the context of ear anatomy, CN IX supplies the mastoid air cells, middle ear, and medial surface of the tympanic membrane. This nerve does not mediate a vagal response.  
❌ Auriculotemporal nerve  :
Incorrect: The auriculotemporal nerve supplies the temporal scalp, the external auditory meatus, preauricular area and tragus, and the temporomandibular joint. This nerve does not mediate a vagal response.  
❌ Lesser occipital nerve  :
Incorrect: The lesser occipital nerve supplies the posterolateral scalp, supraauricular scalp, and superior pinna. This nerve does not mediate a vagal response.  
❌ CN VIII  :
Incorrect: This nerve supplies the lateral surface of the tympanic membrane, external acoustic meatus, and concha. This nerve does not mediate a vagal response.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of left ear pain and ringing. The patient reports an insidious onset of her symptoms four to five days ago. The patient states, “I tried listening to classical music yesterday to calm my nerves, and I experienced a shooting pain in my left ear.” The patient is otherwise healthy, and her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates diminished sensation in the left ear, left sided facial droop, and inability to wrinkle the left forehead. Which of the following structures is most likely responsible for this patient’s otologic symptomatology?
questions.solution:
Bell palsy, or facial nerve paralysis, is a common cause of hyperacusis – a hearing disorder characterized by increased sensitivity to high frequency and high volume sounds. The stapedius muscle contracts in response to loud noise, thus dampening the vibrations of the ossicles and protecting the ear.

Paralysis of the facial nerve (CN VII) results in the inability of the stapedius to contract and causes sounds to be abnormally loud on the affected side.

Hyperacusis can be an incredibly debilitating condition, most commonly caused by prolonged exposure to high decibel sounds. Other common conditions associated with this condition include Bell Palsy or Meniere disease. Symptoms include pain in the affected ear when exposed to noise.  

Option Analysis

✅ Stapedius muscle  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Incus  :
Incorrect: The incus represents the anvil-shaped bone in the middle ear, which transmits vibrations between the malleus and stapes. It is not the primary anatomic site of pathology in patients with hyperacusis.  
❌ Malleus  :
Incorrect: The malleus is a hammer-shaped small bone or ossicle of the middle ear which connects to the incus and is attached to the inner surface of the tympanic membrane. It is not the primary anatomic site of pathology in patients with hyperacusis.  
❌ CN V  :
Incorrect: The facial nerve, not the trigeminal nerve, is implicated in the pathogenesis of hyperacusis.    
❌ Greater petrosal nerve  :
Incorrect: The greater petrosal nerve branches from the facial nerve to form a chain of nerves that innervate the lacrimal gland. This nerve is not implicated in patients with hyperacusis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the office to evaluate right ear pain for the past three months. The pain is constant, dull, and associated with recurrent right-sided jaw pain and headache. The pain worsens throughout the day and with chewing. He hears a “cracking sound” while eating. The patient’s partner says that he grinds his teeth at night. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows limited jaw opening and muscle spasms over the lateral right face. Otoscopic examination is within normal limits. Which of the following nerves contributes to this patient’s ear pain?
questions.solution:
This patient’s ear pain, headache, and jaw pain are characteristic of temporomandibular joint (TMJ) disorder. Underlying etiologies of this condition include pathological contraction of the pterygoid muscles secondary to repeated jaw clenching or grinding, misalignment, or trauma. Patients often develop hypersensitivity of the mandibular nerve (CV V3) and subsequent otalgia, given the nerve’s proximity to the TMJ. Classic symptoms include dull, waxing and waning jaw/facial pain, clicking and popping with jaw movement, ear pain, fullness, and tinnitus.

The mandibular nerve, the largest branch of the trigeminal nerve, supplies sensation to the TMJ in addition to the floor of the mouth, anterior tongue, and the lower face. In addition, this nerve contributes to sensory innervation to the external auditory canal. Therefore, TMJ disorder can also present with referred ear pain.  

Option Analysis

✅ Trigeminal nerve  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypoglossal nerve  :
Incorrect: The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) carries general motor innervation to the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue. It is not implicated in temporomandibular joint disorder.  
❌ Vagus nerve  :
Incorrect: The auricular branch of the vagus nerve (CN X) carries sensory innervation from the external auditory canal; however, it is not the underlying cause of ear pain in this patient with temporomandibular joint disorder.  
❌ Cervical spinal nerve  :
Incorrect: The cervical spinal nerve is harmed by structural lesions to the cervical spine. More commonly, damage to this nerve results in neck pain/stiffness and arm and shoulder weakness. It is not implicated in temporomandibular joint disorder.
❌ Vestibulocochlear nerve  :
Incorrect: The vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) carries auditory and vestibular information from the inner ear. It is not implicated in temporomandibular joint disorder.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of facial swelling. Over the past several weeks, he has noticed his face has become “puffier,” particularly in the morning. In addition, he has a new cough and shortness of breath on exertion. His own past medical history is unremarkable, though his father passed away from a pulmonary embolism. The patient takes no medications. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for thirty years. He does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 111 /min, and blood pressure is 131/66 mmHg. Respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates distended neck veins and bilateral facial fullness without tenderness to palpation or erythema. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with bilateral facial fullness, distended neck veins, and significant smoking history. Together these findings are consistent with superior vena cava syndrome, of which the most common etiology is an apical lung mass.   

Apical lung tumors, also known as Pancoast tumors, are typically non-small cell lung malignancies known for their unique clinical manifestations. Typically, initial symptoms include non-specific shoulder pain that is often misdiagnosed as osteoarthritis or musculoskeletal injury. As the tumor grows, it invades surrounding mediastinal structures and results in a classic constellation of complications.  

Invasion of the paravertebral sympathetic chain and the inferior cervical (stellate) ganglion manifests with Horner syndrome–classically described as miosis, anhidrosis, and ptosis. In addition, an extension of the tumor into the cervical ganglion results in weakness or sensory disturbance in the upper extremity.    

A less common complication is superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome, which refers to diminished return of blood to the right heart due to mass effect or direct invasion of the tumor into the superior vena cava. Patients with SVC syndrome can present with engorged neck veins and facial fullness.  

Other complications of Pancoast tumors include hoarseness from recurrent laryngeal nerve injury, dysphagia from esophageal impingement, and hemidiaphragm paralysis from damage to the phrenic nerve.    

Option Analysis

✅ Apical lung mass :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inherited thrombophilia :
Incorrect: Inherited hypercoagulable disorders, such as factor V Leiden, do not commonly present with thrombus formation in the superior vena cava or inferior vena cava.
❌ Subclavian artery aneurysm:
Incorrect: A subclavian artery aneurysm is not a well-established etiology of superior vena cava syndrome.
❌ Facial cellulitis :
Incorrect: Facial cellulitis remains in the differential for superior vena cava syndrome. However, patients would typically present with additional signs of inflammation, including fevers, chills, or purulent drainage.
❌ Suppurative parotitis:
Incorrect: Suppurative parotitis is a severe bacterial infection of the parotid gland in patients with decreased salivary flow. It commonly presents with trismus and unilateral swelling over the parotid gland with purulence emanating from the Stensen duct.

questions.text: A 39-year-old female with a history of HIV presents to the infectious disease specialist for follow-up care after multiple rounds of treatment for active tuberculosis. She has been intermittently compliant with the  medication regimen and continues to have persistent symptoms despite multiple rounds of therapy with different antimicrobials. The infectious disease specialist informs her that she likely has extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis. Which of the following treatment options is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with persistent active tuberculosis despite multiple rounds of therapy and is diagnosed with extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB). Pretomanid, which was recently approved by the FDA, can be used in conjunction with bedaquiline and linezolid to treat this condition. This drug combination has demonstrated greater than 90% efficacy for treating XDR-TB.  

Drug-resistant tuberculosis continues to be a growing problem around the world and is a key target for the World Health Organization and public health organizations globally. Drug-resistant tuberculosis is divided into multi-drug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) and extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB). MDR-TB is resistant to at least isoniazid and rifampin, the two most potent anti-tuberculosis medications. XDR-TB is a rarer type of drug resistant tuberculosis that is not only resistant to isoniazid and rifampin, but also fluoroquinolones amikacin, kanamycin, and capreomycin. Patients at risk for drug-resistant tuberculosis include those who do not take their tuberculosis medications regularly, develop recurrent tuberculosis, or come from areas of the world where drug-resistant tuberculosis is prevalent.  

Option Analysis

✅ Pretomanid, linezolid, and bedaquiline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Streptomycin monotherapy:
Incorrect: Streptomycin is considered a second line agent in the treatment of Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection. It is not typically used in the treatment of drug-resistant tuberculosis. 
❌ Daptomycin monotherapy:
Incorrect: Daptomycin is a lipopeptide that disrupts the cell wall of Gram positive cocci and is not used in the treatment of tuberculosis. Instead, it is used for treating methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, bacteremia, and endocarditis. 
❌ Linezolid monotherapy:
Incorrect: Linezolid alone is not useful for the treatment of extremely drug-resistant tuberculosis. Instead, it must be used in conjunction with bedaquiline and pretomanid to achieve efficacy. 
❌ Azithromycin and ethambutol :
Incorrect: The combination of azithromycin and ethambutol is utilized in the treatment of Mycobacterium avium complex infections. This combination does not have a role in the treatment of extremely drug-resistant tuberculosis.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old male comes to the clinic complaining of fatigue, dizziness, and shortness of breath. Past medical history includes type II diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease, for which he has been on dialysis for the last 4 years. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 136/78 mmHg. Physical exam shows pallor of the conjunctiva and finger nail beds. Laboratory tests are obtained and the results are shown below.  



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treating this patient’s hematological abnormality?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of chronic kidney disease has lab findings showing normocytic anemia, low reticulocyte count (< 2%), low serum iron, high ferritin levels, and low total iron binding capacity (TIBC). He has anemia of chronic disease due to chronic kidney disease (CKD).  

Anemia of chronic disease is caused by increased hepcidin release from the liver. Hepcidin binds to a transmembrane protein called ferroportin, which is found on intestinal mucosal cells, thus blocking iron absorption from the gut and release from macrophages where it is stored. As a result, although there is iron in the body, it is trapped within macrophages, and serum iron levels are decreased. The bone marrow is unable to produce adequate levels of erythrocytes, resulting in anemia. Iron studies can aid in diagnosis and differentiate anemia of chronic disease from other iron-related pathologies.  



Initially, anemia of chronic disease causes a normocytic anemia, but as the disease progresses, the bone marrow starts releasing smaller erythrocytes, and the anemia becomes microcytic.



Common causes include autoimmune diseases (rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus), neoplasms (hepatocellular carcinoma, renal cell carcinoma), and chronic kidney disease.  

Erythropoietin (EPO) supplementation can be administered to improve symptoms in patients with CKD who are on dialysis and have a hemoglobin < 10 g/dL. Iron supplementation may be used to treat concomitant iron deficiency anemia, and blood transfusions may be used with caution in severe cases. 

Option Analysis

❌ Iron supplementation:
Incorrect: Iron supplementation would be the treatment of choice for iron deficiency anemia. This patient has a high ferritin and low total iron binding capacity (TIBC), making anemia of chronic disease more likely as the underlying cause.
✅ Erythropoietin (EPO):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF):
Incorrect: Granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) would be the treatment of choice for bone marrow stimulation in patients with aplastic anemia. In contrast, this patient has normal platelet and leukocyte counts, making aplastic anemia unlikely.
❌ Phlebotomy:
Incorrect: Phlebotomy can be used to treat hemochromatosis, which presents with elevated serum iron levels. This patient has decreased serum iron, elevated ferritin levels, and decreased TIBC, which is more consistent with anemia of chronic disease.
❌ Intravenous prednisone:
Incorrect: Immunosuppressants may be used in the treatment of pure red cell aplasia. This condition can be caused by many etiologies, ranging from medications (e.g., isoniazid, phenytoin) to malignancy, and presents as a normocytic anemia with low reticulocyte count. However, iron studies are usually normal in patients with pure red blood cell aplasia.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of nausea, vomiting, muscle weakness, and confusion. The symptoms began two days ago. Review of his medical record reveals that he has a recent diagnosis of depression for which fluoxetine therapy was initiated four-weeks ago by his psychiatrist. Temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 78/min, and respiratory rate is 15/min and blood pressure is 117/78 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient has difficulty standing due to generalized weakness. Laboratory studies are as follows:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Sodium  118 mEq/L 
 Blood Urea Nitrogen  15 mg/dL 
 Creatinine  0.8 mg/dL 
 Glucose  105 mg/dL 
 Serum Osmolarity   241 mOsm/kg 
 Urine Osmolality  405 mOsm/kg 

Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient is having severe symptomatic hyponatremia (nausea, vomiting, muscle weakness and confusion). He takes fluoxetine, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that can sometimes lead to syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) by increasing pituitary ADH secretion as a side effect.  

Laboratory findings in SIADH include low serum osmolality and high urine osmolality. This is because excess ADH increases water reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubules, resulting in water retention. In turn, the body reduces aldosterone production, which increases urinary sodium excretion to help eliminate some of the excess water. The net result is euvolemic hyponatremia.  

Patients with SIADH are encouraged to restrict fluid intake to 800 ml/day or less. For asymptomatic patients or patients with mild symptoms, salt tablets can be used. In more severe cases, as in this vignette, hypertonic saline is used to correct the hyponatremia. A loop diuretic can be used to supplement the salt tablets or hypertonic saline.  

Serum sodium levels should be corrected by no more than 10 mmol/L within 24 hours. Overly rapid correction can cause central pontine myelinolysis, which presents with symptoms including acute paralysis, dysphagia, and dysarthria.  



Option Analysis

❌ Initiation of 0.9% saline infusion:
Incorrect: Isotonic 0.9% saline is not recommended in patients with SIADH because patients with SIADH have low aldosterone levels, which causes sodium in the saline to be excreted, and high ADH levels, which causes water in the saline to be retained. The net result is worsening hyponatremia.
✅ Initiation of 3% saline infusion:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Administer furosemide:
Incorrect: Loop diuretics are sometimes used to potentiate the treatment of SIADH. The loop diuretics prevent solute reabsorption in the thick ascending loop of Henle, thereby preventing formation of the medullary concentration gradient. This helps increase the amount of free water lost in urine. However, loop diuretics alone are generally insufficient and are not considered the first-line therapy.
❌ Administer tolvaptan:
Incorrect: Vasopressin antagonists, such as tolvaptan and conivaptan, have been shown to be effective in improving sodium levels in hyponatremic patients. However, the agent has the risk of correcting hyponatremia too rapidly, potentially causing severe neurologic injury. As a result, vasopressin antagonists are generally reserved for patients who have remained hyponatremic despite other interventions.
❌ Emergent hemo-dialysis:
Incorrect: Emergent hemodialysis may rarely be indicated in the treatment of hyponatremia in patients with kidney failure. However, this patient has blood urine nitrogen and creatinine levels within normal range, indicating that the kidneys are functioning normally. Dialysis is not recommended in patients with hyponatremia who have normal-functioning kidneys.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of fever and productive cough with purulent, foul-smelling sputum. Her symptoms have been going on for the past 4 days. She has a history of alcohol abuse and drinks a pint of vodka daily. She was brought to the emergency department several weeks ago for alcohol intoxication after being found unconscious on the sidewalk. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 106/min, blood pressure is 121/65 mmHg, and pulse oximetry is 90% on room air. Oral examination reveals poor dentition. Crackles are heard over the right lung base. Chest radiograph reveals a right lower lobe infiltrate. Sputum Gram-stain shows neutrophils, Gram-positive rods, and Gram-negative rods. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with fever, foul-smelling sputum, and a history of alcohol intoxication. These findings are suggestive of aspiration pneumonia, which can be treated with amoxicillin-clavulanate, for optimal coverage of both anaerobic and community-acquired organisms.

Aspiration pneumonia occurs when patients accidentally aspirate food, drinks, or gastric contents. The condition typically occurs in patients with impaired gag and cough reflexes or altered consciousness. Therefore, aspiration pneumonia is more common in patients with a history of drug or alcohol abuse, seizure disorders, or strokes leading to swallowing issues. Clinically, patients may have crackles on auscultation, high fevers, shortness of breath, and a productive cough with foul-smelling sputum.

Since aspiration pneumonia is caused by a mixture of aspirated gastric contents and oral secretions, sputum Gram-stain will typically reveal mixed infections with aerobic and anaerobic organisms. Therefore, treatment involves antibiotics such as amoxicillin-clavulanate or ampicillin-sulbactam, which provide broad anaerobic coverage.

Option Analysis

✅ Amoxicillin-Clavulanate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Doxycycline:
Incorrect: Doxycycline is appropriate for treating atypical pneumonia caused by pathogens such as with Mycoplasma or Chlamydia. However, this patient more likely has aspiration pneumonia, which is often caused by anaerobic bacteria, and thus doxycycline would provide inadequate coverage.
❌ Levofloxacin:
Incorrect: Fluoroquinolones can be used to treat community-acquired pneumonia, especially in individuals who cannot tolerate the first-line options (e.g. severe penicillin allergy). This patient is presenting with aspiration pneumonia, however, which often involves anaerobic bacteria that fluoroquinolones would inadequately cover.
❌ Metronidazole:
Incorrect: Metronidazole has good anaerobic coverage and is useful for treating intra-abdominal infections. Some studies show the efficacy of metronidazole in the treatment of aspiration pneumonia when used concomitantly with a penicillin. However, monotherapy is associated with a high failure rate.
❌ Vancomycin:
Incorrect: Although vancomycin can be used as part of the treatment regimen in patients with aspiration pneumonia, it is not effective as monotherapy since the infection is often polymicrobial. In contrast, vancomycin only covers gram-positive organisms. Furthermore, vancomycin would provide inadequate anaerobic coverage for treating aspiration pneumonia.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of abdominal cramps, bloating, and diarrhea. The symptoms began several weeks ago. He describes the diarrhea as “greasy and difficult to flush.” He has unintentionally lost 13-lb over this time period and has also felt significantly more fatigued. The patient has not had any recent rashes, joint pains, or blood in the diarrhea. He has been sexually active with 3 partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. Past medical history is noncontributory. He lives in the Dominican Republic. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 122/84 mmHg. Physical examination reveals conjunctival pallor. Mild abdominal tenderness is elicited with palpation, and bowel sounds are hyperactive. Fecal occult blood test is negative, and stool microscopy shows no parasites or leukocytes. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:  
 
 Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies (IgA, IgG)  Negative 
 Anti-endomysial antibody (IgA)  Negative 
 Deamidated gliadin peptide (IgG)  Negative 
 HIV-1/2 PCR  Negative  

Upper endoscopy reveals flattening of the duodenal folds. Biopsy of the small intestine shows blunted villi and elongated crypts with increased inflammatory cells. A peripheral blood smear shows hypersegmented neutrophils. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Avoidance of gluten in the diet
Avoidance of lactose in the diet

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with symptoms of malabsorption and steatorrhea, which has likely contributed to his signs of megaloblastic anemia (e.g., fatigue, hypersegmented neutrophils). Taking into consideration his past history of living in the Caribbean and endoscopic findings of flattened intestinal folds, he likely has tropical sprue.   

Tropical sprue commonly affects individuals living in tropical environments (e.g., Haiti, Dominican Republic, Puerto Rico), as well as travelers returning from these areas. The condition is likely caused by toxins and fermentation products produced by bacterial overgrowth, which can cause significant small bowel structural damage. Biopsy would show findings that are remarkably similar to celiac disease, such as the atrophic villi and crypt hyperplasia.   

Due to nutritional malabsorption, patients with tropical sprue may have impaired B12 and folate absorption in the small intestine, which can lead to megaloblastic anemia. Patients can also have impaired absorption of fat-soluble vitamins (vitamins A, D, E, K). Since the underlying cause is bacterial overgrowth, treatment consists of antibiotics (e.g. doxycycline), as well as folate supplementation.   



Option Analysis

✅ Antibiotics and folate supplementation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Avoidance of gluten in the diet:
Incorrect: Gluten-free diets are essential in the management of patients with celiac disease. Although celiac disease may cause bloating and diarrhea, it more commonly manifests in individuals of Northern European descent. Furthermore, patients with celiac disease would typically be positive for anti-tissue transglutaminase, anti-endomysial, or anti-deamidated gliadin peptide antibodies.
❌ Avoidance of lactose in the diet:
Incorrect: Lactose intolerance is best managed by avoiding lactose-containing foods. Patients commonly present with bloating and diarrhea. Diagnostic studies would show a positive hydrogen breath test, due to bacterial fermentation of undigested lactose in the intestinal tract, as well as normal endoscopic findings, since there is no structural damage. This patient’s endoscopic findings make lactose intolerance an unlikely diagnosis. 
❌ Highly active antiretroviral therapy:
Incorrect: Highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) is extremely effective in the treatment of HIV. Although HIV may also present with chronic diarrhea, this patient’s negative HIV 1/2 PCR test makes this diagnosis unlikely. 
❌ Mesalamine:
Incorrect: Mesalamine is effective in the treatment of inflammatory bowel diseases, such as Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis. Although these conditions can also present with diarrhea, their endoscopic findings would differ from this patient’s. Crohn disease would show sporadic granulomatous inflammation, whereas ulcerative colitis would show continuous lesions at the rectum.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the office seeking evaluation for pain in both legs. The patient describes the pain as deep and constant. The pain is present during the day, and weight-bearing makes it worse. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 127/75 mmHg, and pulse is 75/min. Physical examination reveals warmth and erythema present on the anterior aspect of the bilateral thighs. In addition, the neurological exam reveals sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear. The remainder of the physical examination is noncontributory. Imaging studies reveal significant sclerosis, with evidence of osteolytic lesions and cortical thickening. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has Paget disease of the bone, a condition characterized by abnormal bone remodelling. Patients experience bone pain due to microfractures, erythema/warmth over affected areas, and increased shoe/hat size after puberty. In addition, changes in the shape of the skull can cause facial changes and cranial nerve impingement, which can present with sensorineural hearing loss. Radiographic studies will reveal sclerotic and lytic lesions, since both osteoblast and osteoclast activity are increased.

First-line treatment for Paget disease of the bone is bisphosphonates, which slows down bone lysis. Pain medications can be given for symptomatic management. In patients with contraindications to bisphosphonates (e.g., hypersensitivity reaction, kidney disease, esophageal abnormalities), calcitonin can be given as an alternative. In addition, surgery can help correct bone deformities, decompress an impinged nerve, and reduce associated fractures.  

Option Analysis

❌ Bone marrow transplant:
Incorrect: Bone marrow transplants can treat aggressive cases of osteopetrosis. Osteopetrosis can also cause cranial nerve deficits. However, the condition typically presents in infancy or early adulthood. Moreover, radiographic imaging in patients with osteopetrosis will not reveal lytic lesions.
✅ Bisphosphonate therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Vancomycin and cefepime dual therapy:
Incorrect: Antibiotics can be used to treat cellulitis, osteomyelitis, and other infections. An infection may account for the warmth and erythema. However, the patient would be expected to have a fever. Moreover, it would be atypical for an infection to present in a bilateral and almost symmetrical pattern.
❌ Calcitonin therapy:
Incorrect: Calcitonin is a medication that can reduce bone turnover. However, calcitonin is generally less potent than bisphosphonates. It is used for patients with contraindications to bisphosphonates (e.g., prior allergic reaction, kidney disease, esophageal abnormalities). This patient has none of these contraindications.
❌ Ibuprofen therapy:
Incorrect: Ibuprofen can be used for pain management. However, it is not the first-line treatment for Paget disease of the bone. Moreover, ibuprofen does not address the increased and abnormal bone remodelling, which is the underlying pathophysiology of this condition.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of left knee pain. The symptoms began about half-a-year ago. She works as a supermarket cashier and reports that the pain is worse in the evening. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and atherosclerosis. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 137/85 mmHg, and body mass index is 30 kg/m2. Physical examination is notable for crepitus and reduced range of motion in the left knee. No erythema or warmth is noted at the affected joint. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal examinations are noncontributory. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has osteoarthritis, which occurs secondary to mechanical wear and tear that destroys the joint cartilage and underlying bone. The main culprit behind osteoarthritis is the daily stress applied to joints in a patient’s lifetime, especially to weight-bearing joints (e.g., ankle, knee, hip). This pathophysiology explains why the greatest risk factors are age, joint injury, obesity, and altered walking patterns that increase joint stress.

Osteoarthritis usually causes asymmetrical pain that worsens with use. Patients can also have joint stiffening lasting less than 30 minutes after periods of inactivity. This symptom is termed the “gelling phenomenon” because it occurs when the synovial fluid becomes thickened. Other symptoms include joint instability, limited range of motion, and crepitus, which are crackling or popping sounds felt on joint palpation due to the bones rubbing against each other.

First-line treatment of osteoarthritis involves non-pharmacological approaches such as weight loss, moderate exercise, and physical therapy. Pharmacological treatment focuses on reducing pain and inflammation and usually consists of acetaminophen and NSAIDs. If neither of these are successful, some people may benefit from injections of hyaluronic acid or corticosteroids into the joint, or they may need surgical replacement of the affected joint.





 

Option Analysis

❌ Perform intra-articular glucocorticoid injection:
Incorrect: Glucocorticoid injection can be used for the short-term management of osteoarthritis. However, it is not the first-line therapy, since glucocorticoids can damage hyaline cartilage and may accelerate the progression of osteoarthritis.
✅ Initiation of ibuprofen therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Referral for knee arthroplasty:
Incorrect: Arthroplasty (knee replacement) can be performed in patients with osteoarthritis who have failed medical management, such as NSAIDs and tramadol. It would be premature to refer this patient for surgery, since no medical therapies have been tried yet.
❌ Administration of methotrexate:
Incorrect: Methotrexate can treat rheumatoid arthritis, which manifests with symmetrical joint pain and stiffness that improves with activity. In contrast, this patient has asymmetrical joint pain, and her symptoms worsen with activity, which is more consistent with osteoarthritis.
❌ Initiation of duloxetine therapy:
Incorrect: Duloxetine, a serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, can be used to treat osteoarthritis in patients with contraindications to NSAIDs (e.g. renal failure). However, neither hypertension nor atherosclerosis are contraindications to NSAID therapy.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman comes to her physician for evaluation of recurrent episodes of headache, palpitations, and anxiety. She works as a lawyer and states her job has been stressful recently, and she has noticed that these episodes occur more frequently. The patient had a prophylactic thyroidectomy at a young age due to an inherited genetic condition. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 128/80 mmHg. Physical examination reveals an arm span that exceeds the patient’s height. Examination of the oral cavity shows multiple small mucosal nodules at the tip of the tongue. Which of the following diagnostic studies would be most helpful in confirming the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has a history of prophylactic thyroidectomy and physical examination showing mucosal neuromas and a Marfanoid habitus. She likely has multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2B (MEN 2B).

MEN 2B is caused by a mutated RET proto-oncogene and can result in tumor formation within the thyroid and adrenal gland. Medullary thyroid cancer occurs in almost all patients, therefore warranting prophylactic removal when the syndrome is diagnosed. Adrenal gland neoplasms typically occur in the medulla in the form of pheochromocytomas. The sudden release of catecholamines from the adrenal tumor causes paroxysmal episodes characterized by sympathetic overactivation; hypertensive episodes associated with anxiety, tachycardia, palpitations, headache, diaphoresis (sweating), and tremors are common symptoms.

The diagnosis of pheochromocytoma is made based upon biochemical confirmation of catecholamine hypersecretion, followed by identifying the tumor with imaging studies. Initial biochemical tests involve checking the levels of two hormones, metanephrine and normetanephrine, which are compounds produced from the degradation of catecholamines in the blood and urine. This laboratory evaluation can be done by either a plasma free metanephrines test or by a 24-hour urinary metanephrines test. Once a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma is confirmed, an ultrasound or a CT scan can be used to identify the tumor’s location.



Option Analysis

✅ 24-hour urinary metanephrines test:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ MRI of the brain:
Incorrect: MRI of the brain would be useful for visualizing an intracranial mass, such as a pituitary adenoma. Patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type 1, for example, are predisposed to developing pituitary masses. This patient with MEN 2B, however, is not likely to have an intracranial mass, nor would it explain her symptoms.
❌ Midnight salivary cortisol:
Incorrect: An elevated midnight salivary cortisol level may be present in patients with hypercortisolism, either due to a pituitary or adrenal mass. This patient with multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type 2B, however, is not likely to have Cushing syndrome. Furthermore, hypercortisolism would not manifest with the intermittent episodes of headaches, palpitations, and anxiety experienced by this patient.
❌ Serum calcium measurement:
Incorrect: Serum calcium measurement would be useful for patients suspected of having hypercalcemia (e.g., nephrolithiasis, constipation, neuropsychiatric disturbances). Parathyroid hyperplasia, a common cause of hypercalcemia, is associated with MEN 1 and MEN 2A. This patient, however, has tongue neuromas and a Marfanoid body habitus (arm span exceeding height), which is more consistent with MEN 2B.
❌ Serum gastrin measurement :
Incorrect: Pancreatic neoplasms can be seen in multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type 1. Gastrinomas, for example, can present with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss. However, a gastrinoma would not manifest with intermittent episodes of headaches, palpitations, and anxiety.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with lethargy and severe abdominal pain since yesterday. He has had 4-5 episodes of small-volume bloody diarrhea per day accompanied by lower abdominal cramps for the past 2 months. Review of systems reveals a 4-kg (8.8-lbs) weight loss and loss of appetite. The remainder of his history is noncontributory. Temperature is 38.8°C (102°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 90/55 mmHg. Physical examination shows lethargy and dry mucous membranes. There is abdominal distension, diffuse abdominal tenderness, and decreased bowel sounds without rebound or guarding. Rectal examination reveals marked tenderness, with guaiac-positive, maroon-colored, liquid stools in the vault. Laboratory results are shown below:
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Complete blood count 
 Hemoglobin  9.9 mg/dL 
 Platelets  455,000/mm3 
 Leukocytes  19,200/mm3 
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate  67 mm/hr 

 Fluid resuscitation with 0.9% normal saline improves the blood pressure to 103/59 mmHg. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a 2-month history of multiple episodes of bloody diarrhea that are accompanied by abdominal cramps likely has undiagnosed inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), specifically ulcerative colitis (UC). His rapid clinical deterioration (severe abdominal pain, abdominal distension, tenesmus) with signs of shock (e.g., tachycardia, hypotension, lethargy) are concerning for toxic megacolon, a known complication of UC.

Toxic megacolon is a result of worsening inflammation of the bowel that causes release of inflammatory mediators (e.g. cytokines), bacterial products, and increased amounts of nitric oxide, which contributes to colonic smooth muscle paralysis. This paralysis not only disrupts the intestinal motility but also causes thinning of the intestinal wall and colonic distension, making it prone to perforation. Other manifestations include altered mental status, signs of peritonitis (in the event of perforation), and electrolyte abnormalities.
