The diagnosis of toxic megacolon can be made on plain abdominal x-ray, a non-invasive study that can be quickly performed and also rules out mechanical obstruction or perforation. It shows colonic dilation (diameter >6 cm) with multiple air-fluid levels. If these findings are accompanied by free air under the diaphragm, intestinal perforation should be considered.


Retrieved from: Radiopaedia.org



Option Analysis

❌ Abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Though high-resolution ultrasound is helpful in assessing the response to therapy in patients with UC, it is not typically used in the diagnosis of toxic megacolon. It is usually employed in acute trauma (to look for intraperitoneal free fluid), acute right upper quadrant pain (e.g. due to cholecystitis), or suspected nephrolithiasis.
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: Colonoscopy is contraindicated in patients with suspected toxic megacolon due to the risk of perforation. However, sigmoidoscopy (without bowel preparation) or proctoscopy can be considered to help identify the etiology of colonic dilation once the diagnosis is confirmed with abdominal x-ray.
❌ Barium enema:
Incorrect: Though helpful in the diagnosis of ulcerative colitis, barium enema is contraindicated in patients with suspected toxic megacolon due to the risk of perforation.  
✅ Plain abdominal x-ray:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Opioid analgesics:
Incorrect: Opioid analgesics are contraindicated in patients with suspected toxic megacolon as they further reduce the bowel motility, thereby increasing the risk of perforation. Antimotility agents (e.g. loperamide) and anticholinergic drugs should also be avoided.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man comes to the office with complaints of frequent loose stools and abdominal pain. He started having these symptoms a month ago, and they did not respond to over-the-counter antidiarrheals. He became concerned when he noticed an increase in urgency and a small amount of blood admixed with mucoid stools yesterday. Past medical history is noncontributory. He has not recently travelled outside the country. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows mild abdominal tenderness in the left lower quadrant. Colonoscopy shows erythematous rectal mucosa that is friable to touch, along with scattered ulcerations extending up to the distal part of sigmoid colon. The remainder of the colon and ileum are normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for the patient at this stage?
questions.solution:
This patient has recurrent episodes of diarrhea that has recently become bloody and abdominal pain. The colonoscopy findings of continuous rectal and sigmoid colon inflammation and ulceration, together with erythematous bowel walls and friable mucosa, are highly suggestive of ulcerative colitis (UC).

UC is an immune-mediated inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that causes recurring episodes of inflammation limited to the mucosal and submucosal layers of the colon. Clinically, it presents with recurrent episodes of small-volume bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. Patients may have systemic symptoms including fever, fatigue, and weight loss.

Treatment of UC depends on disease severity, how much of the colon is involved, and the frequency of disease relapse or flares. Mild-to-moderate UC is initially treated with a 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA) suppository or enema. Oral formulation of 5-ASA is added if the patient doesn’t respond to the topical treatment. Another alternative is the addition of oral glucocorticoid preparation, which also helps in alleviating the inflammation and in achieving remission. In severe cases unresponsive to these agents, anti-tumor necrosis factor agents (e.g. infliximab) can be tried.




Option Analysis

❌ Oral budesonide:
Incorrect: Budesonide is a glucocorticoid oral formulation which is usually employed in the treatment of mild-to-moderate UC that is unresponsive to oral and topical 5-ASA. It is one of the initial treatment modalities in the treatment of Crohn disease. In this patient, however, a trial of 5-ASA suppository should be tried first.
❌ Oral infliximab:
Incorrect: Biologic agents (e.g. infliximab) are usually considered as an initial therapy in patients with severe or fulminant UC who cannot tolerate glucocorticoids. These can also be considered in patients with mild-to-moderate Crohn disease. This patient with mild UC does not qualify for infliximab therapy.
✅ 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA) suppository:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Intravenous methylprednisolone:
Incorrect: Intravenous methylprednisolone is the cornerstone of treatment of acute severe (fulminant) UC. It is also used in the management of IBD-related toxic megacolon. It is not preferred for long term management of mild UC and may cause unwanted side effects (e.g., Cushing syndrome, osteoporosis).
❌ Intravenous cyclosporine:
Incorrect: Cyclosporine is an anti-metabolite commonly used in patients with renal transplantation. It is reserved for the management of acute severe UC who fail to improve within three to five days of intravenous glucocorticoids.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man is brought in by his roommate to the emergency department with acute-onset mental status changes. The roommate states the patient rarely eats whole meals and typically only eats canned soups. He has been drinking 7-8 beers daily for the past 20 years. He occasionally uses cocaine and injectable heroin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg. He is confused and disoriented to time, place and person. Pupils are equal and reactive, and horizontal nystagmus is elicited on lateral gaze. Lateral gaze is restricted on both sides. Fundoscopy is normal. Motor strength is 3/5 in the lower limbs and 5/5 in the upper limbs bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes are absent at the ankles bilaterally. Romberg sign is negative. Finger-to-nose and heel-to-shin testing are normal. The patient’s gait is wide-based. There is no nuchal rigidity on examination. Rapid glucose test is 60 mg/dL. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient has symptoms of confusion, horizontal nystagmus, lateral gaze restriction, and ataxia; in conjunction with his history of chronic alcohol intake and chronic malnutrition, he most likely has Wernicke encephalopathy (WE) secondary to chronic alcohol intake.

WE is an acute neurological condition resulting from thiamine deficiency, and it is characterized by a clinical triad of ophthalmoparesis with nystagmus, ataxia, and confusion. Alcohol inhibits conversion of thiamine to its active form, and it inhibits the active transport of thiamine at the level of intestinal absorption. Alcohol can also impair storage forms of thiamine by inducing liver cirrhosis. Thiamine is a crucial cofactor involved in the function of various enzymes, including:

  •  pyruvate dehydrogenase, which is crucial in forming acetyl-CoA, which is then used in the citric acid cycle (TCA) 
  •  alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, which is used in the citric acid cycle 
In the absence of thiamine, these crucial biochemical processes are impaired, resulting in an accumulation of lactate and pyruvate, which can cause metabolic imbalances, leading to neurologic complications including neuronal cell death.



In a patient who presents with signs and symptoms of thiamine deficiency, thiamine infusion is administered first. With a high glucose intake, the requirement for thiamine increases in order to assist in the breakdown of glucose through the Krebs cycle, and thus a glucose infusion can induce or worsen WE. If glucose is administered prior to thiamine replacement, it would be converted to lactic acid, and as a result, it would precipitate WE in susceptible populations such as those with chronic alcohol use and malnourished patients (e.g. anorexia nervosa).

Option Analysis

❌ Naloxone:
Incorrect: Typical features of opioid overdose include respiratory depression, miotic pupils and depressed level of consciousness. Although this patient has a history of substance abuse, his vitals are stable, and pupils are equal and reactive. Naloxone is unlikely to reverse this patient’s current symptoms.
❌ Emergent thrombolytic therapy :
Incorrect: Acute ischemic stroke generally presents with focal neurologic findings (hemiplegia, hemiparesis, slurred speech) and is generally seen in the presence of risk factors such as hypertension, coagulopathy, or atrial fibrillation. In the absence of risk factors or neurological findings that would indicate an ischemic stroke, this diagnosis is unlikely. Instead, the neurological findings in this patient, accompanied by ophthalmoplegia and the likely malnutrition, indicate a thiamine deficiency.  
❌ Empiric antibiotics :
Incorrect: Sepsis can cause an altered mental state. However, the absence of a source of infection and the normal vital signs (e.g., afebrile and normotensive) make this diagnosis unlikely. Furthermore, this patient’s acute confusion, ophthalmoplegia (lateral gaze palsy), nystagmus, and ataxia indicate an alternative diagnosis.
❌ Dextrose-containing solution:
Incorrect: In a patient with risk factors for thiamine deficiency, thiamine replacement must precede glucose replacement therapy because the glucose oxidation can decrease thiamine levels, thereby exacerbating the neurological symptoms of Wernicke encephalopathy.
✅ Thiamine infusion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 65-year old man with a history of severe depression is brought to the emergency department by his partner after she found him unconscious on the bathroom floor. The patient’s partner suspects the patient may have attempted suicide, as she found empty pill bottles next to him. Temperature is 38.1 C° (100.5 F°), pulse is 110/minute, and blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg. On physical examination, the pupils are dilated, his skin appears flushed, and bowel sounds are decreased. ECG is shown below. During the evaluation, the patient has a generalized tonic-clonic seizure, which terminates with administration of lorazepam. Which of the following interventions is most appropriate given this patient’s clinical presentation?


Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a new onset seizure, anticholinergic findings (e.g., flushed skin, mydriasis, urinary retention), and alpha-1 blockade side effects (hypotension). In addition, the ECG strip demonstrates QRS widening. Together, this constellation of findings is consistent with tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) overdose and warrants immediate treatment.

TCAs have a narrow therapeutic-index, and overdose can be lethal, primarily owing to cardiotoxicity.  An ECG must be obtained in all patients with suspected TCA toxicity, and it will typically demonstrate QRS widening (>100msec) due to blockage of fast Na channels in cardiac myocytes.

Sodium bicarbonate is indicated in the treatment of TCA overdose in patients who have seizures, hypotension, or QRS widening (>100msec). Administration of sodium bicarbonate protects against arrhythmia generation, improves the blood pressure, and increases the seizure threshold. Activated charcoal can be administered within two hours following TCA ingestion; however, this treatment can only be given with a secure airway, to protect against aspiration.

The effects of sodium bicarbonate in treating TCA toxicity are due to two primary mechanisms:

  1.  Increasing serum pH: TCAs are weak bases, and an acidic environment facilitates the formation of the ionized form of TCA, thus potentiating its toxic effects. By increasing the serum pH, less of the ionized form of TCA will be present, thus decreasing the active form of TCAs. 
  2.  Increasing serum sodium: TCA inhibits the influx of sodium into the cardiac myocytes and conductive systems in phase 0 of the action potential, thus slowing the depolarization of myocardial cells and prolonging the QRS complex. Providing additional sodium in the extracellular space can potentially reverse the inhibition of fast sodium channels.
PS: If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.  

Option Analysis

✅ Sodium bicarbonate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Glucagon:
Incorrect: Glucagon is used in the treatment of beta blocker and calcium channel blocker overdose. It has no role in the treatment of tricyclic antidepressant toxicity.
❌ Atropine:
Incorrect: Atropine is an anticholinergic medication used in the treatment of cholinergic toxicity. Administration of this medication may mitigate the anticholinergic effects of tricyclic antidepressants; however, it has no role in mitigating the lethal cardiovascular toxicity of this medication class.
❌ Supportive care:
Incorrect: This patient presents with features consistent with tricyclic antidepressant overdose. The ECG shows a wide QRS complex, which mandates treatment with sodium bicarbonate.
❌ N-acetylcysteine:
Incorrect: N-acetylcysteine is indicated for treatment of acetaminophen toxicity, not tricyclic antidepressant overdose.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man is being evaluated for hematuria following urinary catheterization. The patient was hospitalized four days ago with severe chest pain and left lower limb swelling, and he was subsequently diagnosed with venous thromboembolism. The patient was admitted to the floor and initiated on heparin anticoagulation therapy. Today, the nursing staff noted bright red blood following urinary catheterization. The patient’s past medical history includes chronic kidney disease, for which he receives dialysis on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday. The patient’s blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg, heart rate is 100/minute, and respirations are 18/minute. The patient’s serum analysis is demonstrated below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Hemoglobin   9 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  45% 
 Platelet count  190,000/mm3 
 Leukocyte count  8,000/mm3 
 International normalized ratio (INR)  1.6 
 Activated partial thromboplastin time (PTT)   114 seconds
questions.solution:
This patient on heparin therapy for venous thromboembolism has developed hematuria, indicative of  supratherapeutic anticoagulation. Patients who develop excessive bleeding while taking heparin are provided with protamine sulfate--a heparin reversal agent.






Heparin exerts its anticoagulant effect by activating antithrombin III, which then inhibits factor X and factor II, thereby preventing clot formation. Excessive anticoagulation with heparin can be life-threatening and lead to severe bleeding. Therefore, patients taking heparin are monitored by measuring the  activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT).

Protamine sulfate is the first-line treatment for reversal of heparin overdose or toxicity. This negatively charged molecule binds to positively charged heparin molecules and prevents their action. Protamine sulfate can reverse the effects of heparin within seconds of administration.

Option Analysis

✅ Administration of protamine sulfate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Administration of Vitamin K:
Incorrect: Vitamin K is used to reverse the anticoagulant effects of warfarin, which is not typically used for the treatment of acute venous thromboembolism. Moreover, administration of vitamin K is unlikely to be of any acute clinical benefit.
❌ Administration of prothrombin complex concentrate:
Incorrect: Prothrombin complex concentrate is used for immediate reversal of warfarin anticoagulant effects in cases of life-threatening bleeding. It is not first-line for heparin reversal.
❌ Administration of fresh frozen plasma:
Incorrect: Like prothrombin complex concentrate, fresh frozen plasma is also used to immediately reverse the anticoagulant effects of warfarin in actively bleeding patients. It is not the first-line medication to use for heparin reversal.
❌ Administration of andexanet alfa:
Incorrect: Andexanet alfa is used to reverse the anticoagulant effects of direct factor Xa inhibitors (e.g., apixaban, rivaroxaban). Direct factor Xa inhibitors are not used in patients with chronic kidney disease, due to increased risk of bleeding.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of a painful skin rash. The patient had a mole removed from the tip of his nose last week. He broke out in a painful facial rash over the weekend and has subsequently been experiencing fevers and chills. Past medical history is notable for poorly controlled type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, lymphedema, and a left kidney transplant for which he is on tacrolimus. The patient develops hives when he takes penicillin. At arrival, temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 161/82 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for the following finding:



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a facial rash that is consistent with erysipelas. Erysipelas can be treated using a penicillin or second or third generation cephalosporin. Given the patient has signs of systemic infection (e.g., fevers, chills), is taking an immunosuppressive drug, and has a penicillin allergy, intravenous cefazolin would be the most appropriate treatment option.

Erysipelas is an infection of the upper dermis and superficial lymphatics within the skin. It is characterized clinically by well-defined, raised demarcations of erythema. The infection is most commonly found on the lower extremities and face, with Streptococcus pyogenes being the culprit in the overwhelming majority of cases. Risk factors for developing erysipelas include breaks in the skin, poorly controlled diabetes, lymphedema, and an immunocompromised state.

Treatment of erysipelas involves administering antibiotics that provide coverage for Streptococcus pyogenes; typically an oral penicillin is used. In patients with signs of systemic infection or immunocompromised state, an intravenous penicillin or cephalosporin should be administered instead.



Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous cefazolin:
Correct: See main explanation
❌ Oral amoxicillin:
Incorrect: Oral amoxicillin is an appropriate treatment for patients without findings of systemic infection or immunosuppression. In contrast, this patient has signs of systemic infection (e.g., fever, chills) and is taking the immunosuppressant drug tacrolimus. Furthermore, this patient has an allergy to medications in the penicillin family.
❌ Intravenous vancomycin:
Incorrect: Erysipelas is rarely due to methicillin resistant strains of Staphylococcus aureus. While intravenous vancomycin would likely cover Streptococcus pyogenes, which is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s erysipelas, the antibiotic is too broad for this patient’s clinical condition.
❌ Topical mupirocin:
Incorrect: Topical mupirocin is the treatment for localized impetigo, which is characterized by golden crusted lesions. In contrast, erysipelas requires treatment with systemic antibiotics.
❌ Oral acyclovir:
Incorrect: Acyclovir is the treatment of choice for patients presenting with herpes simplex or herpes zoster. This patient has erysipelas, which is a bacterial skin infection, and acyclovir would be ineffective in treating the condition.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the emergency room for evaluation of palpitations. An electrocardiogram is performed and demonstrates sinus tachycardia. A carotid sinus massage is completed, and the patient’s heart rate decreases from 180/min to 100/min. Which of the following is true regarding the response seen in this patient?

choices.text: Afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, while efferent impulses (the response) are transmitted via the vagus nerve.
Afferent signals from the carotid body and efferent signals to the aortic arch baroreceptors are transmitted via the vagus nerve.
Afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the vagus nerve, while the efferent impulses (the response) are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve.
Afferent signals from the carotid body and efferent signals (the response) are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve.
Afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, while the efferent impulses (the response) are transmitted via the accessory nerve.

questions.solution:
Baroreceptors are sensory receptors that detect changes in blood pressure and can modulate autonomic control of the heart and blood vessels through sympathetic and parasympathetic output. Baroreceptors are located within the carotid sinus and aortic arch. The glossopharyngeal nerve carries afferent impulses from the carotid sinus, whereas the vagus nerve carries afferent signals from the aortic arch. Signals from these receptors are relayed to the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) in the medulla. Autonomic output from the NTS is distributed via parasympathetic fibers of the vagus nerve or the sympathetic nervous system, depending on whether the body is trying to increase or decrease blood pressure.  



Baroreceptors in the carotid sinus and aortic arch are activated and send afferent impulses to the NTS. Efferent sympathetic fibers then relay signals from the NTS to the rest of the body, causing alterations in vasoconstriction, heart rate, and cardiac contractility. For instance, in cases of hypotension, there is diminished arterial stretch, which is noted by the baroreceptors, prompting a sympathetic response.  

In contrast, hypertension causes increased stretching of the arterial walls and baroreceptors. Signals are then forwarded to the NTS. Efferent parasympathetic output is relayed by the vagus nerve to the heart, resulting in bradycardia.  

Carotid sinus massage is a maneuver that can diagnose and treat supraventricular tachycardias such as atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia (AVRT) and AV nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT). Pressure on the carotid sinus stretches the carotid sinus and baroreceptor activation. These changes increase parasympathetic output via the vagus nerve, slowing sinus node impulse formation and lengthening the AV node refractory period. These changes can potentially terminate an abnormal rhythm.  



Option Analysis

✅ Afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, while efferent impulses (the response) are transmitted via the vagus nerve.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Afferent signals from the carotid body and efferent signals to the aortic arch baroreceptors are transmitted via the vagus nerve.:
Incorrect: This patient demonstrated the baroreceptor reflex, in which the glossopharyngeal nerve transmits afferent information from the carotid body to the nucleus tractus solitarius. The vagus nerve then transmits efferent signals from the nucleus tractus solitarius to the aortic arch baroreceptors.  
❌ Afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the vagus nerve, while the efferent impulses (the response) are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve.:
Incorrect: This patient demonstrated the baroreceptor reflex, in which afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, and subsequent efferent signals (the response) to the aortic arch baroreceptors are transmitted via the vagus nerve.  
❌ Afferent signals from the carotid body and efferent signals (the response) are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve. :
Incorrect: In the baroreceptor reflex, efferent signals from the nucleus tractus solitarius are transmitted to the heart via the vagus nerve, not the glossopharyngeal nerve.  
❌ Afferent signals from the carotid body are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, while the efferent impulses (the response) are transmitted via the accessory nerve.    :
Incorrect: The accessory nerve (cranial nerve XI) is a pure motor nerve with no parasympathetic input. In contrast, the vagus nerve mediates the efferent response in the baroreceptor reflex.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the office to establish routine healthcare. He recently moved to California to live with his daughter after the death of his spouse. The patient has no active complaints. Past medical history is significant for hemorrhoids. Family history is significant for diabetes mellitus in his father and prostate cancer in his paternal grandfather. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years; he does not drink alcohol. Vitals are within normal limits. Digital rectal examination shows irregular nodularity on the posterior prostate. The rest of the examination is normal. Serum prostate specific antigen is 7 ng/mL. Medical recods show that it was 4.5 ng/mL a year ago. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic study to obtain at this time?
questions.solution:
This patient’s findings of a family history of prostate cancer, an elevated prostate specific antigen (PSA) and irregular nodularity on digital rectal examination (DRE) raises concern for a possible development of prostate adenocarcinoma.   

Since this patient has a life expectancy of more than 10 years, these findings warrant further evaluation with ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy. Biopsy findings of glandular crowding (lacking branching and papillary infoldings) with nuclear atypia (enlarged nuclei, prominent nucleoli and dark cytoplasm) is suggestive of the diagnosis.  


Histological specimen showing acinar type adenocarcinoma obtained by core needle prostate biopsy
Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

In addition to PSA levels, grading and staging of prostate adenocarcinoma are excellent prognostic predictors. Gleason score is used for grading and is based on glandular patterns of differentiation, with grade 1 being well-differentiated representing most favorable prognosis and grade 5 with no glandular differentiation representing poor prognosis. Staging is done using the TNM system, which is based on information from biopsy, DRE and imaging studies.  



Option Analysis

❌ Expressed prostatic secretions culture:
Incorrect: Expressed prostatic secretions culture is usually performed in suspected prostatitis and to differentiate between bacterial and abacterial prostatitis. This DRE is indicative of a malignancy.
✅ Ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ MRI spine:
Incorrect: This patient with irregular nodularity on DRE and an elevated serum PSA should initially undergo biopsy to confirm the diagnosis. MRI spine can be performed at a later stage based on biopsy findings to further assess the tumor burden and guide management plan.
❌ Obtain prostatic acid phosphatase levels:
Incorrect: Prostatic acid phosphatase is an enzyme found in the prostate and can sometimes be elevated in prostate cancer. However, it is nonspecific and is rarely used after the advent of PSA.
❌ Urinalysis:
Incorrect: Urinalysis is not indicated in an asymptomatic patient with normal vitals and DRE suggestive of a malignancy. Prostate biopsy is more appropriate at this time.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of severe pain in the right knee. She reports that it has been painful, warm, and red over the past day. She states that similar symptoms occurred two-years ago in her left toe, which resolved spontaneously without treatment. Past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Medications include pravastatin and hydrochlorothiazide. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 130/92 mmHg. Physical examination reveals swelling, erythema, and warmth of the right knee joint. It is tender to palpation with decreased active and passive range of motion. Arthrocentesis of the joint yields turbid fluid with a leukocyte count of 19,200/mm<sup>3</sup>. Gram stain is negative. Polarized light microscopy shows yellow, negatively birefringent crystals. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with acute onset, severe pain of the right knee, and arthrocentesis reveals yellow, negatively birefringent crystals. These findings are diagnostic of an acute gout attack.  

Acute gout attacks begin with urate crystals precipitating in joints, causing the release of prostaglandins by synoviocytes. These chemotactic mediators recruit neutrophils to migrate into the joint space and amplify the ongoing inflammation process. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), therefore, are pivotal in treating acute gout attacks. All NSAIDs (with the exception of aspirin) inhibit prostaglandin synthesis as well as inhibit urate crystal phagocytosis. In patients who are unable to tolerate NSAIDs (e.g., chronic kidney disease, gastrointestinal ulcers), intra-articular glucocorticoids and colchicine can be used as alternatives.

Option Analysis

✅ Reversible inhibition of cyclooxygenase enzymes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Irreversible inhibition of cyclooxygenase enzymes:
Incorrect: Aspirin causes irreversible inhibition of cyclooxygenase enzymes. This results in reduced synthesis of prostaglandins, which are involved in inflammation. However, aspirin should be avoided in gout treatment as it inhibits uric acid excretion, ultimately delaying the resolution of symptoms. 
❌ Inhibition of microtubule polymerization:
Incorrect: Colchicine prevents microtubule polymerization, which inhibits phagocytosis of urate crystals and subsequent leukocyte migration and activation. Although colchicine is useful in treating acute gout attacks, it can cause side effects including diarrhea and myopathy. As a result, colchicine is a 2nd line treatment option in patients unable to tolerate nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as those with chronic kidney disease or gastrointestinal ulcers.
❌ Inhibition of transcription factors :
Incorrect: Corticosteroids can inhibit transcription factors involved in the synthesis of inflammatory mediators, such as NF-kB. Although intra-articular corticosteroid injections are useful in treating gout attacks, the beneficial effects take several hours to manifest, since regulation of gene transcription is necessary. This property makes corticosteroids a less useful treatment for this patient’s acute symptoms.
❌ Inhibitor of xanthine oxidase:
Incorrect: Allopurinol and febuxostat are involved in the inhibition of xanthine oxidase, an enzyme that plays an integral role in purine catabolism. These medications are indicated in the treatment of chronic gout and hyperuricemia prophylaxis (e.g. tumor lysis syndrome). However, these medications would not be an appropriate treatment choice for this patient, who is presenting with an acute gout attack.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of joint pains in her arms and legs, which have been going on for the past three months. She is an avid tennis player, and the pain has been interfering with her practice. She has also been feeling more fatigued and experienced a loss of libido over this same time period. Her last menstrual period was 12 years ago. She recently traveled to Costa Rica with her partner where they ate local food. Vitals are within normal limits. Her BMI is 22 kg/m2. Physical examination shows diffuse tanning of her skin. Her skin is cool and dry. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the costal margin and is mildly tender to palpation. Laboratory studies are as follows:



After confirming the diagnosis, which of the following is the most appropriate therapy?
questions.solution:
This postmenopausal woman is presenting with arthralgias, hypothyroidism, bronze pigmentation, and elevated glucose levels. Her laboratory testing demonstrates an elevated serum iron and ferritin but reduced total iron binding capacity. In combination, these findings are suggestive of hereditary hemochromatosis (HH), which can be treated with iron chelators and intermittent phlebotomy.  

Hemochromatosis is characterized by a mutation in the HFE gene, which results in uncontrolled small bowel reabsorption of iron. Since accumulation of iron takes many years, women generally present after menopause because during the pre-menopausal years, menstrual bleeding helps slow down iron accumulation.  

Identifying and diagnosing HH early in the disease course is imperative because treatment is highly effective and can prevent many of the disease’s complications, which occur secondary to significant iron accumulation. Initial diagnostic tests include iron studies, which would demonstrate high serum iron, ferritin, and transferrin percent saturation. Further diagnostic studies include testing for common HFE mutations, especially in patients with a family history of HH. Treatment consists of reducing iron in the body with phlebotomy and iron chelators like deferasirox, deferoxamine, and deferiprone.  



Option Analysis

✅ Chelation therapy and intermittent phlebotomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Nucleoside analog therapy:
Incorrect: Nucleoside/nucleotide analogs (e.g., tenofovir, entecavir) are used in patients with chronic hepatitis B infection who have decompensated liver disease. Although this patient has hepatomegaly and right upper quadrant pain, her constellation of symptoms (e.g., arthralgias, hypothyroidism, bronze pigmentation) are not adequately explained by chronic hepatitis B alone.
❌ Metformin and weight reduction:
Incorrect: Metformin and weight reduction are the first-line treatments for diabetic patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). Although this patient has an elevated glucose level, her normal BMI and constellation of additional symptoms (e.g., bronze pigmentation, hypothyroidism, elevated ferritin) suggest hemochromatosis as the cause of her underlying liver disease, for which targeted therapy with chelation and phlebotomy is more appropriate.
❌ Anti-hepatitis A virus immunoglobulins:
Incorrect: Acute viral hepatitis caused by hepatitis A typically presents as fever, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, tender hepatomegaly, and jaundice. In patients already infected, supportive care is typically all that is required for a full recovery. In patients over the age of 40 who have been exposed and not vaccinated, anti-HAV immunoglobulins may be indicated.
❌ Supplementation of underproduced hormones:
Incorrect: Hypopituitarism can result in decreased endocrine function of various organs, such as the thyroid and adrenal glands. In some cases, it may be necessary to administer exogenous hormones to supplement the underproduced hormones. However, this patient’s symptoms are more consistent with those of hemochromatosis. Treating her underlying hemochromatosis with iron chelators and phlebotomy can potentially reverse her endocrine symptoms (e.g., fatigue, decreased libido) as well.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male comes to the physician complaining of severe abdominal pain, as well as bulky, foul-smelling stools, which have been ongoing for the past several weeks. The pain radiates to the back and is often relieved by leaning forward. He has lost 12-lb over the last 3 months. The patient has been drinking 6-8 beers everyday for the last 15 years. He does not consume tobacco or illicit substances. He has been hospitalized for severe epigastric abdominal pain multiple times in the last 10 years. His vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a diffusely tender abdomen. Fecal elastase is measured at 109 µg/g (normal ≥ 200 µg/g). Abdominal CT confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Pancreatic enzyme replacement and H2-receptor blocker
Surgical resection of the pancreatic head

questions.solution:
This patient has signs of malabsorption (e.g. bulky, foul-smelling stools) and chronic pancreatitis (e.g., recurring episodes of acute pancreatitis, abdominal pain relieved by leaning forward). These findings, in combination with his reduced fecal elastase level, are concerning for pancreatic insufficiency.   

 Pancreatic insufficiency often arises due to chronic pancreatitis or cystic fibrosis. Given that pancreatic enzymes are heavily involved in the digestion of fats and carbohydrates, patients with pancreatic dysfunction are at risk of malabsorption. Clinically, the condition can manifest with steatorrhea, weight loss, as well as abdominal bloating and distention.  

 One way to evaluate for pancreatic insufficiency is via the fecal elastase test. Elastase is an enzyme that is normally secreted by the pancreas and eventually is excreted in the stool. In patients with pancreatic insufficiency, such as this patient, fecal elastase levels will be reduced. Other tests include measuring serum trypsinogen, which is another enzyme secreted by the pancreas, and measuring bicarbonate levels in the duodenum after stimulation with the hormone secretin.  

Treatment involves providing oral supplementation of exocrine pancreatic enzymes and H2-receptor blockers (or proton pump inhibitors) to reduce inactivation of the enzymes by gastric acid.  



Option Analysis

✅ Pancreatic enzyme replacement and H2-receptor blocker:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Surgical resection of the pancreatic head:
Incorrect: A tumor at the head of the pancreas may obstruct pancreatic enzyme outflow, resulting in abdominal pain, weight loss, and steatorrhea. Patients may also develop jaundice secondary to biliary tract obstruction. However, this patient has had episodes of abdominal pain for 10 years, which makes pancreatic cancer unlikely given the disease’s aggressive nature and poor prognosis. The average 5-year survival rate is around 10%.
❌ Adherence to a gluten-free diet:
Incorrect: Celiac disease can manifest with steatorrhea and malabsorption, but commonly presents earlier in life. This patient’s history of chronic alcohol use and recurrent episodes of acute pancreatitis makes chronic pancreatitis a more likely explanation for his abdominal pain and steatorrhea.
❌ Restriction of dairy product intake:
Incorrect: Patients with lactose intolerance may need to restrict the amount of dairy products they consume. Lactose intolerance usually presents with bloating and excessive flatulence in adults. Diarrhea may be present, but it is much more common in children and adolescents. However, this patient’s history (e.g., chronic alcohol use, recurrent episodes of acute pancreatitis) and laboratory findings (e.g. reduced fecal elastase) is more concerning for chronic pancreatitis and associated steatorrhea. 
❌ Antibiotic therapy:
Incorrect: Antibiotic therapy can be curative in patients with small intestinal bacterial overgrowth, tropical sprue, or Whipple disease. Although these conditions may also cause diarrhea and malabsorption, this patient’s presentation (e.g., abdominal pain improved by leaning forward) and reduced fecal elastase level are more likely due to chronic pancreatitis.
❌ Mesalamine and budesonide:
Incorrect: Mesalamine and corticosteroids are useful in managing acute episodes of Crohn disease. Crohn disease typically causes non-bloody, chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and malabsorption. Although these features are present in this patient, the patient’s abnormal fecal elastase level does not correlate with this diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 61 year-old man presents to his outpatient provider’s office for a health maintenance visit. Apart from mild lower back and right knee pain that worsens with movement and improves with ibuprofen, the patient reports feeling well. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. His body-mass index (BMI) is 31 kg/m2. Physical exam reveals limited range of motion and crepitus in the right knee. There is no tenderness to palpation along the patient’s spine. Laboratory testing results are as follows:
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  15.1 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  4800/mm3 
 Creatinine  0.9 mg/dL 
 Calcium  9.1 mg/dL 
 Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)  17 U/L 
 Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)  12 U/L 

Plasma protein electrophoresis reveals an elevated monoclonal immunoglobulin count. In addition to informing the patient of these findings, which of the following is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Induction chemotherapy with a three-drug regimen
Encourage patient follow-up in 6 months for additional laboratory testing

questions.solution:
This patient has monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS), a premalignant clonal plasma cell disorder. The condition is asymptomatic. Unlike multiple myeloma (MM), MGUS does not cause the CRAB symptoms (hyperCalcemia, Renal insufficiency, Anemia, and Bone lesions). While the patient endorses back and knee pain, the patient’s medical history in combination with physical exam findings of limited range of motion and crepitus suggests osteoarthritis as the most likely explanation. If the patient were to report pain at rest or tenderness to palpation, then we would be far more concerned about lytic lesions that are observed in MM.  

The work-up includes obtaining a complete blood count, peripheral smear (rouleaux formation is not typically seen), serum protein electrophoresis, and bone marrow biopsy. A diagnosis of MGUS can be made if: 
  1.  The patient is asymptomatic 
  2.  Serum protein electrophoresis demonstrates elevated immunoglobulin levels (but IgM M-protein <3 g/dL) 
  3.  Bone marrow biopsy reveals less than 10% plasma cells.  
While MGUS is asymptomatic, it has a 1% per year risk of progression to multiple myeloma. Hence, patients should be followed-up every 6 months for additional laboratory testing including protein electrophoresis, CBC, creatinine level, and calcium level. A bone marrow biopsy should only be repeated if the patient has signs of disease progression.

Option Analysis

❌ Induction chemotherapy with a three-drug regimen :
Incorrect: Induction chemotherapy with a three drug regimen (e.g. bortezomib, lenalidomide, and dexamethasone [VRd]) is the initial treatment approach in patients with symptomatic multiple myeloma. This patient is asymptomatic. The isolated elevation of serum immunoglobulins raises concern for MGUS, which requires close surveillance. 
❌ Referral for total knee arthroplasty :
Incorrect: This surgery can be used to treat cases of severe osteoarthritis that have failed medical management. In contrast, the patient’s knee pain is minimal and well-managed with ibuprofen. Moreover, the patient’s elevated serum immunoglobulin levels raise concerns for MGUS, which has a 1% per year risk of progressing into multiple myeloma and should be addressed. 
❌ Autologous hematopoietic cell transplantation :
Incorrect: Autologous hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) after induction chemotherapy is the preferred treatment modality for patients with symptomatic multiple myeloma (not MGUS). When compared with chemotherapy alone, autologous HCT prolongs survival and is associated with low non-relapse mortality. This patient, being completely asymptomatic, most likely has MGUS. 
✅ Encourage patient follow-up in 6 months for additional laboratory testing :
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Initiation of plasmapheresis :
Incorrect: Plasmapheresis is used in the management of Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia, which may present with fatigue and symptoms secondary to increased blood viscosity (e.g., headaches, vision impairment, leg pain). In contrast, this patient has none of these symptoms.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office because of persistent fevers, fatigue, loss of appetite, and transient chest pain for the past 2 months. He has also unintentionally lost 7 kg (15 lb) over the same time period. His temperature is 38.8°C (102°F), pulse is 87/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/78 mm Hg. Physical examination is non-contributory. Serial blood cultures grow Streptococcus gallolyticus. Echocardiogram reveals vegetations on the mitral valve. Once the patient is stabilized and treated for his bacteremia, which of the following additional diagnostic tests should be performed?
questions.solution:
This patient has a history of low-grade fevers, weight loss, and vegetations seen on the mitral valve. These findings, along with positive blood cultures growing Streptococcus gallolyticus (also termed Streptococcus bovis biotype I), are suggestive of infective endocarditis and potentially an underlying gastrointestinal malignancy.       
Streptococcus bovis (S. bovis) is a bacteria commonly found in the human gastrointestinal tract, but its presence in the bloodstream is strongly associated with colorectal cancer. However, not all genospecies are equally related to the disease. A recent meta-analysis on the association between S. bovis biotypes and colonic adenomas/carcinomas revealed that patients with S. bovis biotype I bacteremia had a greater risk of having colorectal cancer than those with S. bovis biotype II bacteremia.    

The main site of entry for S. bovis into the bloodstream is the GI tract. Thus, given the association between the pathogen and colorectal cancer, patients should undergo colonoscopy for evaluation of an underlying occult malignancy.

Option Analysis

✅ Colonoscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Perform upper gastrointestinal tract endoscopy :
Incorrect: The original blood cultures grew Streptococcus bovis, a bacteria common to the gastrointestinal tract. The presence of S. bovis in the bloodstream should raise concerns for underlying colon cancer, which can be evaluated via colonoscopy, not upper gastrointestinal tract endoscopy. 
❌ Chest CT scan:
Incorrect: Streptococcus bovis is a common bacteria in the human gastrointestinal tract. Therefore, further diagnostic work-up of the gastrointestinal tract should be performed. Performing a CT scan of the chest would not be helpful and would do little to guide this patient’s care. 
❌ Cystoscopy:
Incorrect: The genitourinary tract is commonly colonized by Enterococcal species. Therefore, patients who have recently undergone a cystoscopy may be at a higher risk of enterococcal endocarditis. However, performing a cystoscopy is unlikely to reveal an underlying condition that caused this patient’s initial bacteremia. 
❌ Abdominal CT scan:
Incorrect: Streptococcus bovis is a common bacteria in the human gastrointestinal tract. Although an underlying gastrointestinal malignancy is likely in this patient, a different diagnostic modality should be used.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to a family medicine clinic with a chief complaint of chronic fatigue. He feels sleepy and tired throughout the day, and he has been drinking increasing amounts of coffee to compensate. He does not have any shortness of breath at rest or dyspnea on exertion. The patient does not take any medications. He formerly smoked and quit six years ago. Temperature is 99.0°F, blood pressure is 158/110 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a BMI of 32 kg/m^2 and a large, supple neck. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the diagnosis of this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of obesity presents for evaluation of fatigue. His physical examination demonstrates a large supple neck, which can commonly precipitate obstructive sleep apnea. This condition is best diagnosed with a formal polysomnography sleep study.

Sleep apnea is characterized by repeated cessation of breathing during sleep, which often results in a feeling of tiredness throughout the day--regardless of the duration or quality of sleep. Complications of sleep apnea include fatigue, hypertension, and pulmonary hypertension.

There are two subtypes of sleep apnea: obstructive sleep apnea and central sleep apnea. Obstructive sleep apnea occurs due to physical obstruction of the airway during sleep and is often associated with obesity or an obstructive lesion (e.g. a large neck). Central sleep apnea involves decreased respiratory drive, leading to low ventilatory effort during sleep. To differentiate between obstructive and central sleep apnea, in-laboratory polysomnography can reveal Cheyne-Stokes breathing, which is a hallmark of central sleep apnea. Obstructive sleep apnea, in contrast, is characterized by fifteen obstructive episodes per hour or five apneic episodes per hour with daytime sleepiness.    

Option Analysis

✅ Polysomnography:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Spirometry:
Incorrect: Spirometry is not used to diagnose sleep apnea as it does not provide data on repeated cessation of breathing over time, as polysomnography does.
❌ Chest-x ray:
Incorrect: A chest x-ray may demonstrate evidence of COPD; however, this patient has a normal oxygen saturation and is outside of the age range of typical onset for this condition.
❌ TSH level:
Incorrect: Hypothyroidism can often manifest with chronic fatigue; however, it is less likely in this patient without other findings of hypothyroidism including cold sensitivity, dry skin, or new unexplained weight gain.
❌ Cosyntropin stimulation test :
Incorrect: A cosyntropin stimulation test, or ACTH stimulation test, is utilized for the diagnosis of Addison disease. While primary adrenal insufficiency can present with fatigue, it also presents with nausea, vomiting, darkening of the skin, and orthostasis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of tremor and ataxia. He is unable to walk without his partner’s assistance in the clinic. In addition, his partner reports “confusion” for the past two days. The patient has a history of severe bipolar disorder, for which he takes lithium. One month ago, he started using an over-the-counter medication for arthritic knee pain. He does not use tobacco or alcohol. Pale mucous membranes are noted on physical examination. Laboratory analysis demonstrates elevated serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen. In addition to intravenous fluids, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment of this patient's clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of bipolar disorder presents with features consistent with lithium toxicity, given his neurological symptoms (e.g., ataxia, confusion) and abnormal kidney function. Lithium is the first-line treatment for bipolar disorder; however, it has a very narrow therapeutic index. This medication is neither metabolized nor bound to serum proteins, and the elimination of lithium occurs primarily via the kidneys.

Acute lithium toxicity typically occurs after intentional ingestion (e.g. suicidal attempt), and it is clinically characterized by gastrointestinal manifestations (e.g., nausea, vomiting, diarrhea) followed by neurological manifestations (e.g. confusion). Chronic lithium toxicity, however, occurs with decreased elimination of lithium by the kidneys. The kidneys treat sodium and lithium similarly, and any change in  urinary sodium reabsorption (e.g., dehydration, renal insufficiency, excessive exercise) will also lead to increased reabsorption of lithium. Ultimately, this lowers serum lithium clearance and predisposes to overdose. In addition, some medications decrease renal clearance of lithium, including thiazide diuretics, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), and angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEI). This patient likely began taking an NSAID for his arthritic knee pain, resulting in decreased lithium clearance and subsequent toxicity.

Clinically, chronic toxicity is characterized by neurological manifestations including ataxia and tremor, in addition to renal insufficiency. In particular, lithium impairs the concentrating effects of the kidneys, inducing nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Patients often demonstrate varying degrees of consciousness, from mild confusion to delirium and coma. Treatment of lithium toxicity begins with administration of intravenous fluids, followed by hemodialysis for patients with severe toxicity or those with evidence of kidney insufficiency.

Option Analysis

✅ Hemodialysis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Activated charcoal:
Incorrect: Activated charcoal is not indicated in lithium toxicity, unless coingestion is suspected. Lithium does not bind well to charcoal.
❌ Supportive care:
Incorrect: This patient's kidney function indicates some level of renal insufficiency from lithium toxicity. In this setting, hemodialysis is indicated in order to clear lithium from circulation.
❌ Sodium bicarbonate:
Incorrect: Sodium bicarbonate is indicated in the treatment of tricyclic antidepressant and salicylate toxicity. It has no role in lithium overdose.
❌ Peritoneal dialysis:
Incorrect: Peritoneal dialysis should not supersede hemodialysis in patients with lithium toxicity. Should hemodialysis not be available, peritoneal dialysis can be considered.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents following two convulsive episodes. Over the last week, the patient has been refusing to eat and stays up all night working on his science fair project. Tonight, his parents found him violently shaking on the floor of his room.  The patient has depression and currently takes bupropion. His younger brother has ADHD, for which he takes methylphenidate. The patient drinks 4-5 beers with his friends on the weekend. Temperature is 100°F (37.7°C), pulse is 110 bpm, and blood pressure is 166/90 mmHg. The patient appears agitated and irritable. On physical examination, the pupils are mydriatic, and the patient appears diaphoretic. Oral mucosa is moist, and a small tongue laceration is present. The patient moves all four extremities to command and has 2+ deep tendon reflexes. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with suspicion for first-time seizures in the setting of a hyperadrenergic state. His clinical history is suspicious for sympathomimetic coingestion (likely his brother's methylphenidate), given his breakthrough seizure while on bupropion (this atypical antidepressant lowers the seizure threshold).

Amphetamine intoxication can cause neurological effects which include euphoria, impulsivity and delusions. In severe cases, it can cause seizures that occur typically within 24 hours of ingestion. Treatment for agitation, aggressive behaviour and seizures caused by amphetamine intoxication involves the administration of intravenous benzodiazepines (midazolam, diazepam or lorazepam). When high doses of benzodiazepines fail to control agitation or seizures, first generation neuroleptics like haloperidol can be used as second-line agents. Physical restraints should be avoided unless the patient poses a threat to himself or staff.  

Option Analysis

✅ Lorazepam:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Naloxone:
Incorrect: Naloxone is used to reverse opioid intoxication, not amphetamine overdose.
❌ Acetaminophen:
Incorrect: Febrile seizures are common in children between 2-5 years of age, but fever is an unlikely cause of seizure in this patient. Acetaminophen may be administered for treatment of this febrile seizure.
❌ Phentolamine:
Incorrect: Phentolamine may be administered for treatment of the noradrenergic state associated with amphetamine abuse; however, benzodiazepines are considered first line.
❌ Cyproheptadine:
Incorrect: Cyproheptadine, a serotonin antagonist, may be used to treat serotonin syndrome. This condition can cause psychomotor agitation and seizures; however, neurological examination typically demonstrates hypertonia and clonus.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to a week of reduced concentration at work and a persistent headache. The patient recently quit smoking cigarettes and is requesting medication to assist in her abstinence. The patient has a history of major depressive disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, gastroesophageal reflux disease and allergic rhinitis. Her current medication regimen includes pantoprazole and over-the-counter nasal decongestants. She smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for ten years. The patient appears irritable. Temperature is 98 °F (36.6 °C), pulse is 96 bpm, and blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg. Administration of which of the following medications is the best next step of management in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with classic features of nicotine withdrawal including a history of chronic tobacco use and recent cessation, dysphoria, increased appetite, hypersomnia, poor concentration and weight gain. Nicotine is a potent psychoactive stimulant that acts as a ganglionic and central nervous system stimulant. Once a patient with chronic tobacco use abstains from smoking, symptoms of nicotine withdrawal arise within as little as several hours. Symptoms include weight gain, dysphoria, hypersomnia, increased appetite, poor concentration and a craving for tobacco.

Management of smoking cessation is most effective when it involves the combination of both behavioral and pharmacological interventions. Recommended first-line pharmacologic therapy includes varenicline or a combination of two nicotine replacement therapies. Nicotine replacement therapy in the form of nicotine gum, patches, lozenges or nasal spray have been found to be effective alternative therapies in smoking cessation. Varencicline is a nicotinic acetylcholine receptor partial agonist that is a first-line agent used for smoking cessation. The atypical antidepressant bupropion is also commonly used as a pharmacological agent for smoking cessation--particularly in patients with a history of major depressive disorder. This medication should be avoided in patients with a history or risk factors for developing seizures.  

Option Analysis

✅ Varenicline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Risperidone:
Incorrect: Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic agent that acts as a dopamine antagonist. This medication is used in the treatment of schizophrenia, not for smoking cessation.
❌ Buspirone:
Incorrect: Buspirone stimulates serotonin receptors and is used in the treatment of generalized anxiety disorder. It is not used in the treatment of nicotine withdrawal syndrome and smoking cessation.
❌ Phenelzine:
Incorrect: Phenelzine is a monoamine oxidase inhibitor that can be used in the management of treatment resistant depression and atypical depression.
❌ Mirtazapine:
Incorrect: Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant--it is not indicated for the treatment of nicotine withdrawal syndrome and smoking cessation.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to his primary care provider for evaluation of vision changes. The patient recalls, “Whenever I try to read the newspaper, the words become blurry, and it has been getting worse over the past few years.” He has been able to better visualize text by holding objects farther away. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia, for which he takes amlodipine and atorvastatin daily. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 148/83 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. The patient is asked to read letters off a Snellen chart, and visual acuity is measured to be 20/25 bilaterally. Which of the following will be most effective in treating this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This older patient presents with difficulty focusing on near objects, and his symptoms have been progressively worsening. He likely has presbyopia, which can be treated with magnifying reading glasses.

Presbyopia is an age-related ocular condition that results in difficulty focusing on near objects. In contrast to hyperopia (far-sightedness), presbyopia typically presents in patients who are over 40 years of age. The condition develops because as humans age, there are changes in the lens’s curvature, a decline in lens elasticity, and a decrease in ciliary muscle strength. Together, these factors make it difficult for the lens to become rounded and focus on near objects.

Treatment for presbyopia involves application of magnifying reading glasses.



Option Analysis

✅ Magnifying reading lenses:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Convex lens:
Incorrect: Convex lenses are used to correct for hyperopia (farsightedness), which manifests with difficulty seeing near objects such as books, newspapers, and computer screens. Although this patient has difficulty reading the newspaper, his age makes presbyopia a more likely cause of his symptoms.
❌ Cylindrical lens:
Incorrect: Patients with astigmatism will have difficulty seeing both near and far objects. The condition can be corrected with cylindrical lenses. In contrast, this elderly patient has difficulty seeing near objects, which is more concerning for presbyopia.
❌ Concave lens:
Incorrect: Concave lenses are used to treat myopia (nearsightedness). The condition manifests with difficulty seeing far objects, but not near objects.
❌ Laser iridotomy:
Incorrect: Laser iridotomy can be used to treat acute closed-angle glaucoma, which often presents with severe eye pain, eye redness, and a dilated pupil. In contrast, laser iridotomy is not used to treat presbyopia.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man comes to the office because of a 1-day history of fever, headache, and bilateral periorbital and mid-facial swelling. The day prior to the onset of the symptoms, the patient had attempted to burst a furuncle in the inner margin of his right nostril. His past medical history is noncontributory, and he does not take any medications. He had last traveled to India 4 months ago. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.5°F), pulse is 66/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 124/72 mmHg. Physical examination shows marked facial and periorbital swelling with bilateral blepharoptosis, chemosis, and proptosis. On fundoscopy, there is no evidence of optic disc swelling. The patient has a full range of eye movements but complains of pain with eye movement. A high-resolution orbital CT with contrast demonstrates bilateral septic cavernous sinus thrombosis. Occlusion of which of the following veins is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, headache, and facial swelling following an attempt to burst a nasal furuncle. In combination with CT scan findings, this clinical presentation is suggestive of cavernous sinus thrombosis.  

The cavernous sinus communicates with the facial vein via the superior ophthalmic vein. The facial vein communicates with the pterygoid venous plexus via the deep facial and inferior ophthalmic veins. Because of these connections and the absence of valves in the facial veins (blood may pass in either direction), an infection of the face may spread to the cavernous sinus and pterygoid venous plexus.

Cavernous sinus thrombosis usually results from infections of the orbit, nasal sinuses, and the superior part of the face that drains into the superior ophthalmic veins. This area is described as the danger triangle (the triangular area from the upper lip to the bridge of the nose is considered the danger triangle of the face).  Infection of the facial veins that may spread to the dural venous sinuses can result from lacerations of the nose or be initiated by squeezing pustules (pimples) on the side of the nose and upper lip.

 


Option Analysis

❌ Supratrochlear vein :
Incorrect: The supratrochlear vein drains the anterior part of the scalp and forehead, where it communicates with the frontal branch of the superficial temporal vein, its contralateral partner, and the supraorbital vein. It does not communicate with the facial veins or the cavernous sinuses. 
✅ Superior ophthalmic vein:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Superficial temporal vein :
Incorrect: The superficial temporal vein drains the side of the scalp, superficial aspect of the temporal muscle, and external ear. It begins from a widespread plexus of veins on the side of the scalp and along the zygomatic arch and joins the maxillary vein posterior to the neck of the mandible to form the retromandibular vein. It does not communicate with the facial veins or the cavernous sinuses. 
❌ Supraorbital vein:
Incorrect: The supraorbital vein drains the anterior part of the scalp and forehead. It begins in the forehead by anastomosing with the frontal tributary of the superficial temporal vein and terminates as the angular vein at the root of the nose. It does not directly communicate with the facial veins or the cavernous sinuses. 
❌ Deep facial vein:
Incorrect: The deep facial vein drains the infratemporal fossa (most areas supplied by the maxillary artery). It originates at the pterygoid venous plexus and terminates by entering the posterior aspect of the facial vein.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department to evaluate shortness of breath. The parent is at the bedside and states, “I saw him lying on his right side putting plastic beads in his mouth. I think he swallowed one of them.” The patient is otherwise healthy, and his vaccinations are up to date. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 95/50 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 95% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is intermittently tachypneic. Faint stridor is present on pulmonary auscultation. The foreign body was most likely aspirated into which anatomic lung region?
questions.solution:
This patient presents after an aspiration event while in the right lateral decubitus position. Of the anatomic sites listed above, the most likely aspiration area is the dependent region of the right upper lobe.   

Aspiration of foreign bodies, vomitus, or oral secretions is a common event. The aspiration site can be predicted based on the patient’s position when the aspiration event occurs. The right main bronchus is wider, shorter, and has a more vertical trajectory than the left mainstem bronchus. As a result, aspirated foreign bodies are more likely to enter and lodge in the right bronchus or one of its branches.  

In addition to this anatomic preference, aspirated foreign bodies follow gravity, resulting in foreign bodies in the dependent portions of the lung. In the supine position, the dependent lung segments are the posterior segments of the upper lobes and superior segments of the lower lobes. In contrast, individuals in an upright position will most likely aspirate into the basilar segments of the right lower lobe. Finally, the aspirate usually enters the right upper lobe when lying on the right side.   

Option Analysis

✅ Right upper lobe:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Right lower lobe :
Incorrect: Aspiration in the upright position is likely to result in the foreign object being lodged in the right lower lobe, not the upper lobes. However, this patient aspirated while in a right lateral decubitus position.
❌ Left lower lobe:
Incorrect: Aspiration is always less likely to occur in the left lower lobe because the right main bronchus is wider, shorter, and has a more vertical trajectory. In addition, this patient aspirated while in a right lateral decubitus position, making the right upper lobe the most likely site of aspiration.
❌ Right middle lobe :
Incorrect: Aspiration into the right middle lobe is uncommon, regardless of anatomic position. 
❌ Left upper lobe:
Incorrect: Aspiration into the left upper lobe does not readily occur. Instead, aspiration is more likely to involve the right lung since the right main bronchus is wider, shorter, and has a more vertical trajectory.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department in respiratory arrest. The patient was at a restaurant eating dinner when he suddenly could not catch his breath or speak. Upon arrival, the patient appears cyanotic and is unresponsive to verbal or tactile stimuli. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation is currently in progress. A 2-centimeter piece of meat is observed during intubation in the piriform recess, which is subsequently removed with McGill forceps. Which of the following maneuvers, if performed initially, could have prevented this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents in respiratory arrest after presumed aspiration of a foreign body into the larynx, which is subsequently removed with forceps. In the setting of a suspected foreign body aspiration in adults, the most appropriate technique to perform is abdominal thrusts, also known as the Heimlich maneuver.   

Foreign body aspiration represents a potentially life-threatening condition, occurring more commonly in pediatric patients when compared to adults. The areas of foreign body impaction are generally divided into those above the vocal cords and those below the vocal cords. Aspiration events above the vocal cords are characterized by upper airway obstruction. They can rapidly result in respiratory arrest due to complete occlusion of the airway–particularly with 2 cm or larger foreign bodies. Patients with suspected upper airway obstruction and asphyxiation should be treated immediately with abdominal thrusts (i.e. the Heimlich maneuver).  

This technique involves a rescuer standing behind a patient and using their hands to exert pressure on the bottom of the diaphragm, which increases the intrathoracic pressure, and hopefully expels the foreign body. If unsuccessful, the rescuer may perform a finger sweep if they can visualize a foreign body. Subsequent treatment involves laryngoscopy and removal if the foreign body is still located in the upper airway.  

Option Analysis

✅ Abdominal thrusts :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Chest compressions :
Incorrect: Chest compressions are indicated for an absent pulse in the setting of cardiopulmonary arrest. The performance of this maneuver would not have prevented this patient’s respiratory arrest.
❌ Back blows :
Incorrect: Back blows are indicated for choking pediatric patients with suspected foreign body aspiration, not adult patients. 
❌ Cricoid pressure :
Incorrect: Cricoid pressure is a technique utilized to obtain a better view of the vocal cords in patients with anterior airways. The technique is performed by applying downward, steady pressure against the cricoid cartilage. 
❌ Head-tilt, chin-lift :
Incorrect: The head-tilt chin-lift technique is used to open the airway for proper bag-valve-mask ventilation, not for removing an aspirated foreign body.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman presents to a primary care physician for evaluation of worsening voice hoarseness. Her voice has become progressively muffled and weak over the past three months. She has also experienced shortness of breath on exertion and a diminished appetite. The patient has not seen a physician in over fifteen years. She has a 40-pack year smoking history. A chest radiograph is obtained and demonstrated below. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of voice hoarseness, and chest radiography demonstrates increased opacities in the left lung apex. These findings are concerning for a left-sided superior sulcus, or Pancoast, tumor. Pancoast tumors are well known to invade mediastinal structures, including the recurrent laryngeal nerve, which innervates all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except for the cricothyroid muscle.    

The left recurrent laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve, is highly susceptible to injury given its course in the mediastinum. As it branches off the vagus nerve, it passes under the aortic arch and then traverses superiorly to innervate the intrinsic muscles of the larynx. These muscles adjust the tension on the vocal cords for sound production. Thus damage of the left laryngeal nerve has the potential to result in unilateral vocal cord paralysis. Clinically, patients may experience new-onset hoarseness, changes in pitch, or noisy breathing.  

Common etiologies of left recurrent laryngeal nerve injury include lung malignancies (particularly Pancoast tumors), transection during thyroid or parathyroid surgery, left atrial enlargement, and head and neck cancers.    

Option Analysis

✅ Left recurrent laryngeal nerve injury :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Superior laryngeal nerve injury:
Incorrect: The superior laryngeal nerve supplies sensory fibers to the laryngeal mucosa and motor fibers to the cricothyroid muscle. Given the anatomic location of this nerve, it is unlikely to be injured by a Pancoast tumor. 
❌ Right recurrent laryngeal nerve injury :
Incorrect: The right recurrent laryngeal nerve would be more likely to be affected by a Pancoast tumor of the right lung. In contrast, this patient’s radiograph demonstrates increased opacities in the left lung apex, suggestive of a left Pancoast tumor.
❌ Left vagus nerve injury :
Incorrect: An injury to the vagus nerve would result in hoarseness, as the recurrent laryngeal nerve branches from the vagus. However, injury to the vagus nerve would also result in findings of autonomic dysfunction. 
❌ Bilateral phrenic nerve injury :
Incorrect: Bilateral phrenic nerve injury would result in respiratory compromise due to interrupted diaphragmatic innervation. As a result, the lungs would likely appear hypoinflated on a chest radiograph.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents to the emergency room for evaluation of chest pain and shortness of breath for the past two days. The patient has also experienced a productive cough yielding purulent sputum. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. The patient has a 30-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), blood pressure is 145/82 mmHg, and pulse is 102/min. Physical examination is notable for decreased breath sounds over the right lower lung field. Which of the following would be most helpful in confirming the underlying cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with chest pain, shortness of breath, productive cough, and fever. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds over the right lower lung field. In combination, these findings are most concerning for pneumonia, which can be best confirmed via a chest radiograph (or chest x-ray).   

Chest radiographs are typically the first-line imaging modality when a pulmonary or mediastinal etiology is suspected. Common indications for chest x-ray include chest pain, shortness of breath, and cough. It is also used as a part of the trauma and preoperative evaluation, as well as after placement of monitoring and support devices (e.g., endotracheal tube, chest tube).  

While there are no absolute contraindications for chest x-rays, they should be avoided in patients who are pregnant unless diagnostically necessary.  


Option Analysis

❌ Troponin :
Incorrect: This patient presents with findings suggestive of pneumonia, as opposed to acute coronary syndrome. A chest radiograph would be more useful in confirming this diagnosis. 
❌ D-dimer :
Incorrect: A D-dimer level is often used in the work-up of a suspected pulmonary embolism, which  presents with chest pain, dyspnea, and tachycardia. However, this patient’s fever, productive cough and decreased breath sounds over the right lower lung field are more suggestive of pneumonia, which is best evaluated with a chest radiograph.
✅ Chest radiograph:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Brain natriuretic peptide level:
Incorrect: A brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) level can be used in the work-up of heart failure. This patient does not have signs of fluid overload (e.g. pitting edema) on physical examination. This patient’s presentation is more suggestive of pneumonia, which is best evaluated with a chest radiograph.
❌ Diagnostic thoracentesis:
Incorrect: A thoracentesis is generally indicated only when imaging demonstrates a sizable pleural effusion. Performing a diagnostic thoracentesis prior to imaging is inappropriate.

questions.text: A 53-year-old-man comes to the office for follow-up after being hospitalized for his first episode of acute alcohol-induced pancreatitis last month. He feels well and denies any abdominal pain, nausea, anorexia, or diarrhea. His medical history is significant for heavy chronic alcohol use, and he does not take any medications. His immediate family members are all healthy. He smokes one pack of cigarettes per day. His vitals are within normal limits. Laboratory results show serum electrolytes, cholesterol and triglyceride levels are within normal limits. In addition to limiting alcohol intake, which of the following is most likely to reduce this patient’s risk of developing chronic pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Chronic pancreatitis is the gradual replacement of healthy pancreatic tissue with misshapen ducts, fibrosis, and calcium deposits. As the pancreas recovers from episodes of acute pancreatitis, stellate cells lay down fibrotic tissue leading to narrowing and eventual stenosis of pancreatic ducts. Over time, pancreatic acinar cells begin to atrophy. Recurrent episodes of acute alcohol-induced pancreatitis cause calcium to deposit on the protein plugs that form in ducts. These changes cause chronic or intermittent upper abdominal pain and culminate in the loss of pancreatic endocrine and exocrine function, leading to fat malabsorption (steatorrhea and fat-soluble vitamin deficiency) and diabetes mellitus.  



The causes of chronic pancreatitis can be remembered by the mnemonic “TIGAR-O,” standing for Toxic-metabolic, Idiopathic, Genetic, Autoimmune, Recurrent and severe acute pancreatitis, and Obstructive. Toxic-metabolic factors include alcohol (usually at least five drinks daily for five years), smoking, and hypertriglyceridemia. Smoking works synergistically in a dose-dependent fashion with alcohol to damage the pancreas, leading to more calcifications, further exocrine and endocrine insufficiency, and an increased risk of developing a secondary pancreatic malignancy. Up to 90% of patients who develop chronic alcohol-related pancreatitis have a history of smoking. In addition to decreasing his alcohol intake, this patient should receive smoking cessation treatment to reduce his risk of developing chronic pancreatitis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Lowering of serum triglycerides:
Incorrect: Triglyceride levels >1000 mg/dL may cause acute pancreatitis, with subsequent attacks precipitated by lower levels (>500 mg/dL) that can eventually lead to chronic pancreatitis. However, this patient does not have a history of hypertriglyceridemia, thus lowering his serum triglycerides would be of no benefit.   
✅ Smoking cessation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Blood sugar control  :
Incorrect: Long standing diabetes mellitus may lead to mild pancreatic injury and fibrosis, which rarely manifest as symptomatic chronic pancreatitis. This patient does not have diabetes, thus lowering his blood sugar is unnecessary.  
❌ Steroid treatment:
Incorrect: Autoimmune pancreatitis may progress to chronic pancreatitis and should be appropriately treated with steroids. However, the progression from acute to chronic alcohol-induced pancreatitis has not been shown to be affected by steroid treatment.  
❌ Lowering of serum calcium:
