Incorrect: Hypercalcemia is a rare cause of acute pancreatitis, but lowering serum calcium levels after acute alcohol-induced pancreatitis has not been shown to decrease progression to chronic pancreatitis.

questions.text: A medical student is on her radiology rotation when the radiologist is asked to interpret a portable AP chest x-ray. While analyzing the x-ray, the radiologist begins discussing the anatomic significance of different findings on chest radiography.  Which of the following heart structures is outlined on the chest x-ray below?
questions.solution:
A standard anterior-posterior chest x-ray provides a plethora of information regarding anatomic structures of the heart. Notably, several structures make up the borders of the heart on standard chest radiography, including the right atrium, aortic arch, pulmonary artery, left auricle, and left ventricle. Derangements in these borders of the heart can aid in the diagnosis of underlying conditions (e.g. irregular aortic contour suggestive of aortic dissection). A specific finding known as the silhouette sign occurs when the normal heart borders are lost due to a pathological process in direct contact with the anatomic borders of the heart (e.g. pneumonia).  



Option Analysis

✅ Right atrium:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Right ventricle:
Incorrect: The right ventricle does not comprise the borders of the heart on a standard chest x-ray, given its more anterior position in the thoracic cavity. 
❌ Left ventricle :
Incorrect: The left ventricle comprises the left lower portion of the heart border on a standard chest x-ray. 
❌ Aortic arch:
Incorrect: The aortic arch comprises the most superior portion of the left heart border. 
❌ Pulmonary artery:
Incorrect: The pulmonary artery can be visualized as inferior to the aortic arch on chest radiography.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with progressive dyspnea on exertion. She has lost 25 lbs over the past three months and has experienced decreased appetite. The shortness of breath is worse when lying flat. In addition, she has been intermittently coughing up blood-streaked sputum. The patient has not seen a physician in twenty years. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for thirty years and drinks one to two beers nightly. She does not take any medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 19/min, blood pressure is 120/71 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 92% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates a cachectic female with moderately increased work of breathing and dullness to percussion over the right lung base. A chest radiograph is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient’s clinical condition?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with increased work of breathing, weight loss, and a large right-sided pleural effusion. In this setting, without signs of hemodynamic instability, the most appropriate management involves thoracentesis, which will provide diagnostic and therapeutic benefits for this patient.  

Thoracentesis is a percutaneous procedure wherein fluid is removed from the pleural space via needle aspiration. When performed correctly, large volumes of fluid can be removed (more than one liter), allowing for lung re-expansion, improved oxygenation, and reduced work of breathing. In addition to therapeutic benefit, aspirated pleural fluid can be analyzed to determine if it is exudative versus transudative and evaluate for the presence of malignant cells.  

The preferred site for thoracentesis is on the affected side of the chest in either the midaxillary line or the posterior midscapular line. Before the procedure, ultrasound guidance should be employed to accurately identify a safe site to insert the needle to avoid abdominal structures (e.g. the liver) and the inferior border of the lung. Once an appropriate site has been identified, the area is sterilized and injected with local analgesia. Next, the thoracentesis needle is advanced over the rib to prevent damage to the intercostal vessels and nerves (which run below each rib). Finally, the catheter is advanced, and fluid is aspirated for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes.  

Option Analysis

✅ Thoracentesis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Chest tube placement:
Incorrect: Given the concern for a malignant effusion and no evidence of trauma or hemodynamic instability, a chest tube is not immediately indicated in treating this patient’s condition.   
❌ Needle decompression :
Incorrect: This patient lacks signs of tension physiology (e.g., hypotension, mediastinal shift), making needle decompression of little clinical utility. 
❌ Intravenous furosemide:
Incorrect: Diuresis may assist in volume reduction. However, it is not the definitive diagnostic or therapeutic treatment for patients with a large pleural effusion.
❌ Dialysis :
Incorrect: Dialysis may assist in volume reduction. However, dialysis will not provide diagnostic information regarding the underlying etiology of this patient’s condition.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician due to persistent right wrist pain. The patient has been experiencing pain on the thumb-side of the wrist every time she holds or grips an object. She recently delivered a healthy, full-term baby four weeks ago. Her past medical history is unremarkable, and she does not take any medications. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, swelling and tenderness to palpation are noted at the radial aspect of the right wrist. Repetitive tapping over the volar part of the wrist does not reproduce the pain. While the patient is grasping the right thumb with the right four digits, the physician places the wrist in ulnar deviation. This maneuver reproduces the pain. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of this patient’s disease process?

choices.text: Myxoid degeneration of the abductor pollicis longus and the extensor pollicis brevis
Entrapment and compression of the median nerve
Outpouching of the synovial membranes lining tendinous sheaths
Occult fracture of the distal radius

questions.solution:
This patient presents in the postpartum period with pain over the radial aspect of the wrist and a positive Finklestein test. These findings are consistent with De Quervain tenosynovitis, characterized by myxoid degeneration of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis.

De Quervain tenosynovitis reflects a non-inflammatory thickening of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis as they cross the radial styloid process and through the first extensor compartment. Clinically, patients will experience pain at the radial aspect of the wrist. The pain is exacerbated when gripping objects or performing repetitive movements involving the thumb. Risk factors include female sex, being in the postpartum period, and prolonged abduction and extension of the thumb.

The most useful diagnostic aid in evaluating DeQuervain tenosynovitis is the Finklestein test. The thumb is flexed and held inside a fist to perform this test. Afterward, the wrist is moved in the ulnar direction. A positive test is characterized by pain at the radial styloid process or along the length of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis with ulnar deviation of the wrist.

Treatment is primarily conservative and involves rest, analgesia, and wrist splinting. Advanced or refractory cases are typically treated with glucocorticoids or surgery.  

Option Analysis

✅ Myxoid degeneration of the abductor pollicis longus and the extensor pollicis brevis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Entrapment and compression of the median nerve  :
Incorrect: Carpal tunnel syndrome typically presents with a positive Tinel test, which involves tapping over the median nerve and evaluating reproducible pain or paresthesia. This patient’s negative Tinel test and positive Finklestein test are more indicative of De Quervain tenosynovitis.  
❌ Outpouching of the synovial membranes lining tendinous sheaths  :
Incorrect: Ganglion cysts are clinically characterized by their round appearance and rubbery texture. No such structures are present on this patient’s physical examination.  
❌ Occult fracture of the distal radius:
Incorrect: A fracture of the distal radius is unlikely without associated trauma.  
❌ Calcium hydroxyapatite arthropathy  :
Incorrect: As the name implies, hydroxyapatite crystal deposition disease (HADD) is characterized by periarticular and intraarticular deposition of hydroxyapatite cysts. While HADD is on the differential for atraumatic swelling and pain of the wrist, this patient has a positive Finklestein test, making DeQuervain tenosynovitis a more likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with severe, substernal chest pain. The pain started 3 hours ago with the sensation of pressure in his chest, and it has been increasing in severity. He had a few similar episodes in the past couple of days, but the pain resolved on its own. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 80/40 mmHg, pulse is 60/minute, and respirations are 25/minute. The patient appears in distress and diaphoretic. Physical examination is otherwise unremarkable. An intravenous line is obtained, and normal saline is administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Immediate admission of the patient for catheterization

questions.solution:
This patient is most likely experiencing acute coronary syndrome (ACS). ACS is an emergency that is time sensitive, and thus prompt diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent complications and improve mortality. After initial stabilization of the patient, a focused history and physical examination should be performed, followed by prompt diagnostic workup.  

The diagnostic workup for ACS begins with obtaining a 12-lead ECG and cardiac enzymes (i.e. cardiac troponins). These tests help to confirm the diagnosis and differentiate between the subtypes of ACS, which include ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (non-STEMI), and unstable angina (UA).    

STEMI is the most severe form of ACS and represents a transmural infarction. ECG shows ST-elevation (more than 1 mm in contiguous leads), and cardiac enzymes are elevated. Once a diagnosis of STEMI is confirmed, urgent treatment should begin.  

In contrast, diagnostic ECG in the case of non-STEMI and UA does not have ST-elevation by definition. However, there are usually signs of ischemia on ECG (e.g., ST depression, T-wave inversion). Because both non-STEMI and UA are similar on ECG, cardiac troponins are used to differentiate between the two diagnoses. In non-STEMI, cardiac troponins are elevated, while in UA, cardiac troponins are normal.




Option Analysis

✅ Obtain a 12-lead ECG:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Obtain an emergent chest x-ray:
Incorrect: This patient is most likely experiencing acute coronary syndrome, and thus he needs a 12-lead ECG prior to any diagnostic imaging. 
❌ Obtain an echocardiogram  :
Incorrect: Echocardiogram is not part of the initial diagnostic evaluation in patients with suspected acute coronary syndrome – this patient needs an emergent 12-lead ECG. 
❌ Immediate admission of the patient for catheterization :
Incorrect: Patients with confirmed acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) should be immediately admitted to the catheterization laboratory for PCI. However, a twelve-lead ECG is needed to confirm the diagnosis prior to intervention.  
❌ Immediate administration of fibrinolytic agent :
Incorrect: Fibrinolytics are used in patients with acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) when PCI is not available; however, a twelve-lead ECG is needed to confirm the diagnosis prior to any intervention.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman comes to the clinic with generalized fatigue, unsteady gait, and numbness in her lower limbs for the past 2 months. She states that she often experiences a “tingling” sensation in her legs and feet. Her other medical conditions include hypertension and hypercholesterolemia, which are managed with hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin, respectively. She had a gastric bypass surgery one year ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 136/95 mmHg. She is oriented to time, place and person but is slow to respond to questions. Motor strength is 4/5 in bilateral lower limbs, and deep tendon reflexes are diminished at the ankles. Sensory loss is noted in the bilateral feet with diminished perception to touch and vibration. The patient’s gait is ataxic. Romberg test is positive. Bilateral plantar reflexes are upgoing. Complete blood count reveals a hemoglobin of 10 g/dL. Peripheral smear is shown below:



Reproduced from Wikipedia

Which of the following is the next best step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
This patient has symptoms of peripheral neuropathy, spastic paresis and diminished sensation to vibration and proprioception with a history of gastric bypass surgery. This presentation is suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency.

Although folic acid deficiency can also cause macrocytic, megaloblastic anemia with hypersegmented neutrophils, neurological findings would be rare. Both folate deficiency and B12 deficiency can result in elevated homocysteine levels, as folate acts as a methyl donor and B12 is a cofactor for the conversion of homocysteine to methionine.

Therefore, serum methylmalonic acid (MMA) level is used as a laboratory investigation to differentiate between folate and B12 deficiency when initial test levels are borderline. MMA is found to be elevated in B12 deficiency and within normal limits in folate deficiency.

Methylmalonyl-CoA is converted to succinyl-CoA by the enzyme methylmalonyl mutase with the cofactor vitamin B12. In the absence of vitamin B12 stores, methylmalonyl-CoA accumulates and disrupts myelin synthesis, resulting in the neurological manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency, also known as subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, which includes:

  •  Ataxia, due to involvement of the spinocerebellar tract 
  •  Spastic paresis with positive Babinski sign, due to involvement of the corticospinal tract  
  •  Loss of vibration and proprioception with a positive Romberg sign, due to involvement of the dorsal column pathway 

Option Analysis

❌ Bone marrow examination:
Incorrect: Bone marrow examination is not indicated for the evaluation of vitamin B12 or folate deficiencies. In both cases, it is likely to reveal a hypercellular bone marrow with megaloblastic erythrocytes and giant metamyelocytes.
❌ Erythrocyte transketolase activity :
Incorrect: Thiamine deficiency can result in decreased erythrocyte transketolase activity, as TPP (thiamine pyrophosphate) acts as a cofactor for transketolase, an enzyme in the HMP shunt pathway. Thiamine deficiency can cause peripheral neuropathy (dry beriberi) and dementia (Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome); however, macrocytic, megaloblastic anemia would be unlikely. Furthermore, involvement of the dorsal column pathway (positive Romberg sign and diminished vibration sense) indicates an alternative diagnosis.
❌ Serum VDRL:
Incorrect: A serum VDRL is indicated for the evaluation of tabes dorsalis, as seen in patients with neurosyphilis. Although tabes dorsalis can also manifest with involvement of the dorsal column pathway as diminished perception to vibration and impaired proprioception with a positive Romberg test, it is unlikely to be the cause of this patient’s megaloblastic, macrocytic anemia.
❌ Thyroid function tests:
Incorrect: Hypothyroidism can cause macrocytic anemia and carpal tunnel syndrome with peripheral neuropathy involving the distribution of the median nerve in the hand. Involvement of the dorsal column, spinocerebellar tract, and the corticospinal tract as seen in this patient, however, would be unlikely.
✅ Serum methylmalonic acid levels:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with right ring finger pain. The patient recalls that the right ring finger has been “catching and locking” for weeks. The symptoms seem to improve throughout the day, with gradual “unlocking” as the day progresses. Past medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension, for which he takes metformin and hydrochlorothiazide. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates the fourth digit of the right hand to be in a flexed position, as shown below. Passive extension of the digit is met with some resistance. There are no palpable nodules or tenderness along the flexor tendon sheath. Nonetheless, he can fully extend the digit with minimal pain. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  


Image reproduced from Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient has intermittent locking and catching of the fourth digit and difficulty extending the finger from a flexed position. This clinical presentation is most consistent with trigger finger, also termed stenosing tenosynovitis.

Trigger finger is a flexor tendon that catches when it attempts to glide through a stenotic sheath, resulting in an inability to flex or extend the finger smoothly. The underlying pathology of this disease remains unclear but is thought to be due to fibrocartilaginous metaplasia of the ligamentous layer of the tendon sheath. The majority of cases are idiopathic, although some are associated with repetitive hand motions, often from occupational activities.

Clinically, patients experience a catching and locking sensation of the finger that progressively worsens over time. Patients may also experience pain localized over the volar aspect of the metacarpophalangeal joint.  

Treatment is primarily conservative and involves splinting, analgesia, and rest. Local glucocorticoid injection can also be administered. Patients who are refractory to conservative management or glucocorticoid injections may warrant the surgical release of the flexor tendon.  

Option Analysis

✅ Stenosing tenosynovitis  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Dupuytren contracture  :
Incorrect: A Dupuytren contracture is characterized by slow, progressive fibroproliferation of the palmar fascia. Patients typically have a palpable cord or nodules along the flexor tendon sheath.  
❌ Flexor tenosynovitis  :
Incorrect: Flexor tenosynovitis is a surgical emergency and refers to a deep space infection of the flexor tendon sheath. Patients can present with pain with passive extension, tenderness over the entire length of the flexor tendon sheath, symmetric finger swelling along the length of the tendon sheath, and flexed posture of the affected finger.
❌ Mallet finger  :
Incorrect: Mallet finger refers to an injury to the extensor digitorum as it crosses the distal interphalangeal joint. This injury results in an inability to extend the finger at the distal interphalangeal joint.  
❌ Jersey finger  :
Incorrect: Jersey finger refers to an injury to the flexor digitorum profundus tendon as it crosses the distal interphalangeal joint. This injury results in an inability to flex the finger at the distal interphalangeal joint.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman presents to her outpatient provider for evaluation of dull chest pain for the past two months. The pain is more profound in the right chest and worsens with physical activity. A chest radiograph is obtained as part of the work-up and shown below. Which of the following best describes the characteristics of this image?  


Image reproduced from SAEM
questions.solution:
A chest x-ray was appropriately obtained in the workup of this patient’s symptoms. The above image demonstrates adequate inspiratory effort, underpenetration, and midline alignment.  

When reviewing a chest x-ray, it is important to assess its quality and technical view, which describes whether an image is taken anterior-posterior (AP) or posterior-anterior (PA). Quality is based on a combination of three metrics:  

The first metric is penetration, which describes the extent to which the x-rays have passed through the patient’s body. If a study is adequately penetrated, then the lower thoracic spine should be visualized through the cardiac shadow. If the lower thoracic spine is not visualized, the study is under-penetrated. In contrast, in an over-penetrated study, too many x-rays pass through low density structures, causing the lung fields to appear black, increasing the risk that pathologic findings are missed.

The second metric is inspiration. In a film with adequate inspiratory effort, 8-10 posterior ribs can be seen above the diaphragm.  

The final metric is rotation, which can be determined by evaluating the relationship between the clavicles and the spine. If the medial ends of the clavicles are equidistant from the thoracic spinous process, then the patient is midline and not rotated.  


Option Analysis

✅  Penetration Inspiratory Effort  Rotation  Underpenetrated  Adequate  Midline :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Penetration  Inspiratory Effort  Rotation  Underpenetrated  inadequate  Midline :
Incorrect: This radiograph is underpenetrated since the lower thoracic vertebral bodies are not visualized. The patient demonstrates adequate respiratory effort since the posterior aspects of over eight ribs can be seen.
❌  Penetration  Inspiratory Effort  Rotation  Underpenetrated  Adequate Right anterior oblique:
Incorrect: This patient’s chest radiograph demonstrates under-penetration and adequate inspiratory effort. Moreover, the image is well-aligned since the spinous processes lie approximately half-way between the medial ends of the clavicles, indicating that the patient is midline.
❌  Penetration  Inspiratory Effort  Rotation  Overrpenetrated  Inadequate  Midline :
Incorrect: This radiograph is underpenetrated, not overpenetrated, since the lower thoracic vertebral bodies are not visualized. 
❌  Penetration  Inspiratory Effort  Rotation Overpenetrated  Adequate  Left anterior oblique:
Incorrect: This radiograph is underpenetrated, not overpenetrated, since the lower thoracic vertebral bodies are not visualized. Moreover, there is no evidence of rotation since the spinous processes lie approximately half-way between the medial ends of the clavicles, indicating that the patient is midline.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man is evaluated by the primary care physician for 9-weeks of muscle pain and joint stiffness most prominent in the bilateral hips and shoulders. The patient reports that the symptoms are worse in the morning and improve with movement. He has had no headaches, jaw pain, or vision loss. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, for which he is currently taking diltiazem. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), blood pressure is 133/79 mmHg, pulse is 66/min, and respiratory rate is 15/min. On physical exam, the bilateral deltoids and quadriceps are tender to palpation. No muscle weakness is observed. The remainder of the physical examination is noncontributory. Laboratory testing reveals the following results:  

 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  15.8 g/dL 
 Leukocyte  8,800/mm3 
 Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR)   98 mm/h 
 Serum creatinine kinase  81 U/L 

What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has polymyalgia rheumatica, an inflammatory disease that most often affects individuals over 50 years of age. The condition can be diagnosed using a combination of the patient’s history, physical examination, and laboratory results.

The condition typically causes symptoms like pain and stiffness of the shoulders and hips. The symptoms are generally more severe in the morning and at night, often lasting for more than an hour, and they typically improve after activity. Polymyalgia rheumatica can also cause a low-grade fever, fatigue, and loss of appetite, which can lead to weight loss.  

Laboratory testing will reveal an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) level. There is little damage to muscles, so serum creatinine kinase levels are within normal limits. In contrast, conditions such as dermatomyositis and polymyositis that cause muscle damage will present with elevated creatinine kinase levels.    

Patients diagnosed with polymyalgia rheumatica should be started on low-dose corticosteroids such as prednisolone. The response to corticosteroids is rapid, and most patients have symptomatic improvement after the first week of treatment. In fact, PMR is so responsive to steroid therapy that a lack of improvement warrants investigation of a different diagnosis. In addition, exercise and a healthy diet can strengthen muscles and bones as well as improve flexibility in the joints affected by the disease.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Initiate low-dose oral prednisolone therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Initiate daily NSAID therapy:
Incorrect: NSAID therapy is useful in conditions related to joint inflammation, such as rheumatoid arthritis (RA), or ankylosing spondylitis. Although RA may present similarly with morning stiffness that improves with movement, this patient’s muscle tenderness, elevated ESR, and low-grade fevers are suggestive of polymyalgia rheumatica, which requires a different form of treatment. 
❌ Perform temporal artery biopsy:
Incorrect: A temporal artery biopsy can be used to diagnose patients with temporal arteritis. The condition can cause headaches, jaw pain, and vision loss. The patient’s symptoms raise concern for polymyalgia rheumatica, which increases the risk of developing temporal arteritis. However, the patient has no symptoms specific to temporal arteritis, and thus a biopsy is not warranted at this time.
❌ Perform quadriceps muscle biopsy:
Incorrect: A proximal muscle biopsy is used to diagnose patients with dermatomyositis or polymyositis. Both of these conditions present with proximal muscle tenderness. Individuals with these conditions also have muscle weakness. In contrast, this patient has full strength. Moreover, individuals with these conditions have an elevated creatinine kinase, whereas this patient’s value is normal.
❌ Initiate imipramine therapy:
Incorrect: Tricyclic antidepressants are used to treat fibromyalgia. The condition can present with widespread pain, fatigue, muscle stiffness, and difficulty concentrating (“fibro fog”). In contrast, this patient presents with localized pain most prominent in the shoulders and hips. Moreover, fibromyalgia would not cause an elevated ESR.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male college student comes to the clinic with an ECG obtained at a health fair, where he was told the reading was abnormal. He is a competitive track and field athlete and excels in long-distance running. He denies chest pain, shortness of breath, or loss of consciousness. He has no prior medical history and takes no medications other than a daily multivitamin. He denies family history of sudden unexpected deaths. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mmHg. He appears thin and comfortable. Physical exam shows a normal heart rate without murmurs and 2+ regular carotid and radial pulses bilaterally. Lungs are clear. ECG shows the following:  



Reproduced from: Wikipedia

Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has isolated first degree atrioventricular (AV) block on his ECG. First degree AV block is defined as a PR interval > 200 milliseconds, representing prolonged conduction through the AV node:  





First degree AV block may be caused by heightened vagal tone (e.g. highly conditioned endurance athletes), structural abnormalities of the AV node, medications that impair nodal conduction (e.g., digoxin, beta blockers, non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers), conduction pathway infiltration (e.g. sarcoidosis), and ischemia (e.g. inferior wall myocardial infarction, because the AV node is supplied by the right coronary artery).  

The majority of cases of first degree AV block are found incidentally on ECG, are not dangerous, and do not cause symptoms. History and physical examination should be directed toward identifying any of the pathologies described above. In the absence of concerning cardiac findings on exam, asymptomatic patients like this athlete require no further workup or treatment.  

Option Analysis

❌ Perform invasive electrophysiology study:
Incorrect: In patients with isolated first degree AV block, an invasive electrophysiology study (EPS) is not needed for diagnosis. If a wide QRS complex is present concurrently with PR prolongation, the conduction delay may be present below the AV node, and EPS may be helpful to determine the precise location.  
❌ Recommend decreasing physical activity:
Incorrect: Highly conditioned endurance athletes may have evidence of first degree AV block because of increased vagal tone with a lower resting heart rate. In the absence of symptoms, reducing physical activity is unnecessary.   
❌ Perform transthoracic echocardiogram:
Incorrect: All patients with suspected first degree AV blocks should be questioned about a history of heart disease. In the absence of risk factors for heart disease, in an otherwise healthy young patient with first degree AV block, an echocardiogram will not provide helpful information and is unnecessary.  
❌ Place permanent pacemaker  :
Incorrect: A pacemaker is not recommended in asymptomatic patients with first degree AV block.   
✅ No treatment is required:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the office due to a breast lump she noticed on self-examination several days ago. Medical history is notable for hypertension controlled with hydrochlorothiazide. She does not smoke or use excessive alcohol. Family history is negative for cancer. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, a non-tender, fixed mass in the right upper quadrant of the right breast is palpated, and mild skin dimpling is noted. There is no axillary lymphadenopathy, and there are no nipple changes. Mammogram reveals a calcified mass with spiculated margins. Core-needle biopsy is obtained and confirms the diagnosis of early staged infiltrating ductal carcinoma clinical stage (cTNM) T1cN0M0. Immunohistochemistry for receptor status is negative for estrogen and progesterone receptors but positive for HER2 amplification. Prior to initiating the appropriate chemotherapeutic medication, which of the following should be done?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with early-stage infiltrating ductal carcinoma. In general, all patients with early-stage breast cancer should be treated primarily with breast surgery (lumpectomy or mastectomy) with/without radiation therapy (RT). Unless there is a specific indication for mastectomy, breast-conserving therapy is prefered and includes lumpectomy with RT. Patients with clinically suspicious axillary lymph nodes should be evaluated prior to surgery with imaging and biopsy. Those without clinical evidence of lymph node involvement should undergo sentinel lymph node biopsy during surgery, as this patient. Following surgery, adjuvant therapy may be added depending on the tumor characteristics, grade, size, lymph nodes involvement, and receptor status (i.e., estrogen and progesterone receptors, and expression of the human epidermal growth factor 2 receptor [HER2]).  

Because this patient’s tumor shows overexpression of HER2 receptors and is negative for estrogen and progesterone receptors, she should receive trastuzumab. Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets HER2 and is important in the treatment of women with breast cancers demonstrating HER2 overexpression. Its use, however, results in a small risk for cardiotoxicity, which is typically seen as an asymptomatic decrease in left ventricular ejection fraction and less often by clinical heart failure; therefore, baseline cardiac function with an echocardiogram should be assessed prior to the initiation of therapy.  

Option Analysis

❌ Chest x-ray:
Incorrect: Methotrexate and busulfan are 2 chemotherapeutic agents that can potentially cause pulmonary fibrosis, which may be seen on chest x-ray. This patient was likely started on trastuzumab, which is associated with cardiotoxicity that is not necessarily evident on chest x-ray.  
❌ Liver function tests  :
Incorrect: Antifolate medications (e.g. methotrexate) can cause direct damage to hepatocytes, resulting in elevation of liver enzymes. Baseline liver function tests are typically indicated in patients starting on methotrexate to determine if elevations while on the medication are truly caused by the drug.   
✅ Echocardiography:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Pulmonary function tests:
Incorrect: Methotrexate and busulfan are 2 chemotherapeutic agents that can potentially cause pulmonary fibrosis, and therefore patients require a baseline pulmonary function test (PFT). If a patient becomes symptomatic (e.g. short of breath), repeat PFT during the course of treatment may demonstrate a restrictive lung disease pattern. This patient was likely started on trastuzumab, which is associated with cardiotoxicity.  
❌ Purified protein derivative skin test  :
Incorrect: Prior to initiating highly immunosuppressive therapies, patients at a high risk of carrying latent tuberculosis (e.g. immigrants, healthcare workers) should be tested with a purified protein derivative [PPD] skin test in order to avoid reactivation and disseminated infection. This patient was likely started on trastuzumab, which is not known for severe immunosuppression, and therefore, a PPD test is not indicated at this time.

questions.text: A 41-year-old male presents to the primary care physician after having a positive interferon-gamma assay. The patient works as a nurse and received the test during a routine onboarding evaluation screening. Several months ago, he had contact with an individual with active tuberculosis, but he never developed any symptoms. He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. The patient subsequently undergoes sputum analysis and chest radiography, both of which are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment regimen for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a history and laboratory findings consistent with latent tuberculosis, as defined by the positive interferon-gamma assay but negative chest x-ray and sputum study. Treatment for latent tuberculosis is best achieved with rifamycin therapy.   

Rifamycin therapy refers to one of the following treatment regimens: 1) four months of rifampin given daily, 2) three months of isoniazid plus rifapentine given once weekly, or 3) three months of isoniazid plus rifampin given daily. An alternative regimen consists of isoniazid given daily for six to nine months.  

In general, rifamycin therapy is preferred for the treatment of latent tuberculosis due to its tolerability, efficacy, and shorter duration. In contrast, isoniazid monotherapy has documented issues with hepatotoxicity and medication noncompliance due to long treatment duration.  

Option Analysis

✅ Rifampin monotherapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Isoniazid, rifampin, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide:
Incorrect: Rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol (RIPE therapy) is reserved for treatment of active tuberculosis. It is not a prescribed treatment regimen for latent tuberculosis. 
❌ Rifampin and pyrazinamide:
Incorrect: Rifampin and pyrazinamide are generally not recommended as therapy for latent tuberculosis due to increased risk of hepatotoxicity. 
❌ Isoniazid monotherapy:
Incorrect: Isoniazid monotherapy is an accepted alternative to rifampin monotherapy for treatment of latent tuberculosis. However, isoniazid has a longer treatment duration and is more hepatotoxic.  
❌ Azithromycin monotherapy:
Incorrect: Azithromycin can be used for the treatment of community acquired pneumonia, bronchitis, and sinusitis. However, it is not used in the treatment of tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of severe pain in the left knee. She reports that it has been painful, warm, and red over the past day. She states that a similar episode occurred several months ago in her right big toe, which resolved spontaneously without treatment. She has not had any fevers, recent joint trauma, or weight loss. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She is currently on hydrochlorothiazide, metformin, and pravastatin. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 138/95 mmHg. Physical examination reveals swelling, erythema, and warmth of the left knee joint. It is tender to palpation with decreased active and passive range of motion. Which of the following is most likely to help establish the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This middle-aged woman presenting with recurrent episodes of joint pain, erythema, and swelling requires an arthrocentesis to further investigate the underlying cause. A likely explanation for this patient’s joint pain is gout attacks, which are caused by precipitation of urate crystals in the joints. Urate crystal deposition then stimulates the production of cytokines that recruit leukocytes.    

Arthrocentesis (aspiration of synovial fluid) of the knee joint has two benefits. First, it is therapeutic, as it relieves pressure from the joint. Second, it is also diagnostic, as additional tests of the aspirated fluid can be performed (e.g., Gram-stain, culture, microscopy).  

In order to diagnose gout attacks, polarized light microscopy should be utilized to identify needle-shaped, negatively birefringent monosodium urate crystals. Although this patient does not have a fever, Gram-staining and culture of the synovial fluid can be done to conclusively rule out septic arthritis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Arthrocentesis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Initiation of antibiotic therapy :
Incorrect: Septic arthritis is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus and can be treated with antibiotics. While this patient’s presentation of acute, severe pain in the knee could be caused by septic arthritis, the lack of fever makes this unlikely. 
❌ Lower extremity MRI :
Incorrect: MRI is useful in detecting structural damage to joints, such as ligament and tendon tears. However, this patient does not have a history of joint trauma. As a result, an MRI scan would most likely not be helpful in diagnosing the patient’s condition. 
❌ Serum uric acid levels :
Incorrect: Serum uric acid levels may be increased in patients with gout. However, this is not always the case, and oftentimes, uric acid levels can be normal or low even during acute episodes. There is a more reliable method to diagnose an acute gout attack. 
❌ X-ray of the left knee:
Incorrect: An x-ray of the left knee would be useful in detecting fractures and/or displacement of bones. This patient has no history of trauma, and therefore, an x-ray would likely not be useful in diagnosing the patient’s condition.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman comes to the emergency department complaining of nausea and flank pain. Over the past 24 hours, she developed pain in her right flan,k along with fevers and several episodes of non-bilious, non-bloody vomiting. She has a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus and uses an insulin pump which is currently in place and appears to be functioning properly. The patient’s temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 95/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows a thin, uncomfortable woman with legs flexed to her chest in the right lateral decubitus position. She is breathing deeply. Lightly tapping over her right lower back causes her to jump in pain. Sensation to light touch is diminished on the plantar surfaces of both feet. Laboratory studies show the following:  
 
Laboratory value Result 
Hemoglobin  12 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  36 % 
 Leukocyte count  16,000/mm3 
 Platelet count  400,000/mm3 
 Sodium  130 mEq/L 
 Potassium  5.0 mEq/L 
 Chloride  100 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  14 mEq/L 
 Blood urea nitrogen  15 mg/dL 
 Creatinine  1.0 mg/dL 
 Glucose  500 mg/dL 
Which of the following solutes is most important to replenish at this point in time?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of pyelonephritis in the setting of well-controlled type 1 diabetes mellitus with evidence of chronic peripheral neuropathy (extremity numbness). Pyelonephritis, or an infection of the kidney, is more common in diabetic patients and causes nausea, vomiting, fever, leukocytosis, and flank pain with costovertebral tenderness on physical examination. Although this patient’s diabetes has stably been controlled on her insulin pump, infections increase the body’s insulin requirement and are thus a common trigger for diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). Without any insulin, lipolysis occurs and the liver starts to turn fatty acids into ketone bodies, such as aceto-acetic acid and beta hydroxybutyric acid, thereby increasing the acidity of the blood, causing an anion-gap metabolic acidosis.   

Clinically, individuals with DKA are dehydrated from hyperglycemic polyuria. The acidosis causes Kussmaul respiration, which is deep and rapid breathing as the body tries to move carbon dioxide out of the blood to reduce its acidity. Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and mental status changes like delirium and psychosis can occur. Laboratory results show hyperglycemia with low serum pH and low bicarbonate. The anion gap is high, which reflects a large difference in the unmeasured negative and positive ions in the serum, largely due to this build up of ketoacids.  

Potassium is critically important to replete in DKA. Recall that cells have a transporter that exchanges hydrogen ions for potassium. When the blood gets acidic, there are many positively charged hydrogen ions present in the blood. Cells will exchange these extracellular protons with intracellular potassium, so initially there will be hyperkalemia. In addition to helping glucose enter cells, insulin also stimulates the sodium-potassium ATPases that help potassium get into cells; without insulin, more potassium stays in the extracellular fluid. Since this extracellular potassium is quickly excreted, even though the blood potassium levels remain high, total body potassium is depleted. Therefore, treatment of DKA relies on IV fluids to correct dehydration, IV insulin to reverse lipolysis, and aggressive potassium repletion as soon as serum potassium levels are in the normal range.  



Option Analysis

❌ Sodium:
Incorrect: An increase in extracellular glucose concentration moves water out of cells, causing dilution of extracellular sodium and a falsely low serum sodium level on lab values. For every 100 mg/dL of glucose over 100, you can expect a 1.6 drop in sodium. This patient’s corrected sodium level is normal at 136 mEq/L.  
✅ Potassium:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Chloride:
Incorrect: Serum chloride levels are usually normal in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis and do not require focused repletion beyond what is given in isotonic fluids.   
❌ Bicarbonate:
Incorrect: Although this patient’s bicarbonate is low, indicating diabetic ketoacidosis, the proper way to fix it is by treating the underlying cause with insulin and intravenous fluids. Clinical trials do not support the routine use of bicarbonate replacement in diabetic ketoacidosis.  
❌ Glucose:
Incorrect: Treating diabetic ketoacidosis requires insulin to allow the body to process all of the built up extracellular glucose. Only once the plasma glucose reaches 200-250 mg/dL is glucose added to the insulin infusion to prevent massive drops in serum glucose, which can cause cerebral edema.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department with fevers and a cough for the past week. The fever is intermittent and associated with a dull headache. The cough is non-productive, and the patient denies sore throat, nasal congestion, shortness of breath, or chest pain. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 5 years ago. Initially, the patient was prescribed oral antihyperglycemics, but he switched to herbal remedies after one month because of side effects. The patient has never smoked cigarettes. He is employed as a groundskeeper at a local country club. The patient’s temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows occasional coarse left-sided crackles on lung auscultation. Neurologic and skin examinations are normal. Serum laboratory studies show the following:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 White blood cells  28,000 /mm3 
 Creatinine  2.3 mg/dL 
 Glucose  374 mg/dL 
 Bicarbonate  19 mEq/L 
 Ketones  Positive 
Chest X-ray shows homogenous opacities in the left upper lobe. Nasal endoscopy shows extensive inflammation of the left nasal cavity and maxillary sinus. Sputum microscopy shows the following:  


 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following antimicrobial agents is most appropriate to administer to this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s findings of fever, leukocytosis, headache, and cough, along with pulmonary opacities and hyphal elements on sputum, suggest a diagnosis of a disseminated fungal infection. Additionally, this patient has a history of uncontrolled diabetes with ketosis and acidosis on laboratory studies. Patients with diabetic ketoacidosis are uniquely at high risk of acquiring mucormycosis, while patients with normal immune function are almost never infected.  

Under the order of Mucorales, the most common genuses that cause human infection are Rhizopus and Mucor. They are ubiquitous in the environment. Their hyphae are broad, irregularly branched (at 90º), and have rare septations. Aspergillus, by contrast, has narrow hyphae with regular branching (at 45º) and many septations. Intravenous amphotericin B is the initial drug of choice to treat mucormycosis. Second line drugs include posaconazole or isavuconazole. Even with appropriate antifungal therapy, mortality from mucormycosis approaches 80%.  

Besides mucormycosis, patients with diabetes are at higher risk of acquiring bacterial and fungal infections in general. The attributable mechanisms include the following: 1) decreased neutrophil chemotaxis and adherence, 2) vascular insufficiency depressing the oxygen-dependent bactericidal functions of leukocytes, 3) sensory peripheral neuropathy predisposing to skin lesions, 4) autonomic neuropathy causing urinary stasis, and 5) increased skin and mucosal colonization with pathogens.  

Option Analysis

✅ Amphotericin B:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Ceftazidime:
Incorrect: Ceftazidime (a third-generation cephalosporin) is the antibacterial agent of choice to treat melioidosis (infection with the gram-negative bacterium Burkholderia pseudomallei). The most common symptoms are pneumonia and skin infections. Diabetic patients are at risk for this infection because of their impaired ability to kill Burkholderia via macrophages; however, this patient’s sputum microscopy shows a different organism. 
❌ Fluconazole:
Incorrect: Fluconazole is a hydrophilic azole used to treat candidal infections, and is commonly used to treat vulvovaginal candidiasis in women. Diabetic patients are particularly susceptible to infections with Candida albicans because glucose activates its adhesion proteins, allowing it to attach to the vaginal epithelium and evade phagocytosis.
❌ Isavuconazonium :
Incorrect: Isavuconazonium is a prodrug that is rapidly hydrolyzed in the blood to the active azole isavuconazole. It is most commonly used in the treatment and prevention of invasive aspergillosis, although it can be used as a second-line medication in the treatment of mucormycosis, if treatment with amphotericin B is unsuccessful.
❌ Nitrofurantoin:
Incorrect: Nitrofurantoin is an antibiotic that is reduced by bacterial flavoproteins into intermediates which halt bacterial metabolism. It is used commonly in the treatment of simple acute cystitis, which is most often caused by Escherichia coli. Diabetic patients are at risk for this infection because of the formation of glycation end products that enhance bacterial binding to the bladder urothelium.

questions.text:
A 76-year-old male presents to the emergency department with altered mental status. The patient was found down for an unknown period of time by neighbors. His initial blood sugar was 45 mg/dL, for which he was given dextrose prior to arrival. He is unable to provide any medical history due to his mental status. Temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 21/min, blood pressure is 84/62 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. Physical examination is notable for a confused male in moderate respiratory distress with rales at the right lower lobe. The patient is given two liters of intravenous normal saline, acetaminophen, intravenous ceftriaxone and azithromycin, and norepinephrine without improvement in his vital signs or clinical status. A repeat blood sugar is 37 mg/dL, and initial laboratory findings are demonstrated below:



Which of the following medications is indicated for management of this patient's clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient with an unknown medical history presents altered, febrile, and likely has underlying pneumonia. Additionally, he is persistently hypoglycemic and hypotensive despite multiple resuscitative measures, and his laboratory findings indicate hyponatremia and hyperkalemia. Together, his findings are consistent with adrenal crisis for which the appropriate treatment is intravenous hydrocortisone.  

Acute adrenal insufficiency, also termed adrenal crisis, refers to the acute loss of adrenal hormones aldosterone and cortisol. It is often precipitated in patients with chronic adrenal insufficiency who are exposed to physiologic stresses. Clinically, acute adrenal insufficiency is characterized by hypotension and refractory shock -- shock that does not respond to intravenous fluids, blood products, pressors, or antibiotics. Additional features are often dependent on the etiology but can include anorexia, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, weakness, fatigue, confusion, and coma.  

There are many precipitating causes of acute adrenal insufficiency, including abdominal trauma, infections, and recent surgeries. In the emergency setting, acute adrenal insufficiency with hypotension should be treated with intravenous fluids and intravenous hydrocortisone due to its potent glucocorticoid effects on hemodynamics and glycemic control.  



Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous hydrocortisone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Intravenous fludrocortisone:
Incorrect: While fludrocortisone may assist in treating this patient’s adrenal crisis, it is primarily a mineralocorticoid, meaning that it will work by mitigating the effects of lost aldosterone. Fludrocortisone has weak glucocorticoid activity, and it will do little to reverse this patient's persistent hypoglycemia. As a result, hydrocortisone is the preferred first-line agent in treating acute adrenal insufficiency.
❌ Intravenous lactated ringers:
Incorrect: This patient has already been resuscitated with two liters of normal saline without improvement in blood pressure. Administrating additional intravenous fluids will be unlikely to improve his condition.
❌ Intravenous vancomycin:
Incorrect: This patient is already being adequately covered for community acquired pneumonia with ceftriaxone and azithromycin. Vancomycin is not indicated in the treatment of this patient’s clinical condition.
❌ Intravenous type O negative blood:
Incorrect: Blood transfusion is generally indicated for hemoglobin levels <7g/dL. This patient is slightly anemic but not to the point of requiring blood transfusion.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for an annual visit. She is feeling well and has no acute complaints. The patient’s mother recently had a spinal compression fracture secondary to osteoporosis. The patient is concerned that she may develop the same condition later in life. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 122/78 mmHg, pulse is 67/min, and BMI 20 kg/m2. Which of the following interventions will be most useful in reducing this patient’s risk of developing osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
Several strategies can be utilized to achieve osteoporosis prophylaxis. These strategies include weight-bearing exercises (e.g., running, hiking) and adequate calcium and vitamin D intake throughout adulthood. Additionally, cessation of cigarette smoking and avoiding excessive alcohol intake are both associated with decreased rates of osteoporosis.

Hormone replacement therapy with estrogen may be beneficial in postmenopausal women. However, hormone replacement therapy can increase the risk of endometrial cancer and cardiovascular disease, and therefore the risk vs. benefit should be analyzed in each individual patient. As a result, some women may also benefit from having progesterone or progestin added to the treatment.



Option Analysis

✅ Initiation of jogging routine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Estrogen replacement therapy:
Incorrect: Estrogen replacements can be prescribed to postmenopausal women. The medications prevent osteoclast differentiation and reduce bone reabsorption. However, estrogen replacements have side effects including increased risk of blood clots and endometrial cancer. For these reasons, estrogen replacements are not prescribed to premenopausal women for osteoporosis prophylaxis.
❌ Prophylactic alendronate treatment:
Incorrect: Bisphosphonates can be used to manage osteoporosis by reducing osteoclast activity and bone resorption. However, the benefits of the medication must be balanced with its risks (e.g., esophageal inflammation, hypocalcemia, aseptic jaw osteonecrosis). As a result, prophylactic bisphosphonate therapy would be inappropriate in this patient.
❌ Initiation of swimming routine:
Incorrect: Weight-bearing exercises, such as running or weight lifting, are effective in reducing a patient’s risk of developing osteoporosis. However, swimming is not a weight-bearing exercise, since the buoyancy of the water counteracts the effects of gravity.
❌ Encourage weight gain:
Incorrect: Low body-mass index (BMI) can increase an individual's risk of developing osteoporosis. However, in patients with a healthy BMI, weight gain itself is not recommended as prophylaxis against osteoporosis because increased body weight can lead to other comorbidities, including osteoarthritis, hypertension, cardiovascular disease, and sleep apnea.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman is scheduled to undergo a routine screening colonoscopy for colorectal cancer. She has no changes in bowel habits, unintentional weight loss, or noticeable blood in the stool. Her previous colonoscopy 10 years ago showed no abnormalities. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus. There is no family history of colorectal cancers. Colonoscopy is performed, which reveals a single, sessile 10-mm polyp covered in mucous in the ascending colon. Histology of this polyp subtype from a different patient is shown below:  

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

 Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Observation and follow-up colonoscopy in 5 years

questions.solution:
Colorectal polyps are overgrowths of epithelial cells in the colon or rectum. They are subdivided into non-neoplastic polyps (e.g., hamartomatous polyps, hyperplastic polyps, inflammatory pseudopolyps) and neoplastic polyps (e.g., adenomatous polyps, serrated polyps). Serrated polyps are a type of colonic polyp that has moderate potential to undergo malignant transformation and therefore should be treated with complete excision.    

Serrated polyps, also termed sessile serrated adenomas (SSAs), are commonly seen in the right colon. These polyps have a smooth surface, are often flat or sessile, and may be covered with mucus. The most useful histologic feature that distinguishes SSAs from hyperplastic polyps is the presence of serrated architecture throughout the full length of the glands, including the crypt base (Figure 1). In contrast, hyperplastic polyps have serrated architecture only at the surface. This unique architecture often gives serrated polyps a “sawtooth” appearance under the microscope.

 Figure 1: Histological differences between hyperplastic and serrated polyps  


A) Hyperplastic polyps demonstrate serrated architecture primarily at the surface (Wikimedia Commons)
B) Serrated polyps demonstrate serrate architecture through the full length of the biopsy sample (Wikimedia Commons)

Option Analysis

✅ Complete excision of the polyp:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Genetic testing for MLH1 mutations:
Incorrect: Lynch syndrome is caused by an autosomal dominant mutation in DNA mismatch repair genes (e.g., MLH1, MSH2). Lynch syndrome is unlikely in this patient who has no family history of colorectal cancer and no personal history of abnormal colonoscopies.
❌ Genetic testing for STK11 mutations:
Incorrect: Peutz-Jegher syndrome is caused by a mutation in the STK11 gene. It presents with mucosal hyperpigmentation and numerous hamartomatous gastrointestinal polyps in young children. This patient is presenting with a single colonic polyp at a much older age and had no abnormalities noted on previous colonoscopies, hence making Peutz-Jegher syndrome unlikely. 
❌ Genetic testing for APC mutations:
Incorrect: Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is an autosomal dominant disorder marked by the appearance of numerous colorectal adenomas by the teenage years. This patient lacks a familial history of colon cancer, and her previous colonoscopy yielded normal findings, hence making this diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Observation and follow-up colonoscopy in 5 years:
Incorrect: The histological findings are consistent with those of a serrated polyp. Serrated polyps have a moderate risk for malignant transformation and therefore should be immediately excised.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman returns to the clinic after a high blood pressure reading 1 week ago. She has also been experiencing fatigue and muscle weakness over the past month. Past medical history is noncontributory. Her blood pressure is 159/94 mmHg at today’s visit. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies reveal a potassium concentration of 3.2 mEq/L. The plasma aldosterone concentration to plasma renin activity ratio is significantly elevated. Abdominal CT reveals bilateral adrenal gland masses. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option?
questions.solution:
This patient has persistent hypertension, fatigue, and muscle weakness. Further workup reveals elevated aldosterone levels and bilateral adrenal masses. She likely has primary hyperaldosteronism due to bilateral adrenal adenomas, which should be treated with aldosterone receptor antagonists.

The most common cause of primary hyperaldosteronism is bilateral idiopathic hyperplasia of the adrenal glands, which results in autonomous overproduction of aldosterone. Other less common causes include adrenal adenomas, ectopic aldosterone secretion from the kidneys or ovaries, and familial hyperaldosteronism. Regardless of etiology, the high levels of aldosterone will lead to hypokalemia, hypernatremia, and metabolic alkalosis. Some patients may develop significant hypokalemia, which may manifest with muscular aches and weakness, muscle spasms, numbness, and heart palpitations.

Diagnosis of primary hyperaldosteronism relies on measuring serum levels of aldosterone and plasma renin; patients with the condition will have elevated aldosterone and decreased renin levels. If an adrenal adenoma is suspected, further adrenal imaging is necessary to identify the location of the tumor(s). This distinction is necessary because treatment varies based on etiology. Bilateral adrenal adenomas are treated with aldosterone receptor antagonists, such as eplerenone and spironolactone. A unilateral adenoma, however, is preferably treated with surgery (unilateral adrenalectomy) in patients who are good surgical candidates.




Option Analysis

✅ Aldosterone receptor antagonist:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor:
Incorrect: Angiotensin-converting-enzyme (ACE) inhibitors are medications commonly used in the treatment of hypertension. However, this patient has persistent hypertension due to bilateral aldosterone-secreting adrenal tumors. Aldosterone receptor antagonists are the first-line treatment for this condition.
❌ Bilateral adrenalectomy :
Incorrect: Surgical resection (adrenalectomy) is indicated in patients with unilateral aldosterone secreting adenomas. In cases wherein the patient has bilateral adrenal adenomas, medical management is preferred over surgical intervention.
❌ Angiotensin receptor blocker:
Incorrect: Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) are drugs commonly used in the treatment of hypertension. However, this patient has persistent hypertension due to bilateral aldosterone-secreting adrenal tumors. Aldosterone receptor antagonists are the first-line treatment for her condition.
❌ Epithelial sodium receptor blocker:
Incorrect: Epithelial sodium channel blockers (e.g., triamterene, amiloride) are potassium-sparing diuretics. They are not indicated in this patient presenting with hyperaldosteronism due to bilateral adrenal adenomas.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents to a cardiologist for evaluation of a new heart murmur discovered at a routine health screening evaluation. The physician reads the report from this evaluation, which states that the patient was found to have a “crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur.” Auscultation at which of the following anatomic locations is most appropriate for reproducing this patient’s characteristic murmur?
questions.solution:
The characteristic crescendo-decresendo systolic ejection murmur described in the question stem refers to aortic stenosis, which is best appreciated over the second intercostal space along the right sternum. Several anatomic areas of the chest wall serve as landmarks for auscultation of different valves of the heart:  

  •  Aortic area: Right second intercostal space, parasternal. Aortic valve murmurs are heard best here, including aortic stenosis (systolic) and aortic regurgitation (diastolic).  
  • Pulmonic area: Left second intercostal space, parasternal. Pulmonic murmurs heard best here, like the systolic ejection murmur of pulmonic stenosis. Physiologic flow murmurs are also best heard here.
  • Tricuspid area: Left fourth intercostal space, parasternal. Diastolic murmurs associated with tricuspid stenosis or atrial septal defects can be heard here, as well as holosystolic murmurs from tricuspid regurgitation and ventricular septal defects. 
  • Mitral area: Left fifth intercostal space, mid-clavicular. One can hear the systolic murmurs from mitral regurgitation or mitral valve prolapse here, in addition to the diastolic mitral stenosis murmur.

Option Analysis

✅ A. :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ B. :
Incorrect: Choice B corresponds to the pulmonic area. This patient’s classic “crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur” is most likely from aortic stenosis, which is best heard over the aortic area (area A).
❌ C. :
Incorrect: Choice C corresponds to the tricuspid area.This patient’s classic “crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur” is most likely from aortic stenosis, which is best heard over the aortic area (area A).
❌ D. :
Incorrect: Choice D corresponds to the mitral area. This patient’s classic “crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur” is most likely from aortic stenosis, which is best heard over the aortic area (area A).
❌ E. :
Incorrect: Choice E does not correspond to a defined auscultatory location. This patient’s classic “crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur” is most likely from aortic stenosis, which is best heard over the aortic area (area A).

questions.text:
56-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain. Over the past week, the patient has been experiencing persistent chest pain, worsening with deep inhalation but not with exertion. The pain is described as “sharp,” and she states that she is also experiencing similar pain in her shoulders. Of note, she is currently receiving treatment for breast cancer. Past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and hyperthyroidism. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 107/min, respirations are 19/min, blood pressure is 110/64 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 95% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates a thin female with moderate tachypnea. Pulmonary auscultation reveals diminished breath sounds at the lung bases bilaterally. Cardiac auscultation reveals hyperdynamic S1 and S2 without gallups, rubs, or murmurs. Musculoskeletal examination of the back and upper extremities is unremarkable. The patient’s initial electrocardiogram is demonstrated below. Which of the following is the most likely anatomic location of this patient’s pain?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient with breast cancer presents with pleuritic chest pain, of which the differential diagnosis is broad. Potential causes include infectious, thrombotic, and inflammatory etiologies. Given this patient’s referred shoulder pain and diminished breath sounds, her presentation is most consistent with pleuritic chest pain secondary to pleural effusions and subsequent diaphragmatic irritation.  

Pleuritic chest pain refers to pain characterized by sudden and intensely sharp, stabbing, or burning pain in the chest when inhaling and exhaling. Most lung tissue does not contain somatic pain fibers, aside from the parietal pleural and the intercostal nerves that line the inner chest wall. Disease processes that irritate these nerve endings manifest with pleuritic pain. The list of potential causes for pleuritic chest pain is broad and includes pneumothorax, rheumatologic diseases, pneumonia, empyema, pulmonary embolism, pericarditis, and pleural effusions.   

Of note, pleural effusions and hemothoraces layer on the diaphragm, irritating it and resulting in referred pain to the shoulder. This phenomenon exists because the central diaphragm is innervated by the phrenic nerve, supplied by spinal levels C3, C4, and C5. These spinal levels also provide innervation to the root of the neck and shoulder.   

Option Analysis

✅ Central diaphragm :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pericardium:
Incorrect: Pericarditis is another common etiology of pleuritic chest pain. However, this patient’s electrocardiogram is without evidence of repolarization abnormalities or diffuse ST elevations and only demonstrates sinus tachycardia. As a result, the diagnosis of underlying pericarditis is unlikely in this patient.
❌ Superior aspect of the pleura :
Incorrect: Infection, malignancy, or thrombosis at the superior aspect of the pleura may result in pleuritic chest pain. However, this patient’s clinical presentation and physical exam are more consistent with bilateral pleural effusions and diaphragmatic irritation. 
❌ Left anterior descending artery :
Incorrect: Occlusion of the left anterior descending artery (LAD) manifests with cardiac chest pain, often described as pressure or “an elephant sitting on my chest.” It is less commonly associated with pleuritic chest pain. Most importantly, this patient's electrocardiogram does not show any anterior ST-segment changes.
❌ Pulmonary artery :
Incorrect: Pulmonary embolism is an essential diagnostic consideration in evaluating pleuritic chest pain. However, given this patient has diminished breath sounds bilaterally, her clinical presentation is more consistent with pleural effusions and diaphragmatic irritation.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider for evaluation of hypertension. The patient was seen in the emergency department last week for a laceration repair, and her systolic blood pressure was noted to be over 200 mmHg. She is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 225/102 mmHg in the right upper extremity and 210/97 in the left upper extremity. The patient has a 2/6 systolic murmur at the right upper sternal border. The patient’s lower extremities have scant hair bilaterally, and a brachiofemoral pulse delay is noted bilaterally. A portion of the patient’s chest radiograph is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient has uncontrolled hypertension, which is the most common presentation for adult patients with undiagnosed coarctation of the aorta. Clues to this diagnosis include an systolic ejection murmur (indicative of a bicuspid aortic valve), brachiofemoral pulse delay, and rib notching noted in the chest radiograph above.  

Coarctation of the aorta is an overall common congenital anomaly, accounting for approximately 6-8% of all congenital heart disease. This anatomic defect refers to a discrete narrowing of the descending aorta at the insertion of the ductus arteriosus, just distal to the left subclavian artery. The degree of defect varies amongst individuals. The condition has a high association with Turner syndrome and a bicuspid aortic valve.   

Due to the stenosis, patients develop hypertension in the upper extremities, diminished blood pressure in the lower extremities, and brachiofemoral pulse delay. In the thorax, notching of the posterior one-third of the third to eighth ribs occurs due to erosion caused by the formation of large collaterals in the intercostal arteries.  

Option Analysis

✅ Coarctation of the aorta :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Peripheral vascular disease :
Incorrect: Peripheral vascular disease can result in diminished or absent hair on the lower extremities. However, this condition would not account for the rib notching noted on the patient’s radiograph.   
❌ Abdominal aortic aneurysm :
Incorrect: An abdominal aortic aneurysm more commonly presents in patients with a long history of smoking and atherosclerotic disease. This diagnosis would not explain the rib notching noted on the patient’s radiograph. 
❌ Dilated cardiomyopathy:
Incorrect: Dilated cardiomyopathy more commonly presents with signs of congestive heart failure, such as lower extremity edema, shortness of breath, and an S3 heart sound. This patient’s heart sound indicates a possible bicuspid aortic valve.
❌ Subclavian artery stenosis :
Incorrect: Subclavian steal syndrome refers to a phenomenon that occurs with severe stenosis of the subclavian artery proximal to the ipsilateral vertebral artery. It can manifest with exercise-induced ischemia of the affected limb.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain and productive cough yielding thick, yellowish sputum. The symptoms developed three days ago. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. The patient consumes 2-3 glasses of alcohol and one pack of cigarettes daily. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), blood pressure is 167/90 mmHg, pulse is 108/min, and respiratory rate is 18/min. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds in the left lower lung field. Radiographic imaging is demonstrated below. Which of the following structures is most obscured as a result of this patient’s disease process?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient has a left parapneumonic effusion, obscuring the left cardiac border. The inferior portions of the left cardiac border are formed by the left ventricle.  

Key anatomical landmarks seen on chest x-rays are as follows:



Option Analysis

✅ Left ventricle:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Aortic knob:
Incorrect: A left upper lobe consolidation or mass can obscure the aortic knob. However, this patient has a parapneumonic effusion in the dependent portions of the left lung field, which obscures the inferior left cardiac border formed by the left ventricle.
❌ Carina:
Incorrect: The carina refers to the anatomic location where the trachea branches into the left and right mainstem bronchi. The carina is not obscured by this patient’s left parapneumonic effusion.
❌ Right diaphragm:
Incorrect: While there is mild blunting of the right costophrenic angle, the right diaphragm is overall unremarkable. In contrast, the patient has a large left parapneumonic effusion that is obscuring the inferior portions of the left cardiac border.
❌ Left atrium:
Incorrect: A left upper lobe consolidation or mass can obscure the left atrium. However, this patient has a parapneumonic effusion in the dependent portions of the left lung field. This pathology obscures the inferior left cardiac border, which is formed by the left ventricle.

questions.text: A 51-year-old female presents for a follow-up appointment with an infectious disease specialist. The patient has a history of HIV and has been intermittently compliant with antiretroviral therapy. She has been staying in a shelter with several individuals who have active tuberculosis infection. Her most recent CD4 count was 167/mm3. The patient undergoes a screening Mantoux skin test, which is negative. However, there is strong suspicion for underlying anergy. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment regimen for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has recent exposure to individuals with known tuberculosis. She has a history of untreated HIV and a compromised immune system, as evidenced by her most recent CD4 count and anergic response to a screening PPD exam. Based on this criteria, she should undergo prophylactic treatment with isoniazid therapy.   

Isoniazid is the only regimen used as prophylactic treatment for patients at risk of acquiring tuberculosis. Susceptible individuals include those with untreated HIV, solid organ transplantation, hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, or compromised immune systems. If an individual has one of these aforementioned characteristics and is at risk of being exposed to tuberculosis, then they should be considered for isoniazid prophylaxis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Isoniazid monotherapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Streptomycin monotherapy:
Incorrect: Streptomycin is considered a second-line agent in the treatment of Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection. It is not used for prophylactic treatment of tuberculosis.   
❌  Daptomycin monotherapy:
Incorrect: Daptomycin is a lipopeptide that disrupts the cell wall of Gram positive cocci. The medication can be used to treat methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, bacteremia, and endocarditis. It is not used in the treatment of Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection. 
❌ Rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol :
Incorrect: Rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol (RIPE) therapy is first-line treatment for active tuberculosis. It is not clinically indicated for prophylactic treatment of tuberculosis. 
❌ Azithromycin and ethambutol :
Incorrect: The combination of azithromycin and ethambutol is utilized in the treatment of Mycobacterium avium complex infection. However, it is not used for prophylaxis against Mycobacterium tuberculosis

questions.text: A 49-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of severe pain in the left knee. He also notes that the knee feels warm and looks red. The patient has not had similar symptoms before. Past medical history is significant for hyperlipidemia and hypertension. Current medications are pravastatin and lisinopril. He does not drink alcohol but has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 22 years. He drinks 2-3 cups of coffee daily. He drinks 2 glasses of milk every day prior to bed because it “helps him sleep.” Vital signs are within normal limits. BMI is 37 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Physical examination reveals swelling, erythema, and warmth of the left knee joint. It is tender to palpation with decreased active and passive range of motion. Arthrocentesis of the joint yields turbid fluid with a leukocyte count of 17,100/mm<sup>3</sup>. Gram stain is negative. Polarized light microscopy shows yellow, negatively birefringent crystals. Which of the following lifestyle changes is most likely to reduce recurrence of his current episode?

choices.text: Begin drinking one glass of red wine daily

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs and diagnostic studies suggestive of an acute gout attack. Gout is caused by precipitation of elevated uric acid in the serum, resulting in crystal deposition in joints. Elevated uric acid levels are the result of overproduction or underexcretion of uric acid. Obesity is conclusively linked to higher serum levels of uric acid; adipose cells partake in purine degradation, and therefore, increased adipose tissue results in increased purine breakdown. Weight-loss can help lower serum uric acid and potentially decrease the risk of future attacks.



Option Analysis

✅ Weight reduction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Begin drinking one glass of red wine daily :
Incorrect: Any alcohol consumption, including beer, wine and spirits, is associated with a greater risk of gout flare in patients with established gout. 
❌ Cessation of cigarette smoking  :
Incorrect: Cigarette smoking is actually associated with a lower incidence of gout. Although cessation of smoking can result in multiple health benefits, reducing the risk of recurrence of this patient’s gout is not one of them. 
❌ Daily low-dose aspirin therapy :
Incorrect: Low-dose aspirin therapy can inhibit URAT1, a urate transporter involved in excreting uric acid into the urine. Inhibition of this transporter results in decreased uric acid excretion into the urine, potentially increasing the risk of future gout flare-ups. 
❌ Reduce coffee consumption:
Incorrect: Coffee consumption is linked with decreased levels of serum uric acid. Reducing coffee consumption in this patient, therefore, would not reduce the risk of gout recurrence. 
❌ Increase seafood consumption :
Incorrect: Seafood consumption, along with red meat consumption, is associated with higher levels of serum uric acid. The likely explanation is that these foods contain high levels of purines and should therefore be avoided in patients trying to prevent gout recurrence.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man presents to the primary care physician with a several week history of worsening fatigue, blurry vision, and rectal bleeding. Medical history is notable for ulcerative colitis, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. The patient’s last colonoscopy was at age 50. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 122/63 mmHg. BMI is 34 kg/m2. Physical examination demonstrates an obese habitus. The patient’s skin appears pale with noted conjunctival pallor.
