Constipation and blurred vision are common adverse effects in all age groups. Other adverse effects include dry mouth, flushed skin, dizziness, confusion, and delirium.  



Option Analysis

✅ Urinary retention:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Scleritis:
Incorrect: Scleritis is an inflammatory condition characterized by inflammation and redness of the sclera. Patients will experience severe eye pain and photophobia. Atropine exacerbates acute angle-closure glaucoma via pupil dilation, but not scleritis.  
❌ Migraine with aura:
Incorrect: Common precipitants for migraine with aura include caffeine, stress, and hormonal changes. Atropine is not known to precipitate migraines.  
❌ Flank pain with hematuria:
Incorrect: Patients who consume ethylene glycol, a common antifreeze component, can present with flank pain with hematuria secondary to renal stone formation. Although atropine can cause urinary retention, it does not precipitate stone formation in the kidneys.
❌ Respiratory depression:
Incorrect: Respiratory depression is a fatal side effect of benzodiazepine overdose. Atropine causes bronchodilation and is unlikely to affect the respiratory drive.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency department during the winter due to shortness of breath and a productive cough. The symptoms have progressively worsened over the past two years, and the patient has had to limit his daily activities to avoid becoming short of breath. Each morning, he coughs up large quantities of viscous sputum. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include lisinopril and metformin. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 147/98 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. Physical examination reveals a markedly increased anteroposterior chest diameter. Cardiopulmonary examination reveals tachycardia and poor air movement bilaterally with scattered expiratory wheezes. A chest radiograph is obtained and shown below. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for managing this patient’s symptoms?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with shortness of breath, a productive cough, and a chest radiograph demonstrating hyperinflated lungs. These findings are concerning for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The best initial step in management includes administering antimuscarinic medications such as ipratropium.  

Ipratropium and tiotropium are muscarinic antagonists that work as bronchodilators. They are usually given via inhalers, where they enter the lungs and bind to muscarinic receptors on the tracheal and bronchial smooth muscles, causing smooth muscle relaxation and bronchial dilation. These properties make them effective in treating chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and asthma. What sets them apart, mainly, is their duration of action. Ipratropium is short-acting, whereas tiotropium is long-acting.  

Option Analysis

❌ Tamsulosin:
Incorrect: Tamsulosin is an alpha-adrenergic blocker used to manage benign prostatic hyperplasia and hypertension. In contrast, this patient presents with shortness of breath, productive cough, and hyperexpanded lungs. These findings are more concerning for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), which is not managed with tamsulosin.  
❌ Pramipexole:
Incorrect: Pramipexole is a dopamine agonist used in the treatment of Parkinson disease, prolactinoma, and restless leg syndrome. It has no proven role in the management of COPD.  
✅ Ipratropium:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Propranolol:
Incorrect: Propranolol is a beta-blocker that can cause bronchoconstriction and may exacerbate this patient’s COPD symptoms. In patients with severe pulmonary symptoms and reactive airway disease, the medication should be cautioned.    
❌ Clonidine:
Incorrect: Clonidine is an alpha-2 agonist used to manage hypertension. It is not used to treat COPD.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to the primary care office with three days of abdominal bloating. The patient recently moved to a new house and has been eating takeout food for dinner frequently. The patient reports it has been more difficult to have a bowel movement than usual, and it requires him to strain significantly. The last bowel movement was two days ago, and he reports it was the only one he has had this week. Past surgical history is significant for an appendectomy at age 28. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 132/80 mmHg. The abdomen is soft with mild tenderness in the left lower quadrant on deep palpation. Which of the following is the most important feature to ask about in order to determine if there is an associated bowel obstruction?

choices.text: Use of manual maneuvers to help move stool out of the rectum
Feeling of incomplete evacuation after bowel movements

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with symptoms of constipation, including difficulty passing stools and infrequent passing of stool. When evaluating a patient with new onset constipation, it is important to ask about the ability to pass gas since obstipation (inability to pass stool and gas) can be a sign of bowel obstruction, which may require supportive care and surgery.

Constipation occurs when stool is unable to move through the bowel properly and/or the pelvic muscles or anal sphincter are unable to facilitate adequate emptying. This may lead to straining with defecation, infrequent bowel movements, a feeling of incomplete emptying, and needing to use manual maneuvers to defecate. Hard stools are a common feature of constipation and the Bristol stool chart can be used to help patients describe their stool objectively based on shape and texture. Abdominal discomfort and bloating may be present. Having less than three bowel movements per week is also suggestive of constipation, although not required for diagnosis.

Physical examination in patients presenting with constipation should include visual inspection of the anal area and a digital rectal exam (DRE). Common findings on DRE are a palpable stool ball or fecal impaction. Patients should be asked to “bear down” or strain as if trying to have a bowel movement during the exam to allow for assessment of sphincter tone and the strength of surrounding musculature. Abnormalities of the sphincter or musculature may suggest an underlying neurologic etiology. Finally, patients should be assessed for anal fissures, hemorrhoids, masses, tenderness, or strictures during the DRE and visual exam.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Hard stools:
Incorrect: Hard stools are common in constipation and would not indicate bowel obstruction.  
❌ Use of manual maneuvers to help move stool out of the rectum:
Incorrect: Needing to use manual maneuvers for stool evacuation is common in constipation; however, it would not be suggestive of a bowel obstruction.  
✅ Ability to pass gas:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Feeling of incomplete evacuation after bowel movements:
Incorrect: A feeling of incomplete emptying is common in constipation and would not indicate a large bowel obstruction.  
❌ Date of last colonoscopy:
Incorrect: Colonoscopy history may help in making the differential diagnosis and evaluating constipation, but it would not help determine if a bowel obstruction is present.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents to the office for a follow-up appointment after he is found to have elevated aspartate and alanine transaminase levels on laboratory testing. He has not experienced abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, or fatigue. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include lisinopril, metformin, glyburide, and aspirin. He drinks alcohol socially and has a 30-pack-year smoking history. The patient also has a history of intravenous drug use and was undomiciled in his early 30s. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory results are shown below. The patient is started on interferon-ɑ therapy. This drug works via which of the following mechanisms?  

Laboratory Value
Result
Hemoglobin
12.5 g/dL  
Leukocyte count  
8,000 mm3   
Platelet count  
230,000 mm3   
Viral profile   

HAV IgM  
Negative
HAV IgG  
Positive
HBsAg  
Positive
HBeAg
Negative
HBV IgG  
Positive
HCV IgG  
Positive
HCV RNA  
100,000,000 IU/ml

choices.text: Inhibition of virion release from infected cells
Prevention of viral entry into the target cell

questions.solution:
This patient has elevated liver enzymes and hepatitis C virus (HCV) IgG titers, and high HCV RNA levels. These findings are consistent with HCV infection, and the patient is started on interferon-alpha (IFN-α) therapy.

Interferons (IFNs) are cytokines that exhibit a broad spectrum of antiviral activities and immunomodulating and antiproliferative properties. Currently, only two types of interferons are available for clinical use: IFNα2A and IFNα2B.

The selective antiviral action of IFN-α is primarily due to its ability to activate host cell ribonucleases that preferentially degrade viral mRNA. IFN-α also promotes the formation of natural killer cells that destroy liver cells infected by HCV. It is usually given either as an intramuscular or subcutaneous injection. Sometimes INFs can be provided in pegylated IFN (i.e. IFN plus polyethylene glycol).

IFNs are used in the treatment of both chronic HBV and HCV infections. When treating HCV infection, IFNs are used either as monotherapy or in combination with other antiviral medications such as ribavirin. Other indications include herpes virus infection, papillomavirus infection, and Kaposi sarcoma occurring in the setting of HIV infection.

Side effects of IFN-α include flu-like symptoms (e.g., fever, malaise, nausea, vomiting), bone marrow suppression leading to neutropenia and thrombocytopenia, neurotoxicity (e.g., sleepiness, depression, behavioral disturbances), and liver dysfunction leading to elevated liver enzymes. It can also cause alopecia, which is more common in children.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Activation of host cell ribonuclease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibition of viral protease activity:
Incorrect: Protease inhibitors are drugs that inhibit the action of HIV-1 protease, an enzyme that cleaves precursor proteins into smaller fragments. These fragments are needed for viral growth, infectivity, and replication. Examples of protease inhibitors include ritonavir and indinavir.  
❌ Inhibition of virion release from infected cells:
Incorrect: Neuraminidase inhibitors (NAIs) are a class of medication that can treat influenza infection by preventing viral progeny release from the host cells. Examples of NAIs include zanamivir and oseltamivir.  
❌ Prevention of viral entry into the target cell:
Incorrect: Enfuvirtide blocks the action of viral fusion proteins and prevents the virus from entering the target cell. It is an antiretroviral agent used in the management of HIV infection. In contrast, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with hepatitis C virus infection.  
❌ Inhibition of viral DNA replication:
Incorrect: Hepatitis B medications, including nucleoside analogs (e.g., entecavir, lamivudine) and nucleotide analogs (e.g., adefovir, tenofovir), are incorporated into growing viral DNA strands. Once these analogs have been incorporated, no additional nucleotides can be added, and DNA synthesis stops. Interferon-ɑ, however, works via a different mechanism of action.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman comes to the office for a general physical examination. The patient has not been to a physician in the last 20 years. The patient frequently experiences fatigue and dull abdominal pain. Past medical history is significant for a diagnosis of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus in her 40s, but these conditions remain untreated. The patient received a blood transfusion several decades ago following complicated childbirth. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory results are shown below. The patient is started on a combination of sofosbuvir and daclatasvir. Daclatasvir acts via the inhibition of which of the following?  

Laboratory Value
Result
Hemoglobin
12.5 g/dL  
Leukocyte count  
8,000 mm3   
Platelet count  
230,000 mm3   
Viral profile  

HAV IgM  
Negative
HAV IgG  
Positive
HBsAg
Positive
HBeAg
Negative
HBV IgG  
Positive
HCV IgG  
Positive
HCV RNA  
100,000,000 IU/ml

choices.text: Viral entry into the target cell

questions.solution:
This patient presents with fatigue, dull abdominal pain, elevated hepatitis C virus (HCV) IgG titers, and high HCV RNA levels. These findings are consistent with HCV infection. The patient is started on sofosbuvir and daclatasvir.

Daclatasvir is an NS5A inhibitor often used in combination with sofosbuvir to treat HCV infection. NS5A is a membrane-associated phosphoprotein part of the HCV RNA replication complex and is essential for viral replication and assembly. Inhibition of this phosphoprotein prevents HCV RNA replication. Other NS5A inhibitors include elbasvir, ledipasvir, ombitasvir, and velpatasvir.

Side effects associated with NS5A inhibitor use include mild to moderate headache, fatigue, and gastrointestinal irritation. Daclatasvir is primarily metabolized through CYP3A metabolism and should not be given strong inducers or inhibitors of this enzyme.  

Option Analysis

❌ Viral DNA polymerase:
Incorrect: Hepatitis medications, including nucleoside analogs (e.g., entecavir, lamivudine) and nucleotide analogs (e.g., adefovir, tenofovir), are incorporated into growing viral DNA and RNA strands. Once these analogs have been incorporated, viral polymerase, and the synthesis of genetic material stops, no additional nucleotides can be added. In contrast, daclatasvir works via a different mechanism of action.  
✅ HCV-encoded proteins:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase:
Incorrect: Ribavirin is an antiviral medication that inhibits viral production of guanine nucleotides through competitive inhibition of inosine monophosphate (IMP) dehydrogenase. It is usually used as an adjunct to interferon therapy.  
❌ Virion release from infected cells:
Incorrect: Neuraminidase inhibitors (NAIs) are a class of medication that blocks the enzyme neuraminidase. NAIs can be used to treat influenza infection by preventing viral progeny release from the host cells. Examples of NAIs include zanamivir and oseltamivir.  
❌ Viral entry into the target cell:
Incorrect: Enfuvirtide blocks the action of viral fusion proteins and prevents the virus from entering the target cell. It is an antiretroviral agent used in the management of HIV infection. In contrast, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with hepatitis C virus infection.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 4-day history of fatigue. Review of systems is negative, except that she has been experiencing increased knee pain recently. Her past medical history is significant for hypertension, for which she takes lisinopril, and osteoarthritis, for which she takes over-the-counter ibuprofen. Temperature is 98.9 F, pulse is 70/min, blood pressure is 140/86 mmHg, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Mucous membranes appear moist. Stool guaiac is negative. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following historical features would most likely be the underlying cause of this patient’s acute renal injury?  

Laboratory Test  
Result
Sodium
135 g/dL  
Potassium
5.2 mEq/L  
Chloride
105 mEq/L  
Bicarbonate
29 mEq/L  
BUN
30 mg/dL  
Creatinine
1.8 mg/dL (baseline 1.0)  
Hemoglobin
10 g/dL  
Urinalysis
unremarkable

choices.text: Recent use of high doses of ibuprofen multiple times a day

questions.solution:
This patient presents with prerenal AKI and recent knee pain from osteoarthritis. The most likely cause of AKI would be recent use of high doses of ibuprofen multiple times a day. Frequent and high doses of NSAIDs in combination with lisinopril can lead to decreased renal perfusion.

Acute kidney injury (AKI) refers to a sudden compromise of kidney function, leading to an increase in nitrogenous waste in the blood including creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN). AKI can be defined as any of the following:
  
  • Increase in serum creatinine by at least 0.3 mg/dL within 48 hours 
  • Increase in serum creatinine by at least 1.5 times baseline (which is known or presumed to have been drawn within the prior 7 days) 
  • Decreased urine output of less than 0.5 ml/kg/h for 6 hours.  
AKI can be characterized as prerenal, intrinsic renal, or postrenal. Prerenal AKI, also known as prerenal azotemia, refers to AKI that occurs when renal perfusion becomes impaired, affecting the kidney’s ability to remove the nitrogenous wastes from the blood. The causes of prerenal AKI can be grouped into four main categories, which include medications, hypovolemia, systemic vasodilation, and decreased cardiac output. Drugs like NSAIDs, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, and angiotensin II blockers affect glomerular hemodynamics and reduce the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) by lowering the intraglomerular pressure.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Recent use of high doses of ibuprofen multiple times a day:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Recent travel:
Incorrect: Recent travel history could provide insight into infectious etiologies or environmental exposures that can impact renal function (e.g. gastroenteritis). In this patient who is taking NSAIDs for pain from osteoarthritis in combination with lisinopril, increased doses and frequency of NSAIDs would be the most likely cause of prerenal AKI.  
❌ Family history of kidney disease:
Incorrect: A family history of kidney disease can suggest a genetic predisposition to intrinsic renal pathologies or chronic kidney disease. This patient’s acute presentation and history of NSAID use in combination with lisinopril points to increased doses and frequency of NSAIDs as  the most likely cause of prerenal AKI.  
❌ Heavy metal exposure:
Incorrect: Exposure to industrial chemicals (e.g. heavy metals) can lead to nephrotoxicity and acute kidney injury, primarily through direct renal tubular damage. In this patient with prerenal AKI, increased doses and frequency of NSAIDs would be the most likely cause of prerenal AKI.  
❌ Recent use of antibiotics:
Incorrect: The use of certain antibiotics like aminoglycosides can lead to nephrotoxicity. In this patient, recent increased NSAID use in combination with lisinopril is the most likely cause of prerenal AKI.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his daughter with a 2-day history of fever, productive cough, and worsening shortness of breath. The patient has a history of prostate cancer that is currently being treated with chemotherapy and radiation. The patient is able to void freely. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), blood pressure is 85/50 mmHg, pulse is 115 beats/min, respiratory rate is 28 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. Physical examination reveals respiratory distress, use of accessory muscles. The skin of the upper and lower extremities appears flush and warm to palpation. Cardiac exam is unremarkable. Pulmonary exam reveals rhonchi at the right lower lung base. Chest X-ray demonstrates a right lower lobe consolidation. Laboratory studies reveal a serum creatinine of 3.5 mg/dL (baseline 1.2 mg/dL) and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 44 mg/dL. Urinalysis is unremarkable. Lactate is 5 mmol/L, and blood cultures/sputum cultures are pending. The patient is started on broad-spectrum antibiotics. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's elevated BUN and serum creatinine?

choices.text: Systemic vasodilation due to septic shock

questions.solution:
The patient has pneumonia complicated by sepsis: fever, productive cough, hypotension, tachycardia, elevated lactate levels, and evidence of organ dysfunction (elevated creatinine indicating AKI). Sepsis induces systemic vasodilation, and with the kidneys being particularly sensitive to alterations in perfusion, it can result in prerenal acute kidney injury (AKI).

AKI can be characterized as prerenal, intrinsic renal, or postrenal. Prerenal AKI, also known as prerenal azotemia, refers to situations where renal perfusion is impaired, affecting the kidney’s ability to remove nitrogenous waste products from the blood. Causes of prerenal AKI include medications, hypovolemia, systemic vasodilation, and decreased cardiac output.

Septic shock is defined by a profound systemic inflammatory response to an infection that results in widespread vasodilation. Vasodilation, in turn, leads to a decrease in systemic vascular resistance. Though cardiac output increases as a compensatory response, it cannot offset the significant decrease in systemic vascular resistance, leading to hypoperfusion of vital organs, including the kidneys.  

Option Analysis

❌ Hypovolemia due to fluid losses:
Incorrect: This patient's presentation indicates that sepsis secondary to pneumonia is the most likely cause of prerenal acute kidney injury. In septic shock, the vasodilatory changes, rather than volume depletion, are the cause of decreased renal perfusion and AKI.  
❌ Direct renal parenchymal injury:
Incorrect: Primary kidney injury in septic shock typically results from systemic vasodilation, which reduces renal perfusion. This patient's urinalysis lacks findings, such as muddy brown casts, which would indicate intrinsic renal damage and acute tubular necrosis.  
❌ Decreased cardiac output:
Incorrect: Cardiogenic shock can result in acute kidney injury due to decreased renal perfusion. This patient’s history, physical exam, and Chest x-ray findings suggest that sepsis is the cause of AKI.  
❌ Urinary tract obstruction:
Incorrect: Prostate cancer could predispose this patient to develop a urinary tract obstruction; however, this patient is able to void freely, and sepsis is most likely the cause of AKI.  
✅ Systemic vasodilation due to septic shock:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the office because of easy fatigability and pain in his legs after walking a block. The pain resolves after resting for a few minutes and is worse going downhill than uphill. The rest of the systemic review is noncontributory. Past medical history is significant for hypertension managed with lisinopril. Family history is significant for myocardial infarction in the patient’s father. He has a 35-pack-year smoking history. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows decreased popliteal and dorsalis pedis pulses and normal femoral pulses in the lower extremities bilaterally. The ankle-brachial index is 0.6 on the left and 0.75 on the right. He is initiated on low-dose aspirin, atorvastatin, and a supervised exercise program. On his three months follow-up, the patient reports minimal improvement in walking. Which of the following is the best next step in managing this patient?

choices.text: Add cilostazol to the medication regimen
Computed tomography angiography followed by stenting
Add warfarin to the medication regimen
Continue the same therapy with regular follow-up

questions.solution:
This patient’s clinical presentation with intermittent leg pain on exertion (claudication), in combination with decreased pulses in lower extremities and ankle-brachial index of ≤ 0.90 bilaterally, is consistent with peripheral artery disease (PAD). PAD is a coronary disease risk equivalent and requires aggressive risk factor management with smoking cessation, aspirin, lipid-lowering therapy, and a supervised exercise program. Patients who fail to improve require additional pharmacotherapy with cilostazol.

Cilostazol is a phosphodiesterase-3 inhibitor (another example is dipyridamole) that suppresses the degradation of cyclic AMP (cAMP) in platelets. Increased concentrations of cAMP subsequently lead to increased concentrations of the active form of protein kinase A (PKA), which is directly related to the inhibition of platelet aggregation. It is also a direct arterial vasodilator (increased cGMP in vascular smooth muscle cells), but its mechanism in improving walking distance among patients with PAD is unknown. It is mainly indicated in managing PAD, coronary artery disease (CAD), and the secondary prevention of ischemic stroke and transient ischemic attack (TIA) combined with aspirin. Dipyridamole is also used in cardiac stress testing. Common side effects include dizziness, headaches, palpitations, and gastrointestinal disturbance.  

Option Analysis

✅ Add cilostazol to the medication regimen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Computed tomography angiography followed by stenting:
Incorrect: Percutaneous revascularization via stenting is indicated in patients with PAD fails to improve or show satisfactory response with a year of exercise therapy, and adjunctive pharmacotherapy. It should not be pursued in this patient without a trial of cilostazol.  
❌ Add warfarin to the medication regimen:
Incorrect: Warfarin is an anticoagulant and is not shown to improve symptoms of intermittent claudication. It is not recommended for this patient.  
❌ Continue the same therapy with regular follow-up:
Incorrect: This patient has failed to improve with exercise therapy and secondary prevention of adverse cardiovascular events. A step-up therapy with cilostazol is indicated in such patients.  
❌ Catheter-directed thrombolytic therapy:
Incorrect: Catheter-directed thrombolytic therapy is usually indicated in individuals with acute deep vein thrombosis associated with severe symptomatic swelling or extensive thrombosis of the proximal or iliofemoral vein. It has no role in the management of PAD.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a follow-up appointment. The patient was diagnosed with HIV infection ten months ago and initiated on a medication that inhibits the virus’s ability to cleave Gag-Pol polyproteins. Today, the patient has no acute symptoms and is feeling well. In addition to HIV infection, past medical history is notable for hypertension and seasonal allergies. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 155/87 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. Physical examination is unremarkable. No lymphadenopathy, tonsillar swelling, or oral thrush is observed. Laboratory testing is shown below. Which of the following additional physical exam findings is this patient at most significant risk of developing in the future?  

Laboratory Value  
Results (U.S. Conventional Units)  
Results (S.I. Units)  
Hemoglobin
12.7 g/dL  
1.91 mmol/L  
Leukocyte Count  
9,000/mm3   
9.0*109/L  
CD4 T-Cell count  
850/mm3   
0.85*109/L  
Glucose (fasting)  
210 mg/dL  
11.7 mmol/L  
Triglycerides
370 mg/dL  
20.5 mmol/L

choices.text: Reduced pinprick sensation in the bilateral upper extremities
Epigastric pain radiating towards the back
Increased dorsocervical and abdominal adipose tissue
Blistering and desquamation of the skin and mucous membranes

questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with HIV infection and initiated on a medication that prevents the virus from cleaving the Gag-Pol polyprotein. Laboratory results are notable for hyperglycemia and hyperlipidemia. As a result, this patient was likely started on a protease inhibitor, which can lead to lipodystrophy.

Protease inhibitors bind and inhibit HIV-1 protease, thereby preventing the virus from processing the Gag-Pol polyprotein into its functional parts and thus impeding viral replication. Protease inhibitors are generally used with other medications as part of highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART).

A common side effect of protease inhibitors is metabolic disorders, such as insulin resistance, hyperglycemia, and hyperlipidemia. These metabolic disorders are often followed by lipodystrophy. Lipodystrophy is characterized by abnormal accumulation of fat tissue in the abdomen, breasts (in women), and around the cervical vertebrae and loss of fat in the extremities and face. As a result, affected patients will classically have thin extremities, emaciated-appearing faces, and truncal obesity. Some studies have reported the incidence of lipodystrophy to be over 50% in patients taking protease inhibitors.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Reduced pinprick sensation in the bilateral upper extremities:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes peripheral neuropathy associated with nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) such as lamivudine stavudine and didanosine. Although NRTIs can cause hyperglycemia and hyperlipidemia as side effects, these medications function by inhibiting viral reverse transcriptase, not by inhibiting viral cleavage of the Gag-Pol polyprotein. In contrast, peripheral neuropathy in protease inhibitor use is rare.  
❌ Unilateral calf erythema and swelling:
Incorrect: A deep vein thrombosis (DVT) can manifest with unilateral calf erythema, swelling, and pain. However, the incidence of DVT or pulmonary embolism after initiating protease inhibitor therapy is infrequent, with some studies reporting the incidence rate to be less than 2%. In contrast, this patient already has laboratory findings suggestive of metabolic disorder (e.g., hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia) and is at a far greater risk of developing lipodystrophy secondary to protease inhibitor use.  
❌ Epigastric pain radiating towards the back:
Incorrect: Certain nucleotide/nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) can cause pancreatitis, which classically manifests with epigastric pain radiating to the back. In contrast, the instance of pancreatitis following protease inhibitor therapy is rare. Furthermore, although this patient has hypertriglyceridemia, triglyceride levels exceeding 1000 mg/dL are generally required to increase an individual’s risk of developing pancreatitis significantly.  
✅ Increased dorsocervical and abdominal adipose tissue:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Blistering and desquamation of the skin and mucous membranes:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS), which affects less than 30% of the total skin surface and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN), which affects more than 30% of the total skin surface. Patients on non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) therapy are at risk of developing SJS/TEN. In contrast, this patient was initiated on a protease inhibitor, which has a higher likelihood of causing metabolic syndrome and lipodystrophy than SJS/TEN.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents to the emergency department because of severe, right-sided abdominal pain. The pain began earlier in the day, fluctuating in intensity, and radiated towards the groin. She has also experienced nausea and one episode of non-bloody, non-bilious emesis after symptom onset. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, asthma, and HIV infection. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), blood pressure is 142/79 mmHg, and pulse is 97/min. Physical examination reveals right abdominal tenderness that is exacerbated by deep palpation. No costovertebral angle tenderness is present. The most recent CD4 count is 1,200/mm3. Urinalysis is shown below. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for this patient’s current symptoms?  

Laboratory Value  
Results
White blood cells  
1-2/hpf  
Red blood cells  
50/hpf  
Bacterial
Negative
Nitrites
Negative
Leukocyte esterase  
Negative
questions.solution:
This patient presents with abdominal pain radiating towards the groin, nausea, vomiting, and hematuria on urinalysis. She likely has nephrolithiasis. Among the medications listed to treat HIV infection, indinavir is most strongly associated with nephrolithiasis.

Indinavir is a protease inhibitor. It binds and inhibits HIV-1 protease, thereby preventing the virus from processing Gag-Pol polyproteins into its functional parts and thus impeding viral replication.

As with other protease inhibitors, indinavir can cause gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., diarrhea, nausea, vomiting), metabolic disorders (e.g., hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia), and lipodystrophy. Furthermore, patients on indinavir may develop nephrolithiasis and associated hematuria. Nephrolithiasis occurs since around 20% of the drug molecules are renally excreted and may subsequently aggregate to form stones. Therefore, individuals treated with indinavir should maintain good hydration to reduce the risk of nephrolithiasis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Acyclovir:
Incorrect: Acyclovir is a guanosine analog that inhibits viral DNA polymerase. The medication can treat infection by the herpes simplex virus (HSV) or varicella-zoster virus (VZV). Although acyclovir can cause crystalline nephropathy and nephrolithiasis, this patient has no indications warranting acyclovir treatment. As a result, it is unlikely that acyclovir is responsible for the patient’s symptoms.  
❌ Zidovudine:
Incorrect: Zidovudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) used to treat HIV infection. The medication can cause side effects, including anemia, leukopenia, lactic acidosis, and lipodystrophy. However, the medication is not typically associated with nephrolithiasis.  
✅ Indinavir:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Efavirenz:
Incorrect: Efavirenz is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) used to treat HIV infection. It can cause side effects, including hepatotoxicity, hypersensitivity rash, and vivid dreams. However, the medication is not typically associated with nephrolithiasis.  
❌ Ritonavir:
Incorrect: Ritonavir is a protease inhibitor that prevents HIV from cleaving the Gag-Pol protein into its functional parts, hindering viral replication. The various protease inhibitors can cause hyperlipidemia, hyperglycemia, and lipodystrophy as side effects. Nephrolithiasis, in contrast, tends to be more strongly associated with the protease inhibitor indinavir.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of a painful rash over the left side of his face for the past four days. He reports his symptoms were preceded by malaise and low grade fevers at home. He has a history of hypertension, diabetes, and chickenpox in his youth. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 154/70 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination, a vesicular rash is noted in the V1 distribution over the left face. Several vesicles are noted over the distal left tip of the nose. The rash does not cross the midline of the face. Mental status and neurologic exams are within normal limits. Which of the following diagnostic studies should be performed next?

choices.text: Fluorescein stain of the left eye

questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is consistent with herpes zoster infection (shingles). There is evidence of infection in the V1 distribution of the trigeminal nerve with a rash at the tip of the nose (Hutchinson sign). These findings warrant further investigation of ocular involvement with fluorescein staining to rule out herpes zoster ophthalmicus. If present, fluorescein staining will reveal epithelial keratitis that can evolve into pseudodendrites.

Herpes zoster infection, also known as shingles, occurs in individuals who have had a primary infection with the varicella-zoster virus. Following the primary infection (“chickenpox”), the virus remains dormant in the dorsal root ganglia of spinal nerves or the trigeminal ganglion. In times of stress or immunosuppression, the virus can reactivate and travel down the sensory neurons, causing herpes zoster.

Patients with herpes zoster classically present with a unilateral rash that does not cross midline that is present in 1 or 2 adjacent dermatomes. The rash initially begins as a maculopapular rash that progresses to vesicles and may coalesce to bullae. The rash typically lasts between 10-15 days. Patients often have a prodrome of malaise, headache, and low grade fever prior to the appearance of the rash. Herpes zoster ophthalmicus occurs when the virus reactivates in the trigeminal ganglion and travels down the ophthalmic nerve. This can affect all parts of the eye, including the retina, and can cause retinal detachment and necrosis, which can compromise longstanding vision. When this rash is present over the face in a V1 distribution, a thorough ocular examination should be performed.  

Option Analysis

✅ Fluorescein stain of the left eye:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ HIV viral load:
Incorrect: Patients with herpes zoster may be screened for HIV as it is a risk factor for developing the condition. However, the V1 distribution in this case confers a high risk for herpes zoster ophthalmicus, warranting a thorough evaluation of the eye.  
❌ Tzanck smear:
Incorrect: Tzanck smear can be performed if the diagnosis of herpes zoster remains unclear, but the diagnosis can be made clinically in this case.  
❌ Lumbar puncture:
Incorrect: Lumbar puncture should be performed for patients with evidence of herpes zoster and encephalitis. This patient has no evidence of encephalitis.  
❌ Viral culture:
Incorrect: Varicella zoster viral culture can be performed if the diagnosis of herpes zoster remains unclear. In this patient, the diagnosis can be made clinically.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of a painful red rash for the past three days. He reports burning over the skin as well as generalized malaise prior to the onset of the rash. He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. He has a history of chickenpox in childhood. Temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), blood pressure is 145/70 mmHg, pulse is 89/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. The patient’s rash is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the best next step for diagnosing his condition?
 

Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is consistent with herpes zoster infection (shingles), which can be diagnosed clinically based on the presence of a typical rash. The typical rash is a unilateral, erythematous maculopapular or vesicular rash that is in 1 or 2 adjacent dermatomes.

The rash of herpes zoster typically lasts between 10-15 days. Patients often have a prodrome of malaise, headache, and low grade fevers prior to the appearance of the rash. When the diagnosis is unclear, further testing can include Tzanck smear, viral culture, serology, and PCR. Patients with concern for disseminated herpes zoster, which can present with associated hepatitis, encephalitis, or meningitis, require further workup with a lumbar puncture, blood work, and imaging.  

Option Analysis

✅ No further testing is required:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Liver function tests:
Incorrect: Liver function tests should be performed if there is concern for disseminated herpes zoster. This patient does not demonstrate signs, symptoms, or risk factors for disseminated disease.  
❌ Tzanck smear:
Incorrect: Tzanck smear can be performed if the diagnosis of herpes zoster is unclear. However, the diagnosis can be made clinically in this patient presenting with a typical rash.  
❌ Viral PCR testing:
Incorrect: Varicella-zoster virus DNA can be detected using PCR testing, though this is typically only performed if the diagnosis of herpes zoster is unclear. The diagnosis can be made clinically in this patient with a typical rash.  
❌ Viral serologic testing:
Incorrect: Antibodies against varicella-zoster virus can be detected, though it is typically only performed if the diagnosis of herpes zoster is unclear. The diagnosis can be made clinically in this patient with a typical rash.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to frequent chest pain over the last three weeks. The pain is retrosternal and described as a “burning sensation.” It is more prominent when she lies down after dinner. Past medical history was notable for hiatal hernia and non-ST elevation myocardial infarction a year ago. Her medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, metoprolol, and lisinopril. She does not smoke or use illicit substances. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable except for mild epigastric tenderness. Electrocardiograms obtained during rest and while exercising are unremarkable. Troponin levels are within normal limits. A decision is made to start the patient on omeprazole. Which of the following steps involved in acid formation in the stomach is directly inhibited by this agent?

choices.text: Secretion of histamine from enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells
Formation of hydrogen ion and bicarbonate
Release of acetylcholine from neuronal endplate
Release of hydrogen ions from parietal cells

questions.solution:
This patient has retrosternal, burning chest pain that is more prominent when she lies down after dinner. She most likely has gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and is started on omeprazole, a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) that is considered a first-line agent for treating GERD.  

Physiologically, when food enters the stomach, it causes the stomach walls to distend. These changes lead to the activation of branches of the vagus nerve and the release of acetylcholine, thereby activating M3 receptors on parietal cells of the stomach. Next, the G-cells in the gastric antrum release gastrin, activating CCK2 receptors on parietal cells. Gastrin and acetylcholine activate the enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells, which release histamine and cause activation of H2 receptors on gastric parietal cells. Activation of M3, CCK2, and H2 receptors increases the conversion of water and CO2 to H+ and HCO3- by carbonic anhydrase. The H+ is then pumped out of the parietal cells and the stomach via the H+/K+ ATPase pump. These H+ ions combine with Cl- ions to form hydrochloric acid and help decrease the stomach pH.   

PPIs work by irreversibly inhibiting the H+/K+ ATPase pump, thereby inhibiting the release of hydrogen ions into the stomach. The result is decreased acid production.  



Option Analysis

❌ Secretion of gastrin from G-cells:
Incorrect: Gastrin is the major hormonal regulator of gastric acid secretion. The pH of the stomach influences gastrin release. Fasting and increased gastric acid in the stomach inhibit its release via somatostatin secretion from delta cells. Omeprazole and other proton pump inhibitors do not directly affect gastrin secretion.  
❌ Secretion of histamine from enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells:
Incorrect: Histamine is the major paracrine stimulator of acid secretion. Its secretion is upregulated by gastrin and acetylcholine. Proton pump inhibitors, such as omeprazole, do not directly affect histamine release.  
❌ Formation of hydrogen ion and bicarbonate:
Incorrect: Carbonic anhydrase assists in forming hydrogen and bicarbonate ions from CO2 and water. Although carbonic anhydrase is found in the stomach's parietal cells, its activity is not affected by proton pump inhibitors such as omeprazole.  
❌ Release of acetylcholine from neuronal endplate:
Incorrect: Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) that decreases the release of hydrogen ions into the gastric lumen. PPIs do not directly affect acetylcholine release from the neuronal endplate.  
✅ Release of hydrogen ions from parietal cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man comes to the office because of burning abdominal pain and discomfort. The pain began around two months ago, is located in the epigastric region, and does not radiate to other parts of the abdomen. The symptoms worsen after meals and are not associated with nausea or vomiting. Past medical history is significant for chronic back pain, for which he has been taking ibuprofen for the past two years. Family history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor and mild tenderness to deep palpation in the epigastric region. Laboratory studies are shown below. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy reveals the pictured findings at the gastric pylorus. Histopathology of the lesion shows superficial fibrinopurulent exudate, granulation tissue, and fibrosis with a margin composed of the hyperplastic gastric mucosa. No organisms are identified. Which of the following medications would have most likely prevented this condition?  

 Laboratory Value  Results 
 Hemoglobin  11.9 g/dL 
 Mean corpuscular volume  90 fL 
 Leukocytes  9,100/mm3 
 Platelets  165,000/mm3 
 Creatinine  0.7 mg/dL 

 

Image reproduced from Flickr.com
questions.solution:
This patient presents with burning epigastric pain associated with meals and prolonged nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug (NSAID) use. In addition, the patient has normocytic anemia, and esophagogastroduodenoscopy reveals a benign peptic ulcer. These findings are most suggestive of NSAID-associated peptic ulcer disease (PUD). Of the medications listed, a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) would have been the most effective primary prevention against NSAID-related ulcers. These include omeprazole, esomeprazole, lansoprazole, and pantoprazole.  

PPIs block gastric acid secretion by irreversibly inhibiting the hydrogen-potassium (H+/K+) ATPase pump that resides on the luminal surface of gastric parietal cells. They are first-line antisecretory therapy in the treatment of peptic ulcer disease. PPIs are available in oral as well as intravenous formulations. Side effects include Clostridium difficile infection, malabsorption of minerals (e.g., magnesium, vitamin B12, calcium, iron), and acute interstitial nephritis.    

PPIs are also used in prophylaxis against PUD. Current guidelines recommend combining NSAIDs with a PPI or misoprostol or switching to a selective COX-2 inhibitor (e.g. celecoxib).  



Option Analysis

❌ Calcium carbonate:
Incorrect: Calcium carbonate is an antacid that contains alkaline ions to help neutralize gastric acid. While it may provide symptomatic relief for occasional heartburn, it is ineffective in preventing NSAID-related gastric or duodenal ulcers.   
✅ Lansoprazole:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Octreotide:
Incorrect: Octreotide is a long-acting somatostatin analog. It is used for the management of acute variceal bleeds. It has no role in the primary prevention of NSAID-induced gastroduodenal ulceration.   
❌ Ranitidine:
Incorrect: Ranitidine is a reversible histamine H2-receptor antagonist (H2RA). Although high-dose H2RAs reduce the risk of NSAID-induced peptic ulcers, they are significantly less effective than proton pump inhibitors (PPIs). Furthermore, there is no clinical outcome data to prove that H2RAs reduce the risk of major gastric ulcer complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or ulcer perforation.  
❌ Sucralfate:
Incorrect: Sucralfate is a sucrose sulfate-aluminum complex that binds to the ulcer base and provides physical protection against stomach acid. Sucralfate may promote the healing of duodenal stress ulcers. It is not effective in preventing NSAID-related gastric or duodenal ulcers.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man comes to the office to evaluate fatigue, abdominal discomfort, and early satiety for the past six months. Past medical history is unremarkable. Family history is noncontributory. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a pale man with petechial lesions over the abdomen and splenomegaly. No peripheral lymphadenopathy is present. His hemoglobin concentration is 9.4 g/dL, leukocyte count is 4,100/mm3, and platelet count is 110,000/mm3. A peripheral blood smear is shown below. Bone marrow aspiration is attempted without success. The first-line treatment option for this patient’s condition acts on which of the following phases of the cell cycle?
 

Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Late G2 phase and early S phase

questions.solution:
This patient presents with fatigue, early satiety (due to marked splenomegaly), petechiae, pancytopenia, and a peripheral blood smear demonstrating lymphocytes with cytoplasmic projections. Combined with an unsuccessful bone marrow aspiration (dry tap), these features suggest hairy cell leukemia (HCL). HCL is an indolent B-cell neoplasm found in middle-aged men characterized by bone marrow failure and infiltration of the reticuloendothelial system. Purine analogs (i.e. cladribine or pentostatin) are the preferred initial treatment for most patients with symptomatic HCL and normal renal function.

Cladribine is a purine analog that inhibits DNA synthesis by acting specifically during the S phase of the cell cycle through various mechanisms. It becomes phosphorylated into a triphosphate form which is subsequently incorporated into newly synthesized DNA strands. It can also inhibit DNA polymerase, the key enzyme of DNA replication. Cladribine is also resistant to adenosine deaminase, which is the enzyme that usually degrades purines. Thus, this agent can reach very high levels inside cells, decreasing de novo purine synthesis. This agent is the medication of choice for treating patients with HCL and other leukemias. Side effects of cladribine include bone marrow suppression and megaloblastic anemia.
 

Option Analysis

❌ G0 phase  :
Incorrect: The G0 phase refers to the resting phase of the cell cycle. Cell cycle–independent drugs such as platinum (e.g. cisplatin) and alkylating agents (e.g. busulfan and cyclophosphamide) act on all cell cycle phases, including the G0 phase. These agents are not indicated as the first-line treatment option for hairy cell leukemia.  
✅ S phase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Late G2 phase and early S phase:
Incorrect: Topoisomerase inhibitors (e.g., etoposide, topotecan) target the late G2 and early S-phase of the cell cycle and interfere with DNA replication. These agents prevent DNA resealing by binding to and stabilizing a transient TOPO–DNA complex resulting in double-strand breakage and DNA damage. These agents are not indicated as the first-line treatment option for hairy cell leukemia.  
❌ G2 phase:
Incorrect: DNA proofreading occurs in preparation for mitosis during the G2 phase of the cell cycle. Bleomycin acts during this cell cycle stage and induces breaks in the DNA via free-radical damage. It is indicated in the management of testicular cancer and Hodgkin lymphoma (not hairy cell leukemia).  
❌ M phase:
Incorrect: This refers to the mitotic phase of the cell cycle. Medications that inhibit microtubule activity, such as vinca alkaloids (e.g., vincristine, vinblastine), taxanes (e.g. paclitaxel), epothilone analogs (e.g. ixabepilone), and eribulin act on this stage precisely. Cladribine (the first-line medication for hairy cell leukemia) acts on a different stage.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the office to evaluate recurrent sore throat and fever despite multiple courses of antibiotic therapy. The patient reports a two-month history of generalized fatigue. Temperature is 37.8°C (100.2 °F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 102/55 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient appears pale and has multiple pinpoints and red, non-blanching spots over his extremities. Splenomegaly is present on palpation of the abdomen. After further evaluation, a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia is established. The patient is started on a pyrimidine analog that competitively inhibits DNA polymerase-α and DNA polymerase-β, resulting in blockade of DNA synthesis and repair. Which of the following is an example of the medication prescribed to this patient?
questions.solution:
Cytarabine is an S phase-specific pyrimidine analog that becomes phosphorylated to Ara-CTP, a triphosphate metabolite, which subsequently binds to and competitively inhibits DNA polymerase. Ara-CTP is also incorporated into RNA and DNA, leading to chain elongation interference and defective ligation of fragments of newly synthesized DNA. Cytarabine is indicated in treating hematologic malignancies such as acute myelogenous leukemia and non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma. This agent carries no significant activity in the treatment of solid tumors. Primary adverse effects of cytarabine include myelosuppression, mucositis, nausea and vomiting, and neurotoxicity with the initiation of high-dose therapy.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Methotrexate:
Incorrect: Methotrexate is a folic acid analog that competitively inhibits dihydrofolate reductase and reduces dTMP levels, preventing DNA synthesis. It is typically indicated in the management of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (not AML).  
❌ Cladribine:
Incorrect: Cladribine is a purine (not pyrimidine) analog that inhibits DNA synthesis by inhibiting DNA polymerase and induction of DNA strand breaks. It is mainly indicated in the management of hairy cell leukemia.  
❌ Azathioprine:
Incorrect: Azathioprine is a purine (not pyrimidine) analog that incorporates into DNA, halting DNA replication and de novo purine synthesis. It is typically indicated in preventing organ rejection, rheumatoid arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease, and systemic lupus erythematosus.  
✅ Cytarabine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Paclitexel:
Incorrect: Paclitaxel is a microtubule inhibitor that hyper stabilizes polymerized microtubules in the M phase of the cell cycle. This agent is indicated in the management of ovarian cancer, not AML.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of fever, fatigue, and sore throat, which have been ongoing for 2 weeks. He thinks he may have “mono.” The patient has had sexual intercourse with three partners over the past year and has been using condoms inconsistently. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), blood pressure is 110/85 mmHg, and pulse is 73/min. Physical examination reveals cervical and supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. The tonsils are erythematous but normal in size. An HIV PCR test is positive for HIV-1. The patient is started on an antiretroviral regimen of emtricitabine, tenofovir, and dolutegravir. What is the mechanism of action by which dolutegravir acts as an HIV medication?
questions.solution:
This patient is started on dolutegravir, which works as an integrase inhibitor.  

Antiretroviral therapy (ART) is initiated at the diagnosis of HIV infection. It typically consists of a 3-drug regimen, consisting of 2 nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) and an integrase inhibitor.  

Integrase inhibitors, as the name suggests, reversibly inhibits HIV integrase, thereby blocking the integration of the HIV genome into host cell chromosomes. These medications are recognized by the presence of “tegra” within their name (e.g., bictegravir, dolutegravir, elvitegravir, raltegravir).    

Common side effects associated with integrase inhibitor therapy include nausea, headache, and myopathy with an increased creatine kinase level. 

Option Analysis

❌ Protease inhibitor:
Incorrect: Protease inhibitors include medications ending in “-navir”, such as atazanavir, indinavir, lopinavir, ritonavir, and saquinavir. By blocking viral protease, these agents are able to prevent HIV mRNA cleavage and the maturation of new viruses. They are associated with hyperglycemia, gastrointestinal intolerance, and lipodystrophy.    
✅ Integrase inhibitor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Entry inhibitor:
Incorrect: Entry inhibitors include enfuvirtide and maraviroc. Enfurvitide binds viral gp41 whereas maraviroc binds CCR-5 on T-cells/monocytes. In contrast, dolutegravir works as an integrase inhibitor.   
❌ Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor:
Incorrect: Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) are a mainstay of HIV treatment. They competitively inhibit nucleotides from binding to reverse transcriptase, thereby terminating DNA chain elongation. Examples of NRTIs include abacavir, didanosine, emtricitabine, lamivudine, stavudine, tenofovir, and zidovudine.  
❌ Non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor:
Incorrect: Non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs) include delavirdine, efavirenz, and nevirapine. These medications allosterically inhibit reverse transcriptase, thereby terminating DNA chain elongation. In contrast, dolutegravir works as an integrase inhibitor.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a fever and chills for the past 24 hours. She started feeling very tired last night and soon developed alternating bouts of fevers and chills. She has not had a cough or runny nose. On review of symptoms, the patient has diffuse myalgias. She has not had any sick contacts. Past medical history is significant for mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. She does not require supplemental oxygen but uses a tiotropium inhaler. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), blood pressure is 105/79 mmHg, heart rate is 101/min, and respiratory rate is 10/min. Oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears fatigued, and her skin is warm to the touch. A pulmonary exam is significant for rhonchi. Nasopharyngeal PCR swab is positive for influenza A. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents with influenza within 48 hours after symptom onset. The patient should be started on oseltamivir.  

Neuraminidase inhibitors, such as oseltamivir and zanamivir, treat influenza A and B. They inhibit influenza neuraminidase, thereby decreasing the release of progeny virus from infected cells. Therapy should be started within 48 hours of symptom onset to reduce the duration of illness.    

Oseltamivir can cause gastrointestinal disturbances such as nausea, vomiting, dyspepsia, and diarrhea. These side effects are less familiar with zanamivir, an inhaled powder. However, zanamivir should be avoided in individuals with underlying airway conditions, such as asthma or COPD, since the medication can cause bronchospasms.  



Option Analysis

❌ Zanamivir:
Incorrect: Although zanamivir is a neuraminidase inhibitor, it should be avoided in this patient with underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Zanamivir may cause bronchospasm in patients with underlying airway disease.   
❌ Prednisone:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms consistent with influenza A infection. Corticosteroids should be avoided since they can exacerbate the patient’s condition and increase mortality risk.  
❌ Oxygen supplementation:
Incorrect: Though the patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, her oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. In patients with chronic hypercapnic conditions, supplemental oxygen is generally indicated when oxygen saturation falls below 88%.   
❌ Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg):
Incorrect: IVIg is composed of pooled serum IgG from thousands of individuals. IVIg is rarely used to treat influenza and is reserved for severe cases. It would not be an appropriate treatment to administer IVIg to this patient, who presents with mild symptoms of influenza A infection.  
✅ Oseltamivir:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
